title: Experience Culture Night at Dublinia
description:
Dublinia, located at the heart of Viking and medieval Dublin, is a step back in time and a journey through the city as it was back then. Experience what life was like aboard a Viking warship, visit a Viking house, take a trip down a Viking street, and learn of the myths and the mysteries surrounding the Vikings and their legacy.

Journey through medieval Dublin and witness the sights, sounds, and smells of the busy city. Visit a rich merchant’s kitchen and walk along a bustling medieval street. See a magnificent range of Viking and medieval artefacts, and experience an immersive audio-visual show of one man’s life, growing up in medieval Dublin.

locations.title: Dublin City - Liberties And Historic Quarter

fullAddress: Dublinia, The Liberties, Dublin 8, Ireland

title: Explore The State Apartments in Dublin Castle
description:
Dublin Castle is delighted to invite the public onto its grounds once more to celebrate Culture Night Dublin 2024.

This year, the State Apartments in Dublin Castle will be open to the public free of charge until late.

The State Apartments were built as the residential and public quarters of the viceregal court. They were the seat of the executive and played host to fashionable and extravagant social events. Today, the State Apartments are the venue for Ireland’s Presidencies of the European Union, presidential inaugurations and other prestigious functions. Enjoy a complimentary visit to the heart of Irish history this Culture Night.

Last admission at 21:30. No advance booking required, admissions will start from 18:00 from the front door of the State Apartments with an outdoor queue in operation.

locations.title: Dublin City - Liberties And Historic Quarter

fullAddress: Dublin 8, D02 XN27, Ireland

title: Exploring Art Expression through the Medium of Sound with Sharon Mundy
description:
Immerse yourself in a therapeutic sound bath and enjoy the healing vibrations of the 7 chakra healing crystal bowls.

Participants will be invited to choose a Mandala template they are drawn to and create their own stencil Mandala using various colours. They then can take their creation and the template home with them to use in their homes as they please. All the while in silence whilst being smothered in rhythmic and healing tones. Art and Sound therapy will be combined to form a natural method of stress relief, healing and self-discovery.
fullAddress: Cullies, Cavan, H12 E5C7, Ireland

title: Exploring Identity Through Mask Making With Outcomers and Friends
description:
In response to Culture Night 2024’s theme of ‘One night for all, this mask making event is a fun and vibrant celebration of identity exploration. Held in the welcome, inclusive space of Outcomers LGBT+ Centre participants will create masks that reflect their unique journeys and reveal aspects of their identity. Participants will be encouraged to delve deep and use their masks to express aspects of themselves that are often hidden or suppressed. Different facets of the participants personality, experiences and emotions can be represented in this very enjoyable workshop.

A vast array of colourful and diverse materials will be provided including paints, sequins, feathers , fake fur and more, inviting creativity and individuality. Each beautiful and unique mask created will tell a story of courage, pride and the ongoing quest for self-identity. This event not only nurtures fun and creativity but also reinforces the importance of visibility and self-acceptance in the LGBT+ community.
fullAddress: Roden Place, Townparks, Dundalk, County Louth, Ireland

genres.title: Visual Arts (Painting, Photography, Sculpture, Digital Art, Print, Etc)

title: Exploring Solidarity Through Culture
description:
Comhlámh and Ireland Says Welcome Group are delighted to invite you to our celebration of Culture Night 2024 in our offices at 12 Parliament St, Dublin 2.

Guests are invited to experience a captivating and heart-warming evening that extends a warm embrace to all, transcending boundaries and cultures. This event is not just a gathering; it’s a celebration of unity, an opportunity for people from various walks of life to connect, share, and celebrate together. This event is dedicated to weaving a tapestry of connections that enrich the fabric of our community.

Come along for a delightful celebration that pays tribute to the kaleidoscope of people and their arts, crafts, music, and culinary traditions from around the world they bring to Ireland. It’s a chance for you to embark on a journey around the world without leaving the venue.

locations.title: Dublin City - Temple Bar And Creative Quarter

fullAddress: 12 Parliament Street, Temple Bar, Dublin 2, Dublin, Ireland

title: Extraordinary Bodies
description:
Join Galway Community Circus for an unforgettable Culture Night with world-renowned circus company Extraordinary Bodies! A collaboration between Cirque Bijou and Diverse City, Extraordinary Bodies is dedicated to promoting diversity and equity in the performing arts. Their boundary-breaking work celebrates diverse bodies, featuring talented D/deaf, disabled, and non-disabled artists, demonstrating how extraordinary people can work equally together on and off stage. The event includes an informal circus demonstration along with a presentation about the company followed by a Q&A session.

Audience members will then be treated to a screening of their one-hour film ‘Human’, a mesmerizing blend of circus, serenade, and cinema that explores the small moments that shape us. Join us for this inspiring celebration of inclusivity and creativity!

The performances, presentation and Q&A will run for about 1 hour. There will be a short interval. The run time of HUMAN is approximately 1 hour.

Photo credit: Extraordinary Bodies & Photographer Paul Blakemore
fullAddress: St. Joseph's Community Centre, Ashe Road, Shantalla, Galway, Ireland

title: F O X & O W L [impressions of nature]
description:
Join artist Sarah Ellen Lundy for a duo of gentle nature orientated activities suitable for all abilities! Self directed life drawing of the rarely visible red fox and long eared owl gives Culture Night audiences novel opportunity to regard at length these stunning specimens of native wildlife in Taxidermy form and conduct at their own pace observational drawings, materials and props provided.

Simultaneously audiences are invited to create their own botanical wall hanging by way of making clay impressions of plants to take home and treasure, materials and gentle guidance provided. Operated on a rotating drop-in basis, all welcome.

title: Faerie Dances
description:
Youth Ballet West will present ‘Faerie Dances’ in the magical setting of Claregalway Castle.

Join the enchanting fairy folk, pixies and goblins as the wonderful young dancers of Youth Ballet West enchant and entertain the crowds at Claregalway Castle. Catch a performance and then mingle with the dancers in the castle grounds as they surprise and delight children of all ages. Performances will run periodically during the 2hrs so come on down at any time to catch them in action. Suitable for all ages.

Charity organisation Youth Ballet West are a pre-professional ballet company based in Galway. Company members range in age from 14 to 19yrs and audition each year to join the company. They receive excellent training in ballet as well as contemporary dance and are given many performance opportunities throughout the year. Don’t miss their upcoming ‘Nutcracker’ this December in the Town Hall Theatre, Galway!

title: Fear and Fever: Living and Dying with Typhoid in Dublin
description:
Visit the Royal College of Physicians of Ireland, where a new exhibition exploring the history of typhoid in Dublin is being hosted on Culture Night. Discover the personal experiences of patients and medics during a time when germs and vaccinations were relatively unknown. See how typhoid was perceived, treated, and prevented.

This event is part of the joint Irish Research Council/Arts and Humanities Research Council funded ‘Typhoid, Cockles & Terrorism: How a Disease Shaped Modern Dublin’ exhibition series.
host: Royal College of Physicians of Ireland

title: Féile Dú Éige Culture Night
description:
Join Féile Dú Éige for a celebration of arts and culture!

Coláiste Acla and Scoil Acla will collaborate together for a traditional music, song and dance workshop, and a ciorcal cómhra for Irish speakers.

Following this, award winning dancers Katrina and Liam Costello who toured the world with Lord of The Dance will put on an Irish dance performance in their "local" pub

Drawing inspiration from fairy tales and classic children’s books, these jewels transport viewers to fantastical realms of imagination as only animation can. Goethe-Institut Irland is also delighted to present the Winner of the German Short Film Award 2022 ‘It Doesn't Have to Be Today. Directed by Sophia Groening, this coming of age film tells the story of four teenage friends in Cologne, who are looking for the right words (and punctuation) for a text message to a girl that one of the guys fancies.

During this workshop, participants will craft a beautiful handmade piece and gain the knowledge needed to pursue weaving independently.

Step-by-step instructions on setting up, winding the warp, and laying the foundation will be given as well as techniques for weaving, embracing the freedom to experiment with colours and textures on our frame. There will also be guidance on problem-solving and troubleshooting common weaving challenges, ensuring a smooth and fulfilling creative process.

title: Free Curators Tour of ‘Muscles and Mind: Irish Art Olympians’ Exhibition
description:
A guided curators tour of ‘Muscles and Mind: Irish art Olympians’ exhibition featuring artworks by Jack B Yeats, Letitia Hamilton, Mainie Jellett, Sir John Lavery, Desmond Broe, Father Jack P Hanlon, Stella Steyn and more.

The revival of the modern Olympic Games in the late 1890’s by baron Pierre De Coubertin embodied the ideal of a marriage between ‘Art and Sport, Muscles and Mind’. With support from the Waterford Arts Office, Creative Ireland, and the Olympic Federation of Ireland, the exhibition features artists from the Waterford Art Collection, as well as some of Ireland’s most renowned artists, who competed for their country in the Olympics between 1924 and 1948.

As part of the Creative Ireland funded ‘Muscles & Mind: Open-Call’, the gallery is also to present a group exhibition exploring themes of nationality, representation, and art as competition, by contemporary artists living and working in Ireland including Catherine Barron, James Horan, Ramon Kassam, Alison Lowry, Séamus O’Brien, Noel O’Donoghue, Laurence O’Toole, Csilla Toldy, Duc Van Pham, Síle Walsh and Lee Welch.

Lastly, the WGOA SETU Graduate Award Commission, will officially launch the newly commissioned portrait of Olympic silver medal winner John Treacy, by recent SETU Waterford Visual Arts Graduate, Sammy Kane.
fullAddress: 33 O'Connell St, Trinity Without, Waterford, X91 NX85, Ireland

title: From These Shores
description:
An exhibition of paintings by Rikki van den Berg and Harry McMahon, curated by Sinéad Smyth

'From these shores' is an exhibition of paintings from two very different perspectives, by artists Rikki van den Berg (Moville, Co Donegal) and Harry McMahon (Portstewart, Co Derry/Londonderry). Curated by Sinéad Smyth.

Two artists gazing across a body of water, one island, two countries and an unclaimed border. The act of painting can often be negated in today' s modern art world. Indeed, there are many galleries which no longer exhibit paintings. The act of creating artwork has transmuted and transcended towards the philosophical, geographical, and humanistic elements of this and other multidimensional lines of inquiry. A fine endeavour and necessary evolution. However, when all of that, which can also be communicated through the gesture of painting, brings us to question and wonder, consider this exhibition as one to sit with and ponder your own perspectives, from your own shore.

Exhibition continues to 8th November and is available to view during building opening hours. Additional opening times may be possible on request.
fullAddress: Echo Echo Dance Theatre Company, Magazine Street, Londonderry, UK

title: FUSE Arts: DIY Zine Making With Nichola Irvine
description:
Young people aged between 16 and 24, join illustrator and 2D animator, Nichola Irvine, on Friday 20th September from 7-9pm, for an evening of creative opportUNITY, activism, craic, personal and cultural exploration while exploring the process of DIY zine-making in the unique location of Atelier Hair in Ebrington Square!

For Culture Night 2024, young people aged 16-24 are invited to join illustrator and 2D animator, Nichola Irvine, on Friday 20th September from 7-9pm, for an evening of creative opportUNITY, activism, craic, personal and cultural exploration while exploring the process of DIY zine-making in the unique location of Atelier Hair in Ebrington Square!
Nichola Irvine, is a freelance Illustrator, 2d animator, painter, mural artist and teacher based in Belfast. Her work is a mix of traditional and digital and her aesthetic focuses on non-conventional canons of beauty; ugly art and colourful, quirky and often textural shapes.
Zines offer a wonderful medium for self-expression - whether you love keeping up with the latest fashion trends; are passionate about current affairs and politics; are an avid gamer; love sports; are a budding historian; or the next music journalist - zine-making is the perfect medium to express your thoughts and personal interests in a creative way! Zines can be super serious, or the silliest thing you have ever created - the options within the realm of zine-making are endless!
Don't worry if you're new to zine-making or already a zine machine creator, Nichola will guide you through the process of sharing your passions in a collaborative group setting at your own pace. No experience is necessary, and all materials and refreshments will be provided but you are welcome to bring your own.
If you have any accessibility needs, please email fuseartsni@gmail.com ahead of the event and we will do our best to accommodate you.

This workshop is kindly funded by the Derry City and Strabane District Council on behalf of T:buc, The Northern Ireland Executive and Community Good Relations Council as part of Good Relations Week 2024 #GRW24

title: Gallery Talks and Tour with Artist Neva Elliott
description:
Join artist Neva Elliott at the Pallas Projects/Studios for tours and discussion of her exhibition Notes on Being Human as part of the Artist-Initiated Projects 2024. Elliott’s practice deals with grief, healing after trauma, and the work everyone must do around difficult human emotions, drawn out through the artist’s own experiences of loss.

Pallas Projects/Studios is a not-for-profit artist-run gallery and studios dedicated to the facilitation of artistic production and discourse, via the provision of affordable artists studios in Dublin's city centre, and curated projects. PP/S addresses the necessity of providing space for artistic production and exhibition, and foregrounds the role of the project as a constant agent of discourse and transformation. They are dedicated to providing a constant space for artistic production and exhibition in Dublin, via an alternative art methodology and DIY work ethic.

Tours commence at 5pm and 7pm.

description:
For Culture Night 2024, GAZE International LGBTQIA Film Festival takes over the Outhouse LGBTQ+ Centre on Capel Street, Dublin, for a full evening programme that celebrates queer film-making from around the world.

The Outhouse basement space will house seated screenings of Irish and international short film programmes and feature films, specially curated by the GAZE programming team. Upstairs will feature a GAZE gallery-style takeover featuring projected cinematic installations throughout the evening, where visitors can come and go as they feel. Finally, the Library space will house talks and readings from film-makers and artists.

description:

She toured extensively through Australia, South Africa, France and Spain. During her travels she developed a lifelong passion for painting. Glenis is self-taught in art through many years of experience. Due to recent illness, paintings from her varied private collection are now being sold.

title: Glove Factory Tour & Demonstration
description:
George Horn Ltd opens its doors to the public on Culture Night to give an overview and demonstration of the processes that go into making a pair of leather gloves, from cutting, to sewing to finishing the gloves. Staff will also be sharing some reminiscences of the old days when the factory was in Ashtown.

George Horn Ltd is a family run glove making business based in Stoneybatter. The company was formed by George Horn in Ashtown in 1943, where it remained until 1972 when the original factory burnt down. After that the business moved to Prussia Street until the early 2000s and from there to Inchicore. In 2023 it relocated to Stoneybatter, and is delighted to open our doors on Culture Night to give visitors an insight into how we manufacture our gloves.

Not suitable for children under 14.

This event is now fully booked, however walk-ins may be admitted if capacity allows.

This interactive sensory installation captures and mimics visitors' movements, allowing them to flow and dance through the room, creating a dynamic and engaging environment. Paired with light art and music, this experience promises to transport visitors for a couple of hours into a captivating, ethereal world.

title: Gorey School Of Art Presents
description:
Gorey School of Art (GSA) is hosting Culture Night to celebrate diversity, creativity and community.

Programme of events Gorey School of Art

Performance workshops, Waves of Words, with Suzanne Walsh - 6-7pm
Suzanne Walsh is an artist and writer from Wexford living in Dublin. They work mainly with performance, voice, music, and audio, as well as some video and
photography. They use recitation, recordings, vocalisations, acting, and text appropriation to create rituals, invocations, poetic disturbances, guided tours, and performative lectures. Workshop is suitable for those aged 16 years and over.
https://www.suzannewalsh.ie/

Print Zine workshop - 6pm-8pm
Join us for the Print Zine Workshop from 6pm-8pm, led by Andrea Mc Corry, a Contemporary Printmaking tutor at Gorey School of Art. This workshop provides a
dynamic and creative environment where you can experiment with various printmaking techniques to craft your own unique zine. It's an opportunity to explore
new ideas, collaborate with others, and share your stories through the expressive and versatile medium of print. Whether you're looking to refine your skills or try
something new, this workshop is the perfect place to unleash your creativity. Workshop is suitable for those aged 16 years and over.

Experimental Painting Workshop with Patrick Redmond - 6-8 pm
This workshop offers a unique opportunity to delve into process painting and contemporary approaches to creating art. Guided by Redmond’s expertise, you'll explore innovative
techniques and conceptual frameworks that challenge traditional boundaries, helping you to develop your own distinctive artistic voice. Whether you're an experienced
painter or new to the medium, this workshop will inspire and expand your creative practice. Workshop is suitable for those aged 16 years and over.

James Merrigan - Screen Printed - Zine Exhibition, 6pm - 10pm
James Merrigan emerged as both an artist and art critic during the 2008 financial crash amidst an efflorescent blog culture. He continues to write under the frequency and critically confessional definition of an art blog. He cut his critical teeth as an independent, with a DIY back catalogue of online and printed identities, including +billion-journal and Fugitive Papers. His current identity, Small Night Projects, is where he now edits, screen-prints and exhibits art and text projects for publication and exhibition in collaboration with other artists and editors. He teaches at Gorey School of Art, and lectures in Psychoanalysis and Art at Trinity College Dublin.

Film Screening - The Hitch Hiker (1953), 6.30pm - 8pm

Live music event 8pm - 10 pm (over 18's)
- Absent Analogue : Funk-Jazztical tricknology and ninja tunes.

title: GPO Museum Self-Guided Visit & Talks
description:
Visit the GPO Museum for a special late evening opening to celebrate Culture Night Dublin 2024!

Take a self-guided visit to the museum and journey through the 1916 Rising, the War of Independence and the Irish Civil War. Learn about the creation of the Irish Free State that later became the Irish Republic, the partition of Northern Ireland and the Good Friday Agreement.

Explore the events of this revolutionary time from those who witnessed it and from different social, political and cultural backgrounds and viewpoints. Their stories are brought to life using over 100 artefacts, including personal items from people whose lives were changed forever by these events. Enjoy specially created talks from the museum's guides about Ireland's unique cultural identity and history. Plus, experience an immersive film that brings you into the heart of the action at the GPO during Easter week 1916.

fullAddress: GPO Museum, O'Connell Street Lower, North City, Dublin 1, Ireland

title: Grace Church – More Than Words with Loso and A.Ward – Rap, Spoken Word & Poetry
description:
A rare opportunity to witness two of the world’s Top 10 Battle Rappers; known for their Christian influenced word play.

With thought-provoking, captivating lyrics, the ‘More Than Words’ event features the renowned American-based spoken word artists, LOSO from Florida and A. WARD from Kansas City; alongside Cork poet and rapper Gerry D, and others.

LOSO, with his clear understanding that impressing people isn’t enough, aims to make a lasting impact with his performances.

A. WARD’s exceptional lyrical skills and dynamic delivery will inspire and entertain. Their poetry is studied in college curriculums and used in anger management counselling, highlighting its profound impact and relevance.

This family-friendly Cork Culture Night event takes place at Grace Church, 53 MacCurtain Street, Cork city, from 7-9:30pm; and everyone’s welcome.

The venue is directly across the road from the Metropole Hotel. People from 30+ nations, including Ireland (and especially our beloved Cork), come to Grace to experience church and feel at home. At Grace Church, we're a contemporary, independent local Christian community, full of life, fun, and a passion for the Living God; in Cork for over 25 years.

title: Grangegorman Histories Walking Tour
description:
This Culture Night, Friday, join Grangegorman Histories for a guided history walking tour of the Grangegorman site.

In the past 250 years, Grangegorman, on the northside of Dublin city centre, has been the site of a workhouse, a hospital, a prison and it is now integrating back into the city as a health and education campus for the HSE, TU Dublin and the local community. The historical buildings of Grangegorman stand as architectural monuments to its past and complex history. In this guided tour, we will explore the histories between the eleven protected structures and share some of those histories.

Over the course of the evening, there will be two guided tours starting from the concourse outside the East Quad, each lasting around 60 minutes.

There are a limited number of places available and registration is essential. Book early to avoid disappointment.

locations.title: Dublin City - Phoenix Park And Museum Quarter

fullAddress: Dublin, D07 XFF2, Ireland

title: Griffith College Campus Tour
description:
Griffith College extends a warm welcome to visitors to discover the storied history of its campus on Culture Night this year.

Originally known as the Grimswood’s Nurseries, in 1813 construction began on a remand prison which became known as the Richmond Bridewell. The likes of Daniel O’Connell and James Stephens became housed here and the site also saw the execution of Joseph Poole in 1883. It housed hundreds of prisoners including some from the 1916 Easter Rising, became the Wellington Barracks in 1892 and was one of the first barracks turned over after Ireland gained independence.

Renamed the Griffith Barracks, after Arthur Griffith in 1922 or 1923, it was eventually purchased to be utilised as a tertiary education institute in 1991 and today serves as home to Ireland’s largest independent third-level education provider.

Discover all of this and much more with a guided tour of the campus.

fullAddress: Griffith College, South Circular Road, Dublin 8, D08 V04N, Ireland

title: Guided Tour of Broadstone, Famous Dublin 7 Landmark Steeped in History
description:
This Culture Night, Bus Éireann are offering an exclusive guided tour of Broadstone, a famous Dublin 7 landmark steeped in history.

The historical Broadstone building operated as the headquarters of the Midland & Great Western Railway from 1847 and 1937. Built between 1841 and 1850, and known as the ‘Director’s House’, the building was designed by John Skipton Mulvaney and sat in front of a train shed offering rail access to points across the west of Ireland.

Since the establishment of Ireland’s national bus company, Bus Éireann, in February 1987, the building has operated as offices for Bus Éireann as part of the Broadstone bus depot.

Tickets for this event will be released soon.
fullAddress: Broadstone Bus Éireann Depot, Phibsborough Road, Phibsborough, Dublin 7, D07 X2AE

title: Guided Tour of Department of Finance and Government Buildings
description:
Visitors on Culture Night are invited on a guided tour of the interior of South Block Upper Merrion Street - the magnificent building that is home to the Department of Finance and the Department of Public Expenditure, NDP and Reform.

South Block was designed by Sir Aston Webb, the pre-eminent British architect of the early 20th century who designed the Victoria and Albert Museum, Admiralty Arch and the façade of Buckingham Palace, London. The building retains its original late Edwardian interior Government Buildings is Webb’s only known building in Ireland. Recent interior renovation work included restoration of original features. Come along for an exclusive peek behind the façade of this important Irish government building at one of their hourly tours for Culture Night Dublin 2024.

There will be four tours lasting around one hour each at 18:00, 19:00, 20:00 and 21:00.
fullAddress: Department of Finance, Merrion Street Upper, Dublin 2, Ireland

title: Guided Tour of The Church
description:
This Culture Night, The Church invites visitors to partake in a guided historical tour of their magnificent 18th century church building and explore the 323 years of history within the walls. From the moment it opened its doors in 1701, to hosting the wedding of Arthur Guinness in 1761, to becoming a bar in recent years, The Church has seen it all!

Tours will begin from 16:00 and run every 30 minutes until 18:00 for groups of up to a maximum of 8 people.

description:
Culture Night at Trinity College Botanic Garden is a rare opportunity for the public to be guided around a unique plant conservation, teaching and research facility with its large collection of plants from all over the world. There is an arboretum with many interesting trees, a sheltered walled garden that is home to some unusual and tender plants, and several glasshouses. Come and take a self-guided wander, or take a tour with Trinity botanists who will explain the importance of our collections and regale you with fascinating stories of plant adaptation and evolution.

The garden will be open from 16:00 with two guided tours, at 16.30 and 18.00. Booking is required for tours as places are limited, so please register early.
fullAddress: Trinity College Botanical Gardens, Dublin, Ireland

title: Guided Tour: From Barracks to Museum: An Introduction to Collins Barracks
description:
This Culture Night, join an interactive tour focusing on the story of Royal Barracks (now Collins Barracks) and the lives of soldiers who lived here between 1706 until 1993. Learn about their daily activities, living conditions, drilling and marching practices and experiences going to war.
This tour will also explore the story of Collins Barracks becoming a Museum, and will introduce visitors to some of the most fascinating artefacts in the Museum's collection.

This tour is available for a maximum of 20 people. Booking is not required, but places are offered on a first-come, first-served basis, with sign up at the Museum’s reception desk 15 minutes before the tour.

locations.title: Dublin City - Phoenix Park And Museum Quarter

title: Guided Tour: Recovered Voices: Stories and Experience of the Irish during World War One
description:
Come along to the National Museum of Ireland - Decorative Arts & History at Collins Barracks for Culture Night Dublin 2024 to join a fascinating interactive tour that focuses on the people involved in World War One and how the War impacted their lives. This tour, led by an experienced Museum guide, seeks to demonstrate the all-encompassing nature of the First World War and includes stories of nurses, doctors, prisoners of war and ordinary soldiers.

This tour is available for a maximum of 20 people. Booking is not required, but places are offered on a first-come, first-served basis, with sign up at the Museum’s reception desk 15 minutes before the tour.

title: Guided Tours & Printmaking Demonstrations at Black Church Print Studio
description:
For Culture Night 2024, Black Church Print Studio are inviting guests to join a guided tour of their studio and spectate live printmaking demonstrations.

Black Church Print Studio is a members organisation for professional artists working in fine art printmaking. Since its opening 40+ years ago, it has established itself as a significant and dynamic organisation. It has proved to be a valuable facility and resource for hundreds of artists and is now one of the leading contemporary fine art print studios in Ireland. The 4-storey building was custom built as a printmaking workshop with a gallery located on the ground floor. On the first level is a lithographic, relief print and digital print workshop area. The second level is the etching (Intaglio) workshop area. The top level provides a workshop for screen print and an analogue photography darkroom.

Tours and demonstrations start at 18:00 and take place every hour, on the hour. Duration 30 mins approx.

description:
The Grand Lodge of Ireland welcomes visitors to Freemasons' Hall, purpose built between 1866 and 1869 to serve as the headquarters of Irish Freemasonry.

The guided tours, operating on a first come, first served basis, will take in four Masonic meeting rooms of Classical, Egyptian, Gothic and Tudor styles and will give members of the public the opportunity to learn more about the centuries-old fraternity.

Come along to the National Gallery on Culture Night for an extensive programme of guided tours by knowledgeable gallery staff.

title: Guided Tours of the Royal College of Physicians of Ireland
description:
This Culture Night, the Royal College of Physicians of Ireland will be offering a small number of guided tours of their beautiful and historic building on Kildare Street. Opened in 1864 the building was designed by William Murray Junior and has been the home of the College ever since. On the tours, visitors will have the opportunity to uncover the history of the building, the College, and the development of medicine in Ireland.

Tours will be held at 17:30pm, 18:30pm and 19:30pm. Booking is essential.
host: Royal College of Physicians of Ireland
fullAddress: 6 Kildare Street, Dublin 2, Dublin, D02 E434, Ireland

title: Guido Fanzini’s Thunderous Entertainment Spectacular
description:
Fanzini Productions present Guido Fanzini.

Gather round, gather round to witness the jaw-dropping antics of this devilishly handsome Italian Kerryman, Guido Fanzini. Is he stupid or brave beyond belief? It really doesn’t matter as he presents 40 mins of fantastic comedy and pure fun in his spoof danger, comedy circus show.

Guido Fanzini is as bald as a goose egg, but looks good in chiffon and lace.

The language of death-defying stunts is used at every turn, giving a comic edge to all of his carry-on. Do not miss this hero of the Irish circus scene.
fullAddress: Killarney House, Muckross Rd, Demesne, Killarney, Co. Kerry, Ireland

title: Gúna by Gillian Grattan
description:
In this work-in-progress, Gillian delves into themes of sisterhood, memory, and forgiveness, inviting audiences on an immersive journey of significant dresses.

Join us for a reading at 8pm on Culture Night at Thomastown Community Centre as actors Susie Lamb and Dympna Hefferan breathe authenticity into the characters and narrative, offering a raw and authentic glimpse into the lives of two sisters as they look back on certain events in their lives.

The audience is taken back in time, as the sisters look back in time as they unpack their shared history while they pack up their mother's bedroom.

With the support of an Agility Award, Gillian has been developing the play under the mentorship of Kathleen Warner Yeates and spent a month at Waterford Little Room earlier this summer working on a first draft. Don’t miss your opportunity to experience Gúna as it continues to evolve and take shape.
fullAddress: Thomastown Community Center, Thomastown, Summerhill, County Kilkenny, Ireland

title: Gypsy Jazz Mayhem with Paradiso Gypsy Jazz Quartet
description:
Hear the best of Ireland’s jazz musicians perform the music of Stephane Grappelli and Django Reinhardt in the most intimate of acoustic surroundings this Culture Night Friday 20 September, as Paradiso Gypsy Jazz Quartet perform a series of pop-up mini-concerts in several participating Sligo restaurants from 8:00-10:30pm.

Eddie Lee - double bass

title: Half Arsed Half Biscuit Perform the Songs of Half Man Half Biscuit
description:
Half Arsed Half Biscuit will perform the great Half Man Half Biscuit songbook at Dolans, Kasbah, Limerick on Friday September 20th for Culture Night 2024.
They'll play 2 sets, then take requests.

Half Arsed Half Biscuit perform the songs of Half Man Half Biscuit. I guess that makes them a tribute band. Though as Birkenhead’s finest Half Man Half Biscuit are unlikely to ever come to Ireland for reasons that are their own Half Arsed Half Biscuit sometimes prefer to think of themselves as proxies, emissaries, evangelists if you like. Preaching to the converted and hopefully converting the converteds girlfriend, boyfriend or mate from work.

Half Arsed Half Biscuit was born of nothing more than the love of the band, their wonderful songs and the desire to hear those songs live in Ireland.

The well-worn pathways for Irish fans of the notoriously travel-shy Half Man Half Biscuit weave through the various airports and ferry terminals.
Half Arsed Half Biscuit present an opportunity to hear the incomparable genius of Half Man Half Biscuit, variously described as “the most authentic English folk act since The Clash” and “the Jimi Hendrix of lyricism” here at home in Ireland.

Session 1
Set 1 7pm-8pm
Session 2
Set 2 9.30pm-11pm
fullAddress: Kasbah Social Club, Dock Road, Courtbrack, Limerick, Ireland

title: Handling Session: War and Peace (and Food)
description: Join Museum Educators at the National Museum of Ireland – Decorative Arts & History at Collins Barracks to learn about the history of food and drink during wartime in Ireland with a fascinating range of artefacts from the Museum’s handling collection. Highlights include a vintage lockable tea caddy, antique silver drinks labels, a World War II-era cookbook, and a marrow spoon specially designed for a certain delicacy in the 19th century, among other illuminating objects about wining and dining through the ages.

description:
BUMBLEance is Ireland’s only dedicated Children’s Ambulance Service. This charity makes a difference by empowering the thousands of families unable to access their child’s healthcare through nationwide medical journeys in a safe, caring and fun environment, offered completely free of charge.

For Culture Night 2024, BUMBLEance are offering a chance to tour one of their ambulances, speak with a driver and chat with their staff about the vital work they do. Plus – there might even be a few freebies on the day!

See how BUMBLEance keeps their wheels turning and register to attend today.

title: HeART of Gaza
description:
HeART of Gaza is an exhibition of children's art direct from the genocide. 50+ artworks by 27 young Palestinians, aged 3 to 17, offer us an intimate insight into the reality of childhood in Gaza in 2024. Naturally, some of the paintings deal with incredibly tough topics. But there are also plenty of favourite hobbies, beloved pets and best friends - art that any child might create. This is perhaps what hits home the hardest.

Each piece is accompanied by a statement from the artist, giving the most vulnerable, the most impacted and the most voiceless in this genocide an opportunity to be seen and heard.

HeART of Gaza is a collaboration between friends, Feile Butler (Sligo) and Mohammed Timraz (Deir al Balah). Feile will be there on Culture Night to give the backstory to this life-changing project.

Live music will be provided at the wine reception by local band, Killing Dove.

The exhibition will remain open to the public on 21-22 and 28-29 September. Over both weekends, visitors are invited to create art in response to HeART of Gaza. These messages of hope, empathy and solidarity will be sent back to Mohammed and the children in Gaza.

Enter the garden and find tiny botanical details within this beautiful medieval manuscript. Learn all about the history of the book: when, why and for whom it was made. Admire the beautiful ornamental decorations and exquisite illuminations.

This drop-in event is limited to 15 participants. Come along on Culture Night for a last look before this exhibition closes on 22 September.

title: Hen’s Teeth & Rory Bowens Present: Nocturnal Beats featuring Róisín Berkeley, Bog Band & Dreamcastmoe
description:
Hen's Teeth and Rory Bowens present a night of local and international talent for Culture Night with solo harpist Róisín Berkeley, Dublin three-piece Bog Band & Washington DC based producer and vocalist Dreamcastmoe.

Hen's Teeth is a cultural events space based out of Blackpitts, Dublin 8.

Nocturnal Beats: Culture Night Late Venue Trail offers a series of free events showcasing Dublin's vibrant nightlife. From Index to Tengu, Hen's Teeth to Fidelity, the trail covers diverse neighbourhoods and cultural hubs. This year, Culture Night introduces seven new venues, welcoming a broader audience and celebrating long into the night. Spanning the City Centre and from Dublin 8 to Dublin 7, the late-night trail explores the city's heartbeat with traditional nightclubs, late-night bars, and cultural spaces. Featuring DJ culture, electronic music, and top-notch sound systems, Nocturnal Beats highlights the dynamism and relevance of electronic music culture today.

Venues: Index; Tengu; Pygmalion; Hen's Teeth; Fidelity; Love Tempo; and WigWam..

title: Hidden Sounds Below Ground
description: Imagine that for one moment, a vibrant, healthy, living soil ecosystem where worms thrive, macro and micro-organisms scratch, eat, reproduce, move and burrow. Now imagine the opposite, a soil that has been left bare, exposed and unprotected. A soundless and silent soil ecosystem. It’s this very life, these sounds, vibrations and noises that will be shared in Sligo’s Peace Park. By 'listening with soil’, we can connect with soil in an empathetic way.

title: Historical and Architectural Tour of St Columba’s College
description:
St Columba's College has been on its current site since 1849. This tour offers a rare opportunity to see the campus and visit significant buildings. These include the 1880 Chapel (the only building in the Republic of Ireland designed by the great church architect William Butterfield), the 1971 modernist Science Block (architect: Robin Walker of Scott Tallon Walker), the Georgian Hollypark House, and Whispering House (2019), as well as lovely gardens.

The tour starts in the Chapel at 7.00pm, and will be led by the Sub-Warden of the College, Julian Girdham, who will give an overview of the school's history. Since the boarding school will be in operation during the tour, the event will end by 8.30pm.
fullAddress: St. Columba's College, Kilmashogue Lane, Whitechurch, Dublin 16, Dublin, D16 CH92, Ireland

title: Historical Walk Through Waterford Courthouse With Maxine Keoghan
description:
Waterford Courthouse is pleased to announce its participation in this year's Culture Night, welcoming the public to explore one of Waterford's most architecturally stunning buildings.

Courthouse Manager, Brian Leonard, expressed his excitement about opening the doors of this historic site to the community. "We are delighted to welcome the public into what is one of Waterford’s most architecturally beautiful buildings," he said. "Culture Night provides a unique opportunity for everyone to experience the rich history and function of the courthouse firsthand."

The event will feature guided tours led by Dr. Maxine Keoghan, a Courts Services staff member and historian, who will provide insightful commentary on the building's history. Attendees will also have the opportunity to learn from other staff members about how the courthouse is utilized by the public and various stakeholders in the justice system.

Two tours will be conducted throughout the evening, offering an engaging exploration of the courthouse's architecture and its role within the community.

The evening will begin on a high note with a performance by Waterford's De La Salle Pipe Band. Celebrating 90 years of piping in Waterford, the band will lead the way, adding a traditional and vibrant element to the evening.

TIMES TO BE CONFIRMED
fullAddress: Waterford Court Office, Catherine Street, Waterford, Ireland

title: History of the Balbriggan Courthouses with Local Historian David Sorenson
description:
Balbriggan Courthouse has been a dominant feature of George's Square for more than 170 years. However, to date very little information on its history has been placed in the public domain.

David’s presentation traces the arc of a number of courthouses in Balbriggan, with emphasis on the current building, looking at how and why it came to be built on its present site. A sample of some of the court cases held in the building, both minor and serious, will be examined. Booking required.

title: How Are Medicines Made?
description:
Tour NIBRT and discover the remarkable science behind manufacturing life-saving medicines. NIBRT is the National Institute for Bioprocessing Research and Training. NIBRT’s mission is to help the growth and development of the biopharmaceutical manufacturing industry by providing cutting edge training and research solutions. Bioprocessing is any process that uses living cells to get an end product. Lots of medicines are made this way, using mammalian cells to produce a protein, such as an antibody that is actively therapeutic in humans. At NIBRT we have a training facility that has all of the elements of a biopharmaceutical manufacturing plant. Here we offer training to staff working in the industry and third-level university students. NIBRT is also a world-class research institute with a large team working to find solutions to challenges facing the biopharma industry.

This event will consist of a short introduction to NIBRT followed by a tour of the facility. Our scientists will be on hand to talk you through what we do at NIBRT. Please note that this event is suitable for ages 12+. For the tour of the facility, closed toe flat shoes and clothing that covers legs must be worn.
fullAddress: Foster Avenue, Mount Merrion, Dublin A94 X099

title: How I Love Their World

South Kerry is her personal time machine, joyous ,sheltered ,sometimes oppressive ,veined with turbulence from harsher times.

title: Iconic Irish Voices at the GPO
description:
Celebrate Culture Night Dublin 2024 with a visit to the GPO. Come see the beautiful building which houses the General Post Office and enjoy some great music inspired by new Irish Stamps. Send a free Culture Night postcard to family and friends, at home and abroad, while stocks last.

title: If Lace Could Talk – Lace Stories
description:
We will present a 10 min video running in a loop in the Limerick Museum on Culture Night, presenting the stories behind five lace objects (both traditional and modern) designed to be worn.

After a brief introduction on the characteristics and history of Limerick lace, the stories of five lace artefacts and their creators will follow . Three of these are historical pieces from the museum's collection: a blouse from the Florence Vere O'Brien collection, a black shawl from the Eileen O'Donohue collection, and a fan from the Maude Kearney collection.
The last two pieces are contemporary Limerick lace and will be presented by their creators.

The video will run in a loop on a screen in the Limerick Museum on Culture Night

The same video will be premiered on the Limerick lace YouTube channel (https://www.youtube.com/@LimerickLace22) on Culture Night.

Session 2 7pm - 7:15

title: If we save the ocean, we save the earth | We Act
description:
Seabed Sanctuary Artist Collective presents a film and music evening focusing on our oceans, and West Cork shores.

7.30pm: Our Toxic Romance with Plastic documentary by Chris O'Connor will be introduced by Nic Slocum of Whale Watch West Cork, with guest speakers and question time.

8.30pm: Music from the Seabed, concert: Marcus Maeder interweaves field recordings of Bantry Bay from the research project Sounds of Water and Land - Glór Uisce agus Tallamh with sound fragments and passages from his latest release, Drifts. The result is a multi-layered, sonic burrow that brings natural sounds from the sea and land together with synthetic sounds into a harmonic polyphony.

8.30pm: Marine Biodiversity of West Cork, 7 years' photography around our shores and shallows by Julia Cooper documenting creatures, seaweeds and habitats

title: If You Go Down the Town Today, You’ll Be In for a Wee Surprise…
description:
This Culture Night, discover 20 unique small ceramic bears, each one lovingly decorated by an established Donegal artist and artists from the HSE Ascain Artlife programme in Letterkenny.

These beautifully crafted bears will be displayed in the windows of 20 shops, pubs, and restaurants along the main street, from the Old Courthouse down to Donegal Stationery, Lower Main Street. Your mission? Find all 20!

This project, conceived by artist Peadar McDaid in collaboration with Buncrana ceramic artist Áine Ní Danu, began with Áine casting and firing the bears before sending them to artists across the county to be transformed and brought to life with creativity and care.
Each bear will be available for purchase at €30, with all proceeds going to the Irish Guide Dogs for the Blind. It’s a fun-filled activity for the whole family, so come along and see how many bears you can find!

If you spot a bear that you like and wish to purchase, contact Peadar on (086 854 00 20) or email him at peadarmcdaid@gmail.com

The artists involved include: Aine Ni Danu, Franck Saucian, Joe Gildea, Tiarnan O'Boyle, David Hemmerle, Cheyenne McDonald, Ciaran Boden, Oli Sulima, Peadar Mc Daid, Thomas Putt, Aidan Sharkey, Chris Holmes, Deborah J Stockdale, Niamh Onofrei, Brian O' Neill, Anna Stainby, Mary Ronayne, Niamh McFadden, Maria McGrory and Koko.
fullAddress: Upper Main Street, Letterkenny, County Donegal, Ireland

title: Illustrated Talk and Musical Performance of the Uilleann Pipes
description:
Na Píobairí Uilleann (NPU) welcome visitors to their headquarters, located in their historical Georgian building on one of Ireland's most architecturally important streets. Come and listen to a short illustrated talk on all things uilleann piping in their dedicated archive and library. Head downstairs to hear live uilleann piping performances from some of Ireland's young and established leading players on this uniquely Irish musical instrument.

Talks take place every hour with performances from different uilleann pipers taking place every 20 minutes.

NPU is a thriving arts organisation dedicated to sharing the sound of Ireland through the preservation, promotion and performance of the uilleann pipes and their cultural heritage. In 2017, uilleann piping was included on UNESCO's Representative List of Intangible Cultural Heritage of Humanity.

description: This event, starting at 18.00 at the University of Galway, includes a talk by Prof. Felix Ó Murchadh, Professor of Philosophy, exploring the connection between the imagination and the environment through a rarely-seen piece from the University art collection (18.30 - 19.30). After the talk, there will be a late opening in An Dánlann - the University Art Gallery - of the exhibition '(Un)Real Ireland', which explores connections between the work and ideas of Anglo-Irish philosopher and novelist Iris Murdoch and the West of Ireland (the event ends at 21.00). Drop-in workshops will take place throughout the evening facilitated by the AIRE (Attentive Inquiry Reclaiming Environment) research team (more on the IRC New Foundations project here https://aireinquiryandenvironment.wordpress.com/).

title: In Dreams
description:
In Dreams is an exhibition of work by Arno Kramer and Cecilia Bullo. From the Netherlands, Arno Kramer has been exhibiting in Ireland since 1995 and has shown at Green on Red Gallery, Limerick City Gallery of Art, The Model, Ballina Arts Centre, Galway Arts Centre and The Mermaid Arts Centre. Cecilia Bullo works primarily in sculpture and installation.

Her practice is informed by historical, mythological, psychoanalytic and ecofeminist theories, creating a vital conceptual framework for her physical work. In particular, she is interested in material cultures relating to rituals of healing and transformation. Cecilia will give a Gallery Talk about the exhibition at 7.30pm.

INCANTATIONS is an exhibition that delves into the metaphysical realm through themes of sound, vibration and cymatics. Through painting, print, installation, animation and sound, Conroy’s work invites its audience on a journey beyond the visible world, exploring the unseen forces that shape our reality, connecting to a higher consciousness.

Varo are singers and fiddle players Lucie Azconaga and Consuelo Nerea Breschi. They perform Irish traditional songs and tunes with arrangement influences from folk, baroque and classical traditions, weaving around the melodies with harmonies, drones and countermelodies.

The performance by Varo will kick off at 19:00.
Suitable for ages 8+. Children must be accompanied by an adult at all times.

title: Inexplicable Tales
description:
What if you were asked if you’ve ever had an experience that you can’t explain?

We have found that most people have their own unexplained tale to tell, and we intend to document more of these stories during Culture Night in our studio in Dominic Street.
These experiences can be sensory, connected to clairvoyance, UFOs, fairies, magic… where sceptics scoff, we are all ears.

If you would like us to record your story, email us: galwaysotherworld@gmail.com. Give a brief description and your contact details, and your permission to potentially use your story in our podcast.
We will then book you in for a short session -free of charge- on Culture Night, and you will receive a copy of your own recording.

The Culture Night recordings will be done in 15 to 30-minute slots and may book out, so please contact us early. However, Galway’s Otherworld is an ongoing project, and we welcome stories via our email address throughout the year.

title: Instant Dissidence Presents ‘Dancing With Strangers: From Palestine to Ireland’
description:
A dancer stands on the streets of Dublin with outstretched arms and a t-shirt that says “Dance With Me”. Will you accept their invitation?

Dancing With Strangers: From Palestine to Ireland is a guerrilla-style, durational, one-on-one participatory work. During the performances, Ireland-based dancers invite audiences to dance with them as they ‘stand in for’ four Palestinian dancers who are unable to be present.

As a choreographic act of resistance, Palestinian artists Agour, Just, Khaled and Maryam have been remote-working with Instant Dissidence’s Artistic Director, Rita Marcalo, to create dance duets that they would like to perform with the people of Ireland. As they are unable to be physically present in Ireland, this is achieved by members of the Irish dance community acting as ‘body avatars’ for the Palestinian dancer’s role in their respective duets. Through their Irish avatars (and the exchanged gift of dance) Agour, Just, Khaled and Maryam are asking for their voices to be heard and their bodies to be felt.

Dance with a stranger and complete the connection.

Dancing With Strangers: From Palestine to Ireland has been supported by Create (the National Development Agency for Collaborative Arts) with funding from The Rowan Trust. Also supported by the Irish Network Against Racism with funding from The Rowan Trust. Supported by Apartheid-free Dance. An Instant Dissidence production.

This is an 18+ event.

Dancing with Strangers will take place at the following locations and times:

Capel Street (Strand Street Junction) from 17:00 - 18:00
Barnardo Square from 18:30 - 19:30
Cow’s Lane from 20:00 - 21:00

Image credit: Dancing With Strangers From England to Calais, Instant Dissidence © Paul Blakemore

title: International Rugby Experience Architectural Tour
description:
The International Rugby Experience is excited to announce a very special Architectural Tour for Culture Night 2024.

The International Rugby Experience building is already an iconic landmark in Limerick city. It is the recipient of multiple architectural and building awards including the Royal Institute of Architects of Ireland Public Choice award, Architectural Project of the Year (Irish Building & Design Awards 2024), Brick Awards 24 Grand Prize Winner (Overall & Public Spaces Category) and Tourism & Hospitality Project of the Year (Irish Construction Industry Awards 2023).

For those interested to see the building in more detail, and to hear about the inspiration behind it, Culture Night offers them the opportunity to take a tour with Tom McGlynn of Niall McLaughlin Architects, the team behind the vision and delivery of the design. Tom was Project Architect on the International Rugby Experience, from concept design in 2017 up to handover of the building in 2022, overseeing the planning process, technical design and construction stages.

There will be two International Rugby Experience Architectural Tours on the evening, each lasting approximately 45 minutes and bringing visitors through the building from ground floor reception to the 6th floor Legends Gallery.

Places are limited and must be pre-booked.

title: Introduction to Lino Printing
description:
This introductory workshop with local artist Terry Lawless will introduce participants to the basic skill of relief printmaking. The participants will have the chance to make their own one-colour design that they will transfer onto a lino block, carve out, ink up and print.

We will look at a brief history of lino printing and how it has impacted on the areas of craft, graphic arts as well as fine arts. How print is currently enjoying a revival and where you can see it.

The participants will be introduced to the process of developing a design. We will look at composing a simple design, exploring the art elements of line and tone and the design principles of contract and balance. In using these the students will develop a simple design that can be transferred to the block.

The participants will then learn the skills needed for inking up blocks and testing different techniques to roll out inks. They will then have time to print their design onto a variety of surfaces, including different types of papers as well as fabrics.

All students will go home with several prints made from their designs.
All tools, inks, rollers, cutting tools, pencils, and papers will be supplied.
There is no need to be able to draw! Terry has plenty of ways around this!!
Bring a simple A5 (Half A4) image that you would like to make into a design, If you don’t have one or forget, Terry will supply one.

Please book by contacting Loretta in the library at Lrose@wicklowcoco.ie or calling 0404-67025
fullAddress: Wicklow Library, The Mall, Corporation Lands, Wicklow, Ireland

title: Introduction to Music with Locanda
description:

This sound workshop and talk is aimed at an audience of all ages with an interest in music. The public will be able to better understand the basic concepts used in music and thus approach this wonderful world more precisely.

The members of the group Locanda will answer big questions, for example: what is sound? What are its characteristics? What is music? Through practical examples the audience will see the difference between rhythm, melody, and harmony, and the types of instruments according to the source of vibration (wind, string, percussion, etc.).

After this introduction, the workshop will focus on the different parts of the instruments available in the room: violin, guitar, bass, saxophone, cajón, cymbals, shakers and voice.

description:
Experience Irish National Opera’s Out of the Ordinary/As an nGnách, the world’s first virtual reality community opera at The Dock, Accenture’s global R&D and innovation centre.  As part of this totally unique experience, attendees will get to travel to an imagined, animated world, with the ability to move around and interact with the environment.

Out of the Ordinary/As an nGnách tells the tale of a community, forced to flee their barren homeland, which, due to their own actions, can no longer sustain them. Nalva, the main character, builds a boat to take her people on an epic journey to find a new home. 

Written by composer Finola Merivale, librettist Jody O’Neill, working with director Jo Mangan and students from rural Ireland and communities from Inis Meáin, Tallaght and South Dublin.

Suitable for ages 14+

This Culture Night, Trinity Trails are offering an Irish Sign Language (ISL) tour of Trinity campus. This 45-minute guided walking tour spans Trinity campus, taking in its architectural highlights. Walk in the footsteps of famous past students and discover the hidden gems and extraordinary stories of Ireland's oldest university.

Meeting point: the Bell Tower in Trinity's Front Square. Please note that this free tour is exclusively in Irish Sign Language and will not have any translation or spoken commentary.

title: Irish Whiskey Museum – Classic Tour
description:
Visit the Irish Whiskey Museum on Culture Night to enjoy their famous one-hour experience inclusive of a fully guided tour plus three perfectly crafted Irish whiskey tastings. Join an immersive, fully guided tour where you’ll have the opportunity to enjoy three distinct and carefully selected Irish whiskeys that showcase the variety, tradition, and innovation of this iconic Irish spirit.

Tours are designed to be interactive and informative. You’ll have the chance to ask questions, engage with experts, and gain a deep understanding of the whiskey culture. Whether you’re a whiskey connoisseur or just a casual drinker, this tour is bound to create unforgettable memories for all.

title: Island City Urban Sculpture Trail – Tour. Meeting Point: Triskel Arts Centre
description:
Meeting Point: Triskel Arts Centre

Take part in a guided walking tour of Island City: Cork’s Urban Sculpture Trail led by Sample-Studios; Art Historian Dr Matthew Whyte and members of their Studios of Sanctuary project. Tours are FREE but booking is essential.

Three tours will be offered of one-hour duration each, beginning at 5:45pm, 7pm, and 8:15pm. Each tour will commence at Triskel Arts Centre.

These tours are the first of an ongoing series access initiatives as part of the Island City Project.
A series of innovative access services will be available during these tours. These services
include:
● ISL interpretation
● Assisted listening technology
● Tactile resources
● Audio description via NaviLens codes.

When booking, please indicate which of the above services you require and if you have any
additional access requirements.

You can download the NaviLensGo app to your personal device – search and download this from your appstore.

After the tour, participants are invited to join Sample Studios of "Sanctuary"; artist Elize de Beer to create a screen printed tote bag, inspired by the Island City Urban Sculpture Trail.

The final stop of this tour will be the viewing of short film on the topic of the artworks, visible to all visitors to Triskel on Culture Night. Where materials allow, those not on the tour may also have an opportunity to create the screenprinted bag
host: Sample-Studios in partnership with Cork City Council

title: It’s All Up In The Air!
description:
Westside Resource Centre is hosting a film screening on the topic of air quality and its impact on the community. Westside Resource Centre is the Community Partner on the Air We Share project which aims to tackle air quality through art, community education and citizen action.

The Air We Share brings together a consortium of local partners, led by Galway City Council, including Galway Arts Centre, the University of Galway’s Centre for Creative Technology, the Centre for Climate and Air Pollution Studies and Physics, Westside Resource Centre, and Galway Culture Company.

The project is a recipient of the Creative Climate Action fund, an initiative from the Creative Ireland Programme. It is funded by the Department of Tourism, Culture, Ats, Gaeltacht, Sport and Media in collaboration with the Department of the Environment, Climate and Communications. The fund supports creative, cultural and artistic projects that build awareness around climate change and empower citizens to make meaningful behavioural transformations.

Find out more: www.theairweshare.ie/
fullAddress: Westside Resource Centre, Seamus Quirke Road, Galway, Ireland

title: Jack B. Yeats; The Wandering Gaze
description:
'The Wandering Gaze' presents a collection of images relative to Travelling people in the work of Jack Butler Yeats. Highlighting Yeats’ keen observations of diversity amongst nomadic groups within Irish society in the late 19th and early 20th centuries, the exhibition includes sketchbook drawings, illustrated prints, watercolour and oil paintings spanning the breath of his career. The exhibition was developed with participants from the Sligo Traveller Support Group working with the writer and Traveller Culture Collections Development Officer in the National Museum, Oein DeBhairduin.

Presented in partnership with Cairde Sligo Arts Festival. Curated by Dr. Julie Brazil.

PLEASE NOTE THAT THIS EXHIBITION IS OPEN FROM 11 AM TO 5 PM, NOT FROM 4 PM LISTED ON THE PAGE

title: James Joyce Centre Self-Guided Visits & House Tours
description:
Visit the James Joyce Centre for a special late evening to celebrate Culture Night 2024!

The James Joyce Centre is situated in a gorgeous 18th-century Georgian townhouse. Explore the museum to see our exhibitions about the life and work of James Joyce, one of Ireland's most famous and influential writers. Current exhibitions include:

A history of the publication of Finnegans Wake.
Three art installations based on Ulysses.
Film screenings.
A virtual reality headset based on scenes from Ulysses.
The door from No. 7 Eccles Street, the home of Leopold and Molly Bloom in Ulysses.
Various manuscripts and materials from Joyce's time.

Visitors are welcome to explore the house, a beautiful example of high-Georgian architecture.

The Joyce Centre will also offer free guided tours of the house every half-hour from 18:00 to 20:00.

title: Joseph Walsh & Sara Flynn Exhibition
description:
The Centre Culturel Irlandais is delighted to present new works by renowned designer and maker Joseph Walsh in special collaboration with ceramic artist Sara Flynn. Dialogue between the two dates back over fifteen years around their common passion for material and form. Here at the CCI, in a poetic interweaving of expression, twelve unique sculptural Enignum Wall Brackets hold twelve porcelain vessels and a landscape of vessels spread across the burr ash surface of an Enignum Dining Table. Together, these organic sculptures and ceramics are contextualised and create an uplifting ensemble of infinite delicacy.

To coincide with Culture Night, the Centre Culturel Irlandais will be holding the exhibition opening on Friday 20 September. There will be a food truck onsite in the courtyard, plus music by Irene and Linda Buckley from 8pm.

title: Josh Johnston – Compositions & Improvisations
description: Josh Johnston is a pianist, arranger and composer/songwriter from Dun Laoghaire. For Culture Night, he will be entertaining audiences at Dublin Unitarian Church with his own compositions and improvisations. After graduating from the University of Salford with a degree in Popular Music in 1997, Johnston bided his time for a few years, working in radio and music retail before taking the plunge to try his hand at being a full-time musician in 2000. He has written and performed with many performers over the years. His most recent solo albums are Reasons to Fly, (2022), and Where We’re Standing Now, (2021). Josh has directed and sung in many chamber choirs, (he currently sings with the Laetare Vocal Ensemble). He also accompanies choirs, singers and soloists; for exams, rehearsals and recitals and is the organist at the Unitarian Church in Dublin.

title: Keeping the Connection – An Evening To Celebrate the Relationships We Have Nurtured Overtime in This Place.
description:
There will be something for everyone this Culture Night at Strokestown Park House.
With a series of events taking place in the Vaulted Stables performance space, and the lovely enclosed former stable yard, it will be an evening filled with music, art, film and even some dressing up!
Early career researcher and PhD candidate Grace Rinehart-Macrae is an expert in historical clothing when she isn’t studying medieval castles for her thesis. Using historically accurate designs and up-cycled materials Grace hand stitches costumes for theatre, and re-enactments. For Culture Night, Grace will present samples of her work and will explain the process of making them. You may even get a chance to dress up in an outfit originally designed hundreds of years ago!

Paper conservator and artist Olena Kovalevych, along with some of our volunteer team has been putting together an exhibition of paintings, based on the Historic Walled Gardens at the Park. Olena is a master of the petrykivka painting style. There will be a drop-in workshop where participants will learn some of the basics of this traditional painting style, which has been listed on the UNESCO list of Intangible Cultural heritage of Humanity.
Both Grace’s and Olena’s workshops are perfect for all ages.

Fim maker Padraig Cunningham and sound artist Natalia Beylis have collaborated on a short film inspired by the work of the curator and volunteers here at Strokestown Park House, as they sort through a collection of recently re-discovered artefacts. This film which has been inspired by the idea that objects have their own history and story, will be shown for the first time on Culture Night. This film has been kindly supported by Creative Ireland through Roscommon County Council Arts Office.
Curator, archivist and musician Martin Fagan returns to Strokestown Park House, bringing his band Stalked by Story to perform in the historic surroundings of the Vaulted Stables. Hailing from Westmeath, Stalked by Story are building up a steady following throughout the mid-lands and will bring their Gothic folk tales of souls from times long past, rural heroes and heroines to the good people of Strokestown.
Be prepared to be amazed by sound artist Natalia Beylis who will perform original work inspired by her time spent at Strokestown House this year. Natalia’s' art revolves somewhere between sonic story-teller and multi-instrumental explorer. She has released 35 albums between solo works and collaborations and has appeared on numerous compilation releases.
We are thrilled to have such a high calibre of artists with us for Culture Night and we hope that you can come along to experience this wonderful initiative with us.
host: Strokestown Park House | National Famine Museum

title: Kevin McSherry Exhibition ‘Going to See a Man About a Horse’
description:
Éigse Terenure are delighted to present 'Going to See a Man About a Horse', an exhibition of the amazing work of award-winning artist and editorial illustrator, Kevin McSherry.

McSherry’s paintings are narrative-laden, and some stories are humorous while others are tinged more darkly. Playing with the viewer's imagination and wit, the compositions are intentionally absurd and thoroughly enthralling, drawing the eye and mind into his world. McSherry’s pieces have been exhibited in galleries in London, Paris, Dublin and elsewhere, and he teaches art classes and runs painting retreats.

Éigse Terenure is a local community group interested in promoting arts and culture events in the area.

title: Laneway Gallery – Songs From A Lost Paradise Exhibition, Talk & Tour
description:
The Centre for Creative Practices presents Songs from a Lost Paradise , a collaborative exhibition by Pakistani-born artist Amna Walayat and Irish artist Tina Whelan.
The exhibition is an artistic journey that bridges diverse cultural narratives on womanhood.

The body of work that is Songs from a Lost Paradise weaves stories of past glories and celebrations with themes of cultural hybridity, feminism, and shame.

Works feature traditional Indo-Persian miniature paintings and intricate installations, as well as womb artworks inspired by ancient and crafted symbology.

This collaboration, originating from different geographical, religious, and cultural backgrounds, celebrates their differences and togetherness, suggesting a new way of understanding and managing life and the body,
focusing on the womb as a symbolic space where different cultural and personal experiences can coexist and be shared.

On Culture Night Amna and Tina will be giving an artist talk and tour to explain the works and the methods and processes involved, combined with an interactive workshop demonstrating some of the techniques used in the work.

For booking, email the link below.
fullAddress: 120A Shandon Street, Gurranabraher, Cork, T23 NA46, Ireland

title: Late Night Opening at Waterford Gallery of Art
description:
Late night opening and free access to our current exhibition, 'Muscles and Mind: Irish Art Olympians'.

From 1912-1948, art was a competitive element of the Olympic Games with three Irish Art Olympians winning medals for Ireland (Jack B Yeats, Letitia Marion Hamilton, and Oliver St John Gogarty). Ireland entered the Olympics in 1924 a year and half after the Free State had been declared. Jack B Yeats’ Silver medal for ‘The Liffey Swim’ (1923) painting, and Oliver St John Gogarty’s Bronze for his ‘Ode to the Tailteann Games’ were the first Olympic Medals won for Ireland as a free nation.

But what does it mean to compete as an artist? What does it mean to represent your nation alongside, and against, others? Who decides the difference between gold, silver and bronze levels of creativity – and does it matter?

Artists included are Jack B. Yeats, Letitia Hamilton, Seán Keating, Mainie Jellett, Fr. Jack P. Hanlon, Desmond Broe, Flora Vere O’Brien, Ina Boyle, Stella Steyn, Hilda Roberts, Sir John Lavery, Sir William Orpen and more.

As part of the Creative Ireland funded ‘Muscles & Mind: Open-Call’, the gallery is also to present a group exhibition exploring themes of nationality, representation, and art as competition, by contemporary artists living and working in Ireland including Catherine Barron, James Horan, Ramon Kassam, Alison Lowry, Séamus O’Brien, Noel O’Donoghue, Laurence O’Toole, Csilla Toldy, Duc Van Pham, Síle Walsh and Lee Welch.

Lastly, the WGOA SETU Graduate Award Commission, will officially launch the newly commissioned portrait of Olympic silver medal winner John Treacy, by recent SETU Waterford Visual Arts Graduate, Sammy Kane.
fullAddress: Waterford Gallery of Art, 31-32 O'Connell Street, Trinity Without, Waterford, Ireland

title: Lavit Gallery – Civilisation Blooming Exhibition & Tours
description: Cork-based artists Deirdre Frost and Seiko Hayase collaborate in producing a cross-cultural exhibition Civilisation Blooming / 文明開花, a project that sees the two artists venture into new media and establish a synergistic practice. 文明開花 means 'civilisation' in Japanese, and is written using characters that mean 'blooming culture'. 'Bloom' can be considered a positive, when something has flowered, is in it's prime or at it's peak. However an algal bloom for example can be considered a negative event, a sign of ecological imbalance. Looking at the idea of peak humanity in this Anthropocene age, with the potential collapse of multiple organisational systems looming globally, the artists consider the idea of civilisation blooming. Featuring painting, woodblock prints, sculpture, ceramics and stop-frame animation. Opening hours on Culture Night 16.00-20.00. Exhibition tours 18.00 & 19.00. No booking required.

title: Leisure Seekers: Exhibition Opening
description:
Join us for the opening of Leisure Seekers, a new exhibition from Harold Offeh. Leisure Seekers is a multi-media installation emerging from Harold Offeh’s research visits to Bray where he has explored the town’s history as a holiday destination.

Working with local stories, fables, communities, families and sea swimmers, Offeh explores aspects of this rich history of Bray as a place for fun and leisure through the ages.

Offeh has embraced his role as a stranger and visitor, delving into Bray's history and politics of leisure - the title of the installation speaks to the promise of pleasure and desire for fun offered by the traditional ‘fine day out’. Through narratives and historical references, the work speaks to the complexity of who has access to leisure, and why.

For more details please visit the Mermaid Arts Centre website: https://www.mermaidartscentre.ie

No booking is required for this exhibition.

title: Leitrim Sculpture Centre Culture Night
description:
On Culture Night 2024, Leitrim Sculpture Centre will bring together exhibitions, technical demo’s, open studios; the Chluinin co-op shop and local food in an evening that celebrates some of the diverse art forms practised across the County and the North West. Exhibition: Artist in Residence Katheryn Maguire will present To the Mountain in the gallery on New Line from 5 – 9pm. To the Mountain is Maguire's first solo show, which explores how the mapping of Mountains was developed in Ireland to ascertain the 'underground potential' of geological material value and to facilitate taxation. The mapping was done by triangulation and by creating a series of primary triangles. Sightings were taken between stations using theodolites.

This, and the artist's question, 'Do Mountains commune with us?' has inspired the fabrication of the exhibition including text, sculpture, video and installation works which continues until Saturday, Sept. 21st 4 pm. Technical demonstrations with public participation include Stone motifs & letter-cutting by Dominic Keogh of memento-mori; Ceramic form and glaze work by Herbie McCann; Metal casting by Kate Oram; Printmaking by Liz Byrne & Phoebe Dick and a variety of woodworking techniques for musical instruments and furniture by David Spence. Open studios include Caoimhe Guckian; Baibre Kennedy, John Byrne and international artist-in-residence Jude Griebel from the USA (all of the above at LSC factory New Line between 6pm – 8pm when local food and refreshments will be served). In addition, the Cluainín Community Co-operative Shop on Main Street will highlight the work of over 50 practitioners in the North West from 5-9pm, all work is for sale and at the factory on New Line between 6 – 8pm

No booking required and all welcome.
fullAddress: Manorhamilton, County Leitrim, F91 EAW7, Ireland

title: Let’s Draw
description:
In collaboration with the French Embassy in Ireland, Galway City Council presents “Let's Draw” by Maxime Touroute and Rémy Dupanloup. Lets Draw is funded by the Department of Tourism, Culture, Arts, Gaeltacht, Sport and Media, and is part of the ongoing development and enhancement of Galway City's thriving Night-Time Economy.

Let's Draw will transform Galway's iconic Spanish Arch into an interactive canvas where the public becomes the artist. Taking place from 9PM pm to midnight participants of all ages are invited to use their smartphones as drawing tools. Creations will be projected in real-time onto the Comerford House building, forming a tapestry of light and colour that evolves with each stroke.

Renowned French artist and technologist Maxime Touroute has developed the cutting-edge technology that powers this interactive experience. His intuitive web-based interface allows anyone, regardless of artistic ability, to contribute to the collective artwork. Special guest artists from the Galway Cartoon Festival will participate alongside the public, offering guidance and inspiration. Themed drawing prompts will encourage collaboration and ignite a shared sense of creativity.

Let’s Draw is open to everyone, regardless of artistic experience.

A limited number of drawing devices will be available for those without smartphones.
