title: Letters Home
description:
Internationally acclaimed duo, Christine Tobin singer-songwriter and Phil Robson guitarist present a film and music event called ‘Letters Home’. The documentary film celebrates those who emigrated to find work in the U.K. and farther afield during the second half of the 20th century. Hear the stories of six people from the Boyle, Frenchpark and Ballaghaderreen area, recorded in their own voices, interwoven with live music, song and a visual backdrop of images & photographs that recount their experiences, stretching from the 1960’s to the 1990’s. The subjects interviewed include legendary and much loved Boyle veteran Christy Wynne. Christine and Phil created the film based on their accounts of life then, both at home in Ireland and in the countries they travelled to in search of work. The title Letters Home is an acknowledgement of the important contribution emigrants made to the Irish economy by sending money back home to their families during this period.
Christine Tobin grew up in Dublin and later became an integral part of the London contemporary music scene for many years, then moved to NYC in 2015 where she became part of the city’s creative music world before returning to Ireland in 2020. Awards include a BASCA British Composer Award, an Edinburgh Festival Herald Angel Award, a BBC Jazz Award & a UK Parliamentary Jazz Award.
Phil Robson is a UK born, multi-award winning jazz guitarist/composer who has played with many legends of that music internationally as well as
fullAddress: King House Interpretive Galleries & Museum, Military Road, Knocknashee, Boyle, County Roscommon, Ireland

title: Life Drawing at WGOA with Catherine Barron
description:
Free drop-in life drawing workshop with artist Catherine Barron.

All materials provided and suitable for all ages and abilities.

Born in Carlow, Catherine Barron is a visual artist, writer, arts facilitator and creativity researcher. She has won multiple awards for her work, including the 2023 ESB Keating award and silver medal for outstanding work of art at the RHA annual exhibition, the Adams and De Veres awards at the RHA annual exhibition 2014, and the inaugural Amelia Earhart prize for an Irish female artist (Derry, 2022).

Barron was shortlisted for the Hennessy portrait prize (now Zurich prize) at the National Gallery of Ireland in 2015. Her work is represented in many public and private collections including the National Portrait Collection (University of Limerick), the EPA, the OPW, Fingal County Council, Bank of Ireland, the Department of Education, Carlow Institute of Technology and the Haverty Trust.

Catherine Barron is represented by the Molesworth Gallery, Dublin.

title: Light Bank
description:
County Longford Arts Service and NTE Longford present a large-scale outdoor digital projection art event transforming the former Ulster Bank building in the centre of Longford town.

The project aims to transform the former Ulster Bank building into a canvas of light, illumination and community spirit. This event, titled “Light Bank" is a digital mapping project that seeks to blend the rich culture of Longford’s commercial past with contemporary digital art, creating a mesmerising visual spectacle that celebrates the place of Longford as a vibrant town. The project will feature a sequence of animations and visual narratives projected onto the facade of the bank, telling a different story about the town's culture, its people and place. Projection venue will be hosted by Longford Arms Hotel.

Working in collaboration with mentor artist Caroline Conway, artists Nathan Sheridan, Mary Fleming, Raymond Asiemo and Patrina Prunty have developed site specific digital artworks that will be projected onto the former Ulster Bank building on Main Street.
This event was funded though the Culture Night Late / Night Time Economy Initiative of The Department of Tourism, Culture, Arts, Gaeltacht, Sport and Media.

Gabriela Avram of Friends of Lace, Limerick will introduce the history and heritage of Limerick Lacemaking. Limerick lace is the most famous of all Irish laces. Limerick lace is a hybrid lace made with a needle on a machine-made net base.

title: Lithuanian Traditions & Innovations
description: For Culture Night 2024, the Embassy of the Republic of Lithuania to Ireland is welcoming the public to a historical, Lithuanian straw garden making workshop with an esteemed master from Lithuania. The cherished Lithuanian tradition of straw garden making, deeply embedded within this country’s history, was inscribed on UNESCO’s list of the Intangible Cultural Heritage of Humanity last year. Unique straw garden motifs became a symbol of this year’s Lithuanian Song Celebration, which marks the hundred-year anniversary of the tradition. This Lithuanian cultural heritage will be presented alongside modern technologies, with visitors having the opportunity to get acquainted with Lithuania via a VR headset on the night.

description:

Artist Claire Guinan will be collaborating with indie duo Pressurised Container for a live art demo and music set.

This event will place in Dead Centre Brewery, Athlone on Friday the 20th September from 7-9pm.

Free entry. All welcome.

title: Live Art Demonstration and Exhibition
description:
For Culture Night Dublin 2024, the Windmill Quarter Townhall is hosting an exhibition from Dublin Painting & Sketching Club as well as a series of engaging activities including live art demonstrations by the club’s prominent members, offering a rare glimpse into professional artmaking.

A classical guitar performance will also create a serene and reflective ambiance, enhancing the artistic atmosphere.

The event is not just a showcase of talent but also a community gathering, encouraging dialogue among artists and visitors. Refreshments will be available to purchase and art enthusiasts can also purchase original artworks, supporting local artists.

This Culture Night promises an unforgettable blend of visual and auditory arts, celebrating creativity and community spirit.

title: Live Art Making in the Square
description:
Artists Anna and Phil Atkinson bring to Longford a street art spectacle, paying homage to a tale from Irish mythology. The art will be rendered on a large wooden canvas over the afternoon and evening. Pop by and say hello.
This event was funded though the Culture Night Late / Night Time Economy Initiative of The Department of Tourism, Culture, Arts, Gaeltacht, Sport and Media.

title: Live Broadcast with GOCOM Radio
description:
Our dedicated team of reporters will be stationed across various key locations in Galway, bringing you the latest news, live interviews, and on-the-ground coverage of cultural festivals, music concerts, theater performances, and local gatherings.

We'll capture the pulse of Galway's Culture Night life, highlighting the diverse range of activities and entertainment available. We need play cultural music, bring updates and insights into community events.

Listeners can expect engaging commentary, exclusive interviews with event organisers and performers, and timely information on any changes or highlights as they happen. With our team spread out across the city, we'll provide a comprehensive view of Galway's dynamic evening scene, ensuring that our audience stays informed and connected to all the excitement.

For those who are out and about or listening from the comfort of their homes, GOCOM RADIO will bring the city's events straight to listeners, making sure they are part of the action.
fullAddress: Westside Enterprise Park, Bóthar le Cheile, Westside, Galway, Ireland

title: Live In The Garden 2024
description: Join us for a vibrant Culture Night celebration in the heart of our community garden, where diversity and creativity bloom under the stars. This unique event brings together an eclectic mix of music, art, poetry, and dance, showcasing talents from various cultures and backgrounds. Wander through art installations nestled among lush greenery, and be moved by live poetry readings that echo the spirit of unity and understanding. Enjoy performances ranging from traditional dances to contemporary musical acts, each representing the rich tapestry of our community. In addition to celebrating the arts, the event highlights our commitment to environmental sustainability—learn about local biodiversity, recycling initiatives, and our Tidy Towns efforts. This evening promises not only entertainment but also education and inspiration, fostering a deeper connection between community members and the environment.
host: Speak Up Sing Out Music School
fullAddress: Kilcock Community Garden, Courtown Road, Commons West, Courtown Bridge, County Kildare, Ireland

title: Live Music, Workshops, Talks and Tours at Hugh Lane Gallery
description: Visit the Hugh Lane on Culture Night for brilliant line of art workshops, pop-up talks, expert guided tours plus an exciting lineup of musicians and spoken word artist performing throughout the evening including Rattling Ark Méabh McKenna, Everything Shook, Ordnance Survey, Ellie O’Neill / Sharon Phelan / Matthew Nolan, Daniel Luke, and Chiamaka Enyi-Amadi. Come and see displays and exhibitions including Time and Time Again curated by Young Visionaries, and High Expectations Early Years, an interactive display for very young children, and Sarah Purser: A Force for Irish Art.

title: Living History at Enniscorthy Castle
description:
Enniscorthy Castle will bring history to life for your entire family - meet Norman knights and Irish kings, merchants, designers, and a 1916 soldier - who tell you about their lives and times in Enniscorthy. From the moment you step in the door of the Castle, someone new will greet you as you explore.
This is an interactive, take at your own pace, wander through the castle event! Drop in between 4-8pm, free, all ages, children must be accompanied by an adult, no pre-booking required.
See https://www.facebook.com/enniscorthycastle/ for updates!

title: Living History with Maura Logue
description:
‘On the Gallivant’, with Nora Gallagher.

Maura Logue’s popular 1950’s country girl creation, Nora Gallagher, is on the ‘Gallivant’ to the big Market Town of Letterkenny. It’s a big outing for the stay-at-home girl. She will be dropping into Donegal County Museum for a ‘sup of Tae, with 2 sugars’. She, no doubt, will be blathering about the time Public Transport came to Drumshee in the late 1950’s. As transport was ‘as scarce as hen’s teeth’, Nora didn’t do much gallivanting then - but that all changed when Fr. Maloney got Hugh John to launch The Bingo Bus!

‘On the Gallivant’, with Nora Gallagher.

Maura Logue’s popular 1950’s country girl creation, Nora Gallagher, is on the ‘Gallivant’ to the big Market Town of Letterkenny. It’s a big outing for the stay-at-home girl. She will be dropping into Donegal County Museum for a ‘sup of Tae, with 2 sugars’. She, no doubt, will be blathering about the time Public Transport came to Drumshee in the late 1950’s. As transport was ‘as scarce as hen’s teeth’, Nora didn’t do much gallivanting then - but that all changed when Fr. Maloney got Hugh John to launch The Bingo Bus!

Call into the Museum at 7.45pm to hear Nora Gallagher’s comedic nostalgic yarns of hopping on ‘The Bingo Bus’ (1959) and moving into a bigger world of the 1960’s. Then at 8.45pm hear all about the ‘The Big Day Out To Knock’ (1960).

Nora Gallagher is written and performed by Maura Logue, Dark Daughter Productions and Costume Hire.

Nora Gallagher is written and performed by Maura Logue, Dark Daughter Productions and Costume Hire.

title: LIVVS X DOCnet Showcase
description: A showcase of the multicultural music landscape of Ireland. This event celebrates DEIB (Diversity, Equity, Inclusion, and Belonging). The event aims to promote multiculturalism and community engagement through a combination of visual, performing art, music and spoken word.

title: Local Lore and Legend: An Evening of Tall Tales from Tipperary
description:
Tall tales and local lore once shared around the fire, before Tiktoc and TV, to amuse, scare, educate and entertain, reimagined by the creative team at Clonmel Theatre Guild, and now dramatically retold on the streets of Clonmel.

These stories which many local people heard from the elders of their childhood were collected and crafted by the Guild for a night’s entertainment.

Weather permitting, they will be retold outdoors as part of a walking tour. Join for one story and walk up the street for another.

Starting point: Mick Delahunty Square, Clonmel. E91Y891

**CROWD PHOTOGRAPHY / DIGITAL RECORDING RELEASE NOTICE**
Please be aware that by entering this area, your photograph and/or digital recording will be used, without compensation, for the use in all media and you release Tipperary County Council and The Arts Council from liability whatsoever of any nature.
If you have any questions about data protection please contact: artsoffice@tipperarycoco.ie
fullAddress: Mick Delahunty Square, Burgagery-Lands West, Clonmel, County Tipperary, Ireland

title: Local Storytelling with Balor Otherworld
description:
Join Balor Otherword for an enchanting event of local storytelling that will captivate people of all ages with tales of heritage, folklore, and history.
Dressed as a druid, Balor Otherword brings to life interconnected stories of local folklore and superstitions including Shannon Town, Biddy Early the Herbalist , Honest Tom Steele , Banshees, Pucas and many more.
After the storytelling, Balor Otherworld will dive into other stories based on audience requests.

His engaging storytelling style will captivate audiences of all ages and transport you to a world of myth and legend.
fullAddress: Tullyvarraga, Shannon, Co. Clare, V14 AK74, Ireland

title: Locanda: Live Concert
description:
The Instituto Cervantes Dublin, the Spanish cultural and language centre in Ireland, presents a vibrant programme open to all audiences and ages to enjoy Spanish culture in Ireland.

Visitors on Culture Night are invited to a live concert from Locanda who fuses rumba with Latin jazz and flamenco, and optimistic, socially-themed lyrics along with catchy melodies. With an equal mix of Mediterranean Turkish and Spanish musical influences, Locanda's project revolves around the original compositions of Pilar Paradela. The current lineup consists of Spanish guitar (Juan Francisco Ros), bass (Tamer Cavusoglu), tenor saxophone (Antonio Parejo), violin (Berk Talay), percussion (Zeyrek Yildiz), and vocals (Pilar Paradela).

Join in, have a dance and enjoy the good energy of the members of Locanda on Culture Night.

locations.title: Dublin City - Trinity And The Docklands

fullAddress: Instituto Cervantes, Lincoln Place, Dublin 2, Ireland

We are a community based voluntary organisation focused on the promotion of the art of brass playing and have been a constant, vibrant presence in Wexford since 1937.

Featuring well known musicians from Wexford, the band will play a wide ranging programme of music, some Irish flavoured given the year that is in it for Wexford.

title: Looking for Brigid in Derry
description:
Looking for Brigid in Derry
Photographs & Audio by Deirdre Brennan
Sound Edit by Barry Connolly

Deirdre Brennan created a photographic and audio project about women and children named Brigid (or its iterations) to commemorate the 1500 anniversary of St. Brigid's death in 2024. The purpose of this project was to celebrate women and children through the lens of Brigid, the goddess or saint.

Derry was a significant location for the project. Over the course of a few days, Deirdre took pictures of 32 women and children at The Playhouse.

Portraits of women and children ranging in age from 8 weeks to 108 will be displayed. Women who made significant contribution to the city will tell incredible histories.

Deirdre Brennan Photography https://deirdrebrennan.com/

title: Lou McMahon Ensemble + Butterfly Wars
description:
Butterfly Wars is a lush, and beautiful video game concept album and live show by composer Lou McMahon. It features contemporary classical string quartet instrumentals fused with singer-songwriter melodies on piano and guitar, creating a gothic atmosphere that underscores the gaming concept. Butterfly Wars follows the story of goth AI X, who grapples with the question: am I the seed of AI or the embodiment of the human spirit?

This is chapter one, set on the planet Mysteria, a dark and wild place way, way off above the clouds. The concept work will be performed by Lou McMahon with an ensemble of string musicians in the Glor foyer. This is a stripped-back version of the live show which sometimes features a contemporary dancer. It is a work of haunting abstraction.

"A Magnificent Song [Mysteria]" — RTVS (Radio and Television of Slovakia)
fullAddress: glór, Causeway Link, Clonroad Beg, Ennis, County Clare, Ireland

title: Louise Peat Open Studios
description:
Artist Louise Peat welcomes visitors to her studio on Culture Night to allow the public an exclusive peek into what is usually the artist’s own private workspace in the Basement Studio at 5 Henrietta Street.

The open studio event will offer an insight into the place and the unique ways in which the artist works. This Culture Night Dublin event is an excellent opportunity to talk first-hand to the artist and to view her work in the special environment in which it was created.

The studio, located on Henrietta Street - Dublin's earliest Georgian street dating back to the mid-1720s - has been a vibrant hub for artists since around 1975. Unfortunately, as of July 2025, the studios will cease and no longer host artists. This marks the end of a remarkable era of creativity on this historic street.

description:
Love Cats! is a vibrant celebration of feline-inspired art. On Culture Night, local artists will showcase their unique interpretations of our favourite furry friends, with the only prompt being "Cats". Expect a diverse array of art, from paintings and sculptures to digital designs, all on display at The Cottage Bar. Artists taking part include Kim Sharkey, Sarah Lewtas, Redmond Herrity, Seamus Quinn, Claire McLaughlin and Valerie Wurmli.

As you explore the exhibition, enjoy live music from High Tailed Catnip (aka. High Heeled Converse), setting the perfect mood for an evening of art, music, and cat appreciation. Don't miss this purr-fect blend of local talent and feline fun.

title: Love is a Place
description:
Join us to celebrate the launch of Holy Show arts magazine featuring a new poem, essay and photographs of Bray’s seafront. Poet Jane Clarke and photographer David Stephen capture the sights and sounds of the promenade, with a particular focus on the people who use it (and the things you hear them say in passing!) Jane will read her new poem and talk about her Springtime ‘residency’. A special commission from Holy Show in partnership with the Mermaid Arts Centre.

Refreshments served and a pre-event swim near the bandstand weather permitting.

Holy Show is a printed summer annual of contemporary life and culture as seen through the eyes of Ireland’s artists.
fullAddress: Bray Bandstand, Bray, County Wicklow, Ireland

title: Love Language, Love Tuam
description:
Tuam Library celebrates the town's unique dialect and languages on Culture Night. The event is a meeting of language and art, with a collaboration between Bru Bhríde and artist Kathy Ross. Tuam has its own colloquial dialect, including phrases like “how are ya sham” and “gates wide.” The dialect is deeply rooted in the Cant Traveller language.

On Culture Night, we will celebrate Tuam's language and identity by designing and crafting upon material tote bags and making Beady Pockets. Participants will learn about Tuam slang and Traveller culture whilst trying the embroidery techniques used in Beady Pockets.

Kathy Ross will lead a print making and fabric painting table, where they can use a printing press to apply phrases from Tuam slang, Cant, the Irish language or their own dialect.
fullAddress: Tuam Library, High Street, Corralea West, Tuam, County Galway, H54 F627, Ireland

title: Lumina
description:
As part of this year’s Culture Night Late, Galway County Council will proudly present Lumina, a series of artistic outdoor projections on The Cathedral Church of the Assumption of the Blessed Virgin Mary, known as Tuam Cathedral. Lumina will take place on the evening of Friday, 20 September 2024 from 9:30pm.

“Join Galway County Council, Culture Works and Creative Places Tuam for this flagship event as we celebrate the town’s cultural vibrance with the community of Tuam. In the true spirit of Culture Night everyone is welcome!” says Cllr. Albert Dolan, Cathaoirleach Galway County Council.

This breathtaking nighttime spectacle will captivate audiences as the facade of the Tuam Cathedral is transformed into a canvas of light and sound through projections and live choral performances.

“Culture Night and Lumina showcase the artistic and cultural offering of Tuam and north Galway which is to be admired and enjoyed”, says Liam Conneally, Chief Executive Galway County Council.

Audiences will witness the work of four local, national and international artists that have all taken part in Cybernate, a digital arts residency that supports artists to develop their artistic practice.

“Lumina is the unmissable event of our Culture Night programme this year. We’re delighted that work by Tuam artist Jennifer Cunningham will be projected in her local town at a huge scale for all to see”, says Sharon O’Grady, Galway County Arts Officer.

Jennifer Cunningham (Tuam), Scott Robinson (Limerick) and ENTER.black founders Bonnie Lisbon and Harry Clunet-Farlow (Paris) are creating a stunning showcase of animations and visual narratives that will mesmerise audiences. The work will be accompanied by a unique music composition from ENTER.black, paired with the enchanting voices of Tuam Cathedral Choir and The Tome Chanters. This unique blend of art and technology promises to captivate and inspire, offering a one-of-a-kind experience that celebrates creativity and innovation in Tuam and Galway County.

Before attending Lumina, explore a variety of exciting Culture Night events in Tuam: Here We Are Now! by Sparkcatchers, Open Mic at Brú Bhríde, FUSE Trad with FUSE Music, Open Studio with Karena Ryan, Love Language, Love Tuam with Kathy Ross at Tuam Library, Irish Myths and Legends with Patricia King-Callaghan and Cyanotype Workshop with Jennifer Cunningham at Tuam Town Hall.

Exact times for Lumina will be announced closer to the event. Follow Galway County Culture night social media channels for updates.

Galway County Council Arts Office presents Lumina, a Culture Night Late event with artists Jennifer Cunningham, Scott Robinson and ENTER.black. Funded by the Arts Council, Department of Tourism, Culture, Arts, Gaeltacht, Sport and Media and Galway County Council. Supported by Creative Places Tuam. Produced by Culture Works.
venueName: The Cathedral Church of the Assumption of the Blessed Virgin Mary (Tuam Cathedral)

title: MAGICAL PERFORMANCE OF TULLOW’S MYTHS
description: Ireland’s finest performers of mythological tales will be putting on an extraordinary show revealing folklore and myths from Tullow’s past through music, movement, and beautifully executed stories. This exceptional show should not be missed.

title: Make a Charm – Create Your Own Porcelain Pendants
description:
Come join Aoife Natsumi Frehan and Emma O'Toole at The Forge Clay Studio for a fun and creative event where you can make your very own porcelain pendants! Let your imagination be guided by the flora and the fauna found in your surroundings. Our experienced instructors will guide you through the process, making sure you leave with a one-of-a-kind piece to cherish.
Bring your own plants (or anything else!) that you want to use to leave an impression on clay. We will be using a shape cutter to neatly shape the pendants. You will then be able to colour these using Englobes, if you wish!

The charms you have made will be fired, glazed with a see-through glaze and returned to you once the workshop is done by Aoife Natsumi. Your Porcelain Pendants will be ready for pick-up on the first weekend of October! Once you have it back, you can pick whatever chain or cord you like to turn it into a necklace.
Don't miss out on this opportunity to get crafty and unleash your inner artist! We have a limited capacity so don't be slow in making a booking!
(We won't be providing alcohol, but if you like you can bring your own little drink to get the creative juices flowing!)

Eventbrite link coming soon.

*If you find this event to be full, please give ForgeClay@gmail.com an email to be put on the waiting list in case of cancellation. Thank you!
fullAddress: 42 New Road, Galway, Ireland

title: Make an Irish Woodland Lantern
description:
Make an Irish Woodland lantern in clay using hand building techniques. Imprint the patterns of leaves freshly picked in Anitas garden into the clay. Press the name of your tree in Irish onto your lantern using Gaelic printers type once used by the artists father in his printing business. Cut out leaf shapes to finish your candle holder. All pieces will be fired and glazed by Anita afterwards.

Please note is event is SOLD OUT.
fullAddress: Shanco, County Meath, C15 HRN8, Ireland

title: Make at Muckross: Culture Night ‘Storyshop’ Workshops for Children
description:
Join Me and The Moon this Culture Night at Muckross!

Workshop start time is 3pm.

Using drawing tools, each child will develop their own story character, which when finished will be added to a large group mural. Over the course of Culture Night, a story begins to emerge as our mural develops.

Children will be led by demonstration and will have lots of fun in the making. Timetabled workshops will take place at Muckross Garden Restaurant. Suitable for primary school children of all ages (5-12 years). Parent and child workshop (no drop-offs) and adults are encouraged to join in the fun.
fullAddress: Muckross House, Muckross, Killarney, County Kerry, Ireland

title: Makeup X ART Workshop with James Mac
description:
Makeup and Artistry workshop from JMAC, renowned makeup artist and Netflix/BBC finalist from GLOW UP series 2.

James returns to Laois to host a creative workshop demoing the unconventional methods to connect to art through makeup design. The event will be hosted in the Dunamase Gallery, and will inspire an evening of creativity. The workshop promises to offer a unique and insightful new form of artistic expression.
fullAddress: Dunamaise Arts Centre, Church Street, Maryborough, Portlaoise, County Laois, Ireland

title: Maltese Language
description:
Maltese is the only Semitic national language in Europe. Its rich and diverse literature is manifested in the thriving publishing industry in Malta. With roots from the Middle East going back millennia, exposure to Romance and other Indo-European languages has left its influences. Come along on Culture Night for these special classes in the Maltese language that will give participants an opportunity to explore its roots, basic structure and some vocabulary. No previous knowledge of the language is necessary. The activity is accessible to people of all ages.

This event is part of the European Culture Trail – a EUNIC Ireland (European Union National Institutes for Culture) initiative in cooperation with the European Commission Representation in Ireland. Immerse yourself in the diversity of European languages and cultures on the European Culture Trail, where delights from different European countries await you.

For those visiting European Culture Trail events in person, you are invited to download the “European Culture Trail Treasure Hunt” passport here - https://rb.gy/4cbske - and collect stamps or signatures at each stop. The passports with the most stamps at the end of the night will be entered into a raffle for the chance to win some wonderful prizes.
fullAddress: European Commission Representation in Ireland, Mount Street Lower, Dublin 2, Ireland

An outdoor Cinema extravaganza featuring Mamma Mia 2 The Movie in the beautiful setting of Mallow Castle. There will be live Abba music for 80 minutes before the movie to get everyone in the mood before it gets dark & the movie begins. There will be plenty of food/refreshments available for purchase inside the castle grounds. Wrap up warm, bring your blankets, camping chairs for your own comfort.

title: Mandala Making Workshop
description:
A mandala is a geometric design, meaning ‘circle’, which symbolises the Buddhist universe and is used as an aid to meditation. Working with mandalas can be a creative way to come into harmony with oneself, with others and with the environment.

Join the Dublin Buddhist Centre in exploring this ancient Buddhist art form as they co-create a mandala using materials gathered from nature and, when it is complete, release it back into nature. Bring along any natural found objects such as flowers, leaves, leaves, pebbles, shells, feathers etc. that you would like to incorporate into the mandala.

Spaces are limited and offered on a first come first served basis.

locations.title: Dublin City - Monto And North Georgian Quarter

fullAddress: Dublin Buddhist Centre, James Joyce Street, Mountjoy, Dublin, Ireland

title: Mantra Chanting Workshop
description: In the Buddhist tradition, mantras are words or phrases that are chanted as objects of meditation and expressions of devotion. Sacred sound symbols, they invoke qualities of the enlightened mind and bring us in touch with our highest potential. Join the Dublin Buddhist Centre Mantra Circle as they explore how the practice of mantra can help to calm the mind and open the heart.

locations.title: Dublin City - Monto And North Georgian Quarter

title: Marina Market Cork – Everybody Dance with Stevie G.

title: MARYANN
description:
MARYANN is a vocalist, multi-instrumentalist, and songwriter from Carlow, Ireland. An artist who uses her voice to express her love of storytelling, she has spent time performing in both Ireland and Lanzarote; blending powerful vocals with thoughtful lyricism.

Blending the bold story-telling of her musical theatre background with pop and folk influences like Maisie Peters and Nina Nesbitt, her writing is like a compilation of musical diary entries, from someone who is hyper aware of her own coming-of-age. Her debut EP is out in September 2024.
fullAddress: The Railway House, Moneybeg, Muine Bheag, County Carlow, Ireland

title: Mater Misericordiae University Hospital Culture Night
description:
The Mater Misericordiae University Hospital is delighted to open its doors to members of the public once again for Culture Night 2024.

Visitors can enjoy the interactive family-friendly exhibits throughout the original hospital building, including in our Pillar Centre for Transformative Healthcare. View the partially restored original Chapel ceiling, take a walk through the old surgical theatres and practise your surgical skills; learn about the important work of the National Isolation Unit; enjoy the sounds of the Mater Choir in the beautiful Pillar Room; and learn about the past, present, and future of medicine, surgery, nursing and pharmacy.

Entry through the old hospital front entrance on Eccles Street.

title: Meditation Workshop – The Cultivation of Loving Kindness
description:
Together with mindfulness, Metta, meaning ‘loving-kindness’, is a core part of Buddhist meditation. By cultivating Metta we can grow out of self-centredness and emotional negativity, and into being able to have harmonious and satisfying relationships with other people, as well as with ourselves.

In this one-hour workshop, visitors to the Dublin Buddhist Centre will be introduced to the Metta Bhavana meditation practice as a way of cultivating states of emotional positivity and freedom of heart and mind.

title: Meditation Workshop – The Mindfulness of Breathing
description: Meditation is a means of transforming the mind and it can help us to better appreciate ourselves, other people, and the beauty of the world around us. Central to the practice of meditation is mindfulness. In this one-hour workshop, visitors to the Dublin Buddhist Centre will be briefly introduced to one of the fundamental Buddhist meditation practices: the mindfulness of breathing.

Charlie Gallagher is a Blacksmith, the only sword maker in Ireland, a Celtic martial artist, wordsmith, folklorist, historian, wood carver and stone mason. There is no better place to discover our rich cultural heritage and experience history come alive this Culture Night than the Donegal County Museum!

title: Meeting House Square: BPM Collective
description:
BPM Energy Ltd. (a.k.a. “B*tches Play Music”) is a Dublin-based collective programming experimental electronic experiences that centre underrepresented artists in Ireland and the diaspora.

From its inception as a project exploring the limits of transgressive sound in a safe, welcoming club environment, BPM Energy Ltd. has expanded to encompass a diverse range of events based around community engagement and a spirit of playfulness. From noise concerts to social ambient lounges, sit-down trad fusion gigs, drone concerts, and boisterous club nights, BPM Energy Ltd. is an ever-evolving sandbox for exploring new sounds, spaces and modes of sonic-centred community. They are united by a desire to create unifying and expansive moments in a scene overwhelmed with commerciality and social hegemony.

Line up:
Pixieteeth b2b polyp
DJ Egg
DJ Clench

title: Meeting House Square: Culchie Goth
description:
Culchie Goth, hailing from the bogs of Offaly, has breathed new life into the traditional art of fiddle playing. With a name that reflects their rural roots and urban influences, they delve deep into traditional Irish sounds and re-mould them to fit a queer, contemporary audience. Their repertoire of rousing reels, polkas and jigs mixed with familiar dance beats have filled dance floors across the queer nightlife scene in Ireland.

Join them on a transformative journey where ancient melodies intertwine with pulsating beats. Enjoy the essence of traditional Irish music with a techno twist!

This event is part of an expansive programme at Meeting House Square for Culture Night Dublin. Filming and photography will be taking place at this location. By attending we assume permission unless a member of our team is explicitly notified.

title: Meeting House Square: JyellowL
description:
JyellowL will be bringing something for every mood to the stage at Meeting House Square. Giving a high energy performance with impactful lyricism, his dynamic songs are both personal and urgent, and are sure to both make you move and touch your heart. Make sure to catch JyellowL’s set on Culture Night for an inspiring, explosive fusion of genres.

JYellowL is a RTÉ Choice Music Prize nominated artist who has been consistently paving the way in Irish hip hop over the past number of years. The achievements speak for themselves, from supporting artists like Burna Boy, De La Soul, Nelly and The Game, to placements among the likes of the official FIFA soundtrack, Normal People and 1.2 million streams on Spotify alone in 2023 - all as an independent artist. His Irish, Jamaican and Nigerian roots have shaped his powerful, distinct sound and the Dublin-London based rapper is known for his effortless flow and music rooted in rap but fused with afrobeat, dancehall, RnB and soul.

title: Meeting House Square: Mariachi San Patricio
description:
Mariachi San Patricio has been proudly celebrating the great tradition of Mexican mariachi music in Ireland for over a decade.

Established in 2011, the band is christened San Patricio after the brave St. Patrick's Battalion, an Irish regiment who fought and died for Mexico in the Mexican-American War of 1846-48. The name is a nod toward a beautiful affinity of Mexican and Irish cultures, represented by the soulful gritos of Ireland's only full mariachi.

The ensemble has travelled all over the island of Ireland sharing and honouring the beauty of mariachi music. What started as a passion project bringing the spirit of Jalisco to the heart of Dublin City has since become a moveable fiesta of music, colour and joy.

title: Meeting House Square: Queer Set Dancing
description:
Come along to a taster session of Alexa Moore's Belfast-based Queer Set Dancing class, which aims to put an LGBTQI+ spin on a traditional style of Irish dance. During the session you'll get a taste of set dancing, learn some steps, and (hopefully) meet some new people! Taught by a queer woman, Queer Set Dancing is open to everyone regardless of sexual orientation or gender identity but is specifically inclusive of LGBTQI+ people and their allies.

Alexa Moore is an Ulster woman working to advance rights and equality for LGBTQI+ people. She moved to Belfast in 2018 to run a trans human rights organisation before moving on to work on issues relating to Brexit and human rights, eventually landing at The Rainbow Project earlier this year as their Policy, Campaigns and Communications Manager. She has been running Queer Set Dancing in The MAC, Belfast, for the past 2 and a half years, having set it up to share her love of set dancing and help keep it alive across the island.

This is a 16+ event. The class has been structured for individuals of this age and above in mind.

Artwork by Fiona McDonnell.

title: Meeting House Square: Roo Honeychild Live – Dance Muscle
description:
DANCE MUSCLE is a new project from local light Roo Honeychild, founder of renowned queer party crew Club Comfort and purveyor of rapturous DJ sets. This new performance is an energetic tour through her original productions and beyond. These run the gamut of contemporary dance music, absorbing influence from around the world and remixing it anew, intent for Dublin in the 2020s. Previous performances with Baby Baby and Dublin Modular have been described as "Deadly," "Unreal," and, "A Sweat Bath."

Honeychild has been a preeminent force on Ireland's rave circuit for the last eight years, and has performed internationally, releasing music with Gash Collective, Nasty Enterprises, Dublin Digital Radio. She has featured on a number of cultural institutions: Boiler Room, NTS, Dublin Digital Radio, Red Light Radio, Rinse FM, Noods Radio, Reprezent FM, COMMON, alongside gracing the decks at a host of festivals: Alternating Current, Open Ear, Electric Picnic, All Together Now, Drop Everything, Ladyfest Maastricht, Body & Soul, and Longitude.

title: Meeting House Square: Squish Stomp Spin – The Magic of Stim
description:
This is the tale of a fairy - the silliest, most creative and colourful fairy in all of Ireland. But it isn’t a fairytale! It’s a story about stimming, a neurosparkly look at being yourself. Una is on a quest to stop King Dirch from ruining everything with his dreary demands for “normal”. Along the way, you can join Una and try out different stims to feel through some big emotions and save fairy freedom!

‘Squish Stomp Spin - The Magic of Stim’ was originally produced for Sensoria 2024. This innovative new show by Moss Russell uses circus and spectacle to destigmatise stimming and promote positive representation for neurodivergent individuals through storytelling.

title: Meithel Meán Fómhair!
description:
Welcome one, welcome all! We invite all those in our community and beyond to The Organic Centre this Culture Night for a friendly gathering where we are hosting an evening of culturally themed events based on the significance of our natural world, so please come and join us for an array of complimentary happenings, beginning with self guided wanderings throughout our gardens and tunnels whilst the light remains, followed by local singer and guitarist Mike Mclister whose music will be inspired by his surrounds and the natural world has to offer.

Fiona Wheeldon-Former NPWS ranger-will involve attendees in various crafting endeavours to the tune of the dynamic duo of Tony Cuckson & Barbara Smith who will weave stories, music and tales of the wonders of our landscape, followed by a gentle eco art session with artist Sarah Ellen Lundy to finish up proceedings. With locally made nibbles being available free to participants throughout the evening and dancing thoroughly encouraged! All ages welcome to what should be a well rounded event to feed body and soul through cultural and creative activities suitable to all abilities, and will impart the importance of the centres work in this context as a cultural hub where local and new communities are at the heart of all efforts now and to come.

Please note this is a walk-in programme between 6-9pm with food and materials available on a first come basis so come early & stay for the evening!
fullAddress: Sraud (Conolly), County Leitrim, F91 H978, Ireland

title: Mercier Press – Literature at St. Luke’s – Open House, Bookshop & Reading
description: As the oldest independent publisher in Ireland marks 80 years, Mercier is delighted to celebrate Culture Night in its brand new premises at St. Lukes Cross, Cork. Founded in 1944 by Tipperary native Seán Feehan and his wife Mary, by the 1970s Mercier had gained a reputation for being different and radical, publishing controversial Irish bestsellers. Ever since, the Cork-based press has been a formidable and prolific presence in Irish publishing, publishing Irish interest books to present the Irish people and their culture both to themselves and the wider world.The Culture Night Event at 82 St. Luke's will incorporate a pop-up bookshop of both recent and older titles, as well as readings from our current and contemporary authors alongside a reading from The Tailor and Ansty by Eric Cross, which was banned on its initial publication in 1942
fullAddress: Ballyhooly Road, Montenotte, Cork, T23 Y3V2, Ireland

title: Merrion Square Artists Light Up
description:
The artists of Merrion Square are joining in the fun of Culture Night Dublin 2024!

Merrion Square Open-Air Art Gallery has been held every Sunday on the external railings of Merrion Square, one of Dublin’s largest and grandest squares, since 1985 - almost forty years! - in the surrounds of Georgian Houses, the garden of Leinster House, as well as two National Museums.

Enjoy the spectacle as you pass, or stop for the chance to purchase original art directly from an artist, most of which are professional and full-time practitioners. There are a large variety of genres on display, from traditional to contemporary. Come to the Oscar Wilde corner of Merrion Square and have a chat with this friendly collective of talented artists.
fullAddress: Dublin, D02 NH98, Ireland

title: Michael Collins House Open Evening and Free Guided Tours
description: Tour Michael Collins House Museum to discover the life story of Michael Collins and the history of the fight. Set out in a restored Georgian townhouse on the square where Collins once lived, history is brought to life through guided tours, interactive displays, audiovisuals, original artefacts and more suitable for all the family.

title: Michael McWilliams Exhibition
description:
Visit the United Arts Club in their Gallery and Club Bar for a truly wonderful exhibition by artist Michael McWilliams.

This exhibition is part of an open house for Culture Night where United Arts Club are delighted to welcome members of the public to come and visit the United Arts Club for a variety of events throughout the night including drawing and art demonstrations, musical performances and tours of our historic building. Situated in the heart of Georgian Dublin the United Arts Club has, since its founding in 1907, been a meeting place for people with an interest in all aspects of the arts. The Club has a rich and fascinating cultural history with founding members including W.B. Yeats, Countess Markievicz, and AE Russell.

description:

Irish fiddle artist Michelle O'Brien and Dublin jazz pianist So-Young Yoon unite their distinct styles in a performance featuring Psy's global sensation ‘Gangnam Style’ alongside the stunning Irish masterpiece ‘Oíche Nollaig’ by virtuoso pianist and composer Mícheál Ó Súilleabháin, with Dave Mooney on double bass and Paul O'Connor on drums.

title: Mick O’Callaghan and Friends
description:
Mick O Callaghan will be reading excerpts from his book “The Boy who Kicked the Nun” in Murphys Restaurant Main Street, alongside some guest performers. His debut book, is a memoir chronicling his life's journey, from his early days in Tralee to his teaching career, culminating in his well-earned retirement and profound love for his North Wexford abode, giving an insight into moments of his life and observations. Mick writes a weekly blog on www.aramblersblog.com, features regularly in Comhnasc , is a writer for love Gorey.ie news and events and has written many articles for the retired teachers group.

Mick will be joined by Margaret Sherif and Seamus Kavanagh. Margaret is a local widely published writer. Margaret retired three years ago as Co-ordinator of the Gorey School Completion Programme in GCS. She has been published in Women's magazines, Irelands Own, Sunday Independent and on Sunday Miscellany. Seamus Kavanagh is author of the widely acclaimed poetry book “Reflections in Rhyme ‘published by Carol Boland of Boland Press Hollyfort. He is also a regular contributor to“Comhnasc’ the retired teachers’ national magazine with a circulation of 11000.

The band for the musical section of the night will be Jazz Token, who are based in Baltinglass, and have been playing together for six years now.  They play jazz standards and instrumentals from
the swing era to the nineteen sixties with a more modern flavour – from Cole Porter and Duke Ellington to Horace Silver and Sonny Rollins!  Listen to some famous songs and to some of the
stories behind them, or even dance to the beat of a classic jazz combo.  
Frank Gallagher – vocals & guitar
Rory Adams – vocals & piano
Máirt Hanley – bass
Christy Stapleton – drums

Our hosts for the night will be Aidan Murphy and Liz Fitzgerald . It all kicks off at 6.30 pm in Murphys Restaurant Main Street, Gorey on Friday September 20th.
fullAddress: Laurence Murphy & Son, Main Street, Gorey corporation lands, County Wexford, Ireland

title: Mini-Memoir Writing Workshop With Award-Winning Author DAVE DUGGAN
description:
CULTURE NIGHT: Mini-Memoir Writing Workshop with award-winning author DAVE DUGGAN in Little Acorns Bookstore, Derry

Ever wished you could write and record your very own or a family member's personal story but have no idea where, when or how to start? If yes, then this upbeat, exciting and creative mini-memoir Culture Night workshop is specifically for you! Led by the award-winning author DAVE DUGGAN, each participant will be invited to write a first draft of a specific memory and, by the end of the workshop, will leave with a personal piece of writing that should help stir more memories and inspire further writing.

An extra highlight will include Dave reading some excerpts from his much-anticipated collection of essays, JOURNEYWORK - A CREATIVE LIFE due release this autumn from the Nerve Centre.

DAVE DUGGAN lives in Derry. His work, in both English and Irish, includes five novels, 20 stage plays (one of which toured in Afghanistan), a dozen radio dramas (on BBC and RTÉ), a blog [see: https://breathingwithalimp.blogspot.com ] plus an Oscar-nominated short film.

No previous writing experience is necessary but a desire to write a personal or family memory is. Booking is essential to reserve one of 20 places. Pens, paper and hot drinks will be supplied.
venueName: Little Acorns Bookstore, 18 Great James Street, Derry, Derry, BT48 7DA
fullAddress: Little Acorns Bookstore, Great James Street, Londonderry, UK

title: Misleór Cherra Sessions
description:
Warm up by the Misleór ‘cherra’ (Cant word for ‘fire’), with live storytelling and music from local Traveller artists, paper flower-making and traditional crafts!

For Travellers and many other nomadic peoples the cherra is an important place for sharing and connecting; a melting pot of memory, imagination and creativity. Join us around the cherra to celebrate Traveller culture by simply listening or sharing a story, poem, song or tune of your own!

title: Monsters and Things
description:
An old-fashioned Punch and Judy-style puppet box and a beautiful mix of rod puppetry is grafted onto a modern story about 'X Factor' fame and fortune. Jacko, his hapless friend Podi, a wise old wizard and a host of small creatures from mice to snails, will enthral the audience in fifty minutes of adventure and misadventure.

Jacko, the brains and ambition of the outfit, is very put out when woolly-jumpered Podi comes down with a cold, threatening his dream of becoming rich and famous. Coming across a spellbook belonging to a mysterious wizard, Jacko, in his efforts to cure Podi, inadvertently turns him into a scary monster and a series of small creatures all of whom the children agree sing better than himself.

A clever blend of pantomimic farce, puppetry and storytelling is wonderfully pitched to engage children’s imagination and draw them into the plot. (adapted from Irish Theatre Magazine).

title: More Than Music
description:
Down Syndrome Tipperary has an active adult membership and one thing members love is music! However we are not as familiar with traditional music as with popular songs and bands.

For Culture night we are inviting a local musical combo to play popular music, but in the trad music genre – eg Abba music with an Irish twist. Our members will have familiar music, but with a cultural slant. Traditional music will also be performed and members will have the opportunity to try traditional music instruments themselves, as well as getting together and having a great night!

title: Mountshannon Community Culture Night Extravaganza
description:
Join us for a magical evening celebrating Culture Night in Mountshannon with three exciting events designed to bring our community together in harmony.

Kick off the night at 7.30pm at Aistear Park with a spectacular 'Rhythm Ramble' led by Cormac Griffith and Slavek Kwi, who have been working with local schools to create unique instruments. We'll stomp and rattle our way from the park to the Catholic church in a lantern-lit procession.

This will be followed by a concert in the Church from 8pm with local musicians and singers including the East Clare Community Choir and Lough Derg Singers, Cormac Griffith on his Glass Harp, Slow Creatures (a wonderful young local trio), and Cli Donnellan, who will perform the world premiere of her piece, 'Walk with Me', composed especially for our theme, ''Harmony''.

Conclude the evening with a special 'A Flow of Words' featuring local writers and poets who have composed pieces around our theme which will also be broadcast on Scariff Bay Radio on Saturday, September 21 and Sunday, September 22. This segment will beautifully weave together the night’s celebration of harmony through music and spoken word.
venueName: Aistear Park Mountshannon and St Caimin’s Catholic Church Mountshannon, Co Clare
fullAddress: Mountshannon, Co. Clare, Belmont Pl, Ballywilliam, Cobh, County Clare, Ireland

No matter your age or fitness level, everyone is invited to join in on the fun and dance the night away in Father Burke Park.

Kick off Culture Night in style with a silent disco fitness class like no other.

Before hitting the dance floor, attendees can even get into the festival spirit with some face painting.

Once the headsets are on, get ready to move and groove to the beat of the music for a full two hours, guided by an amazing fitness instructor.

The Healthy Ireland Fund supported by the Department of Health.

title: Movie Night @ The Courthouse
description:
Clones Film Festival will be showing Brendan Gleesons Farewell to Hughes

'To some it was an unassuming pub on a side street behind the Four Courts in Dublin City Centre. To musicians, dancers, singers and listeners, it was a mecca of traditional music for over 35 years. In 2021, Hughes’s pub closed its doors for the last time; the echoes of musical memories left buried in its walls.'

Filmed over five days in January 2022, Brendan Gleeson’s Farewell to Hughes’s records and interviews various musicians, dancers and singers as they gather one last time to revisit the magic, with archival footage inserted throughout to tell the story of Hughes’ contribution to both the traditional music community in Dublin and the city as a whole

Cert:12

Spaces are limited. Seats will be allocated on a first come, first served basis.
fullAddress: The Diamond, Crossmoyle, Clones, County Monaghan, Ireland

title: MTU – Blackrock Castle Observatory – Astronomy in Early Irish Culture: Workshops, Stargazing & Tours
description:
For Culture Night at MTU Blackrock Castle Observatory we’re celebrating archaeoastronomy.

We’ll investigate the important links between the night sky and culturally significant sites such as Newgrange, Bonane Stone Circle and more.

Visitors will get to experience a presentation on Irish Archaeoastronomy, an art workshop inspired by Newgrange, and , weather permitting, our good friends at Cork Astronomy Club will host a session of live stargazing.

Booking is not required, but tours/presentations will be offered hourly on a first-come-first served basis, so please arrive early.

COMMITTMENT. This exhibition reflects their own artistic ideals and expertise, invested in both art education and their own contribution to the vibrant, cultural visual art world they work, live in and contribute so much too - MTU Art & Culture Website (www.arts.mtu.ie)

title: MTU – Cork School of Music – Music Recitals, Drama Performances & Exhibitions
description:
Visual Art Exhibition: Foyer - Oils and charcoal by Philip Murphy, from 16:00.
A mix of figurative and landscape art, exploring music, musicians and the art they create from the perspective of another art form. The landscapes explore our impact - either great or insignificant and transitory or permanent - on land (in this case the Iveragh peninsula in Kerry), the marks we make in it through the generations. Part of the Pause series, MTU Cork School of Music is honoured to host a new visual art exhibition.

Drama Platform Showcase: Stack Theatre, 19:00 - 20:00.
Featuring recent graduates and current students of the BA in Theatre and Drama Studies degree at MTU Cork School of Music. Presenting scenes and monologues a range of theatre writers and much more.
Booking required - Details to follow.

Classical Music Recitals: Curtis Auditorium, 18:00-20:00.
Performances by Deirdre Cadogan (clarinet), Maria-Estella Fischer (piano), Tara Malone (flute) and Cillian Ó Cathasaigh (violin).

Sweet Dreams: Lullabies Around The World - 17:30 to 21:30
The Sweet Dreams: Lullabies Around the World project highlights the commonalities of local and migrant populations in Ireland.
Participants of the Women’s Programme at Nasc, the Migrant and Refugee Rights Centre, have collected their native lullabies and expressed what the lullabies mean to them through drawing, pictures, crochet, sewing etc. Some participants have recorded themselves singing their chosen lullabies, which you can listen to via the QR codes on the postcards. As part of Culture Night, this small and interactive exhibit wants YOU to participate too! Blank postcards have been provided so that anyone in Cork – of local or migrant background – can draw, write and remember the lullabies you hold most dear. By highlighting the emotions and values that we have in common, we can promote integration and inclusion for everyone in the Cork community.

title: Music Generation Clare Present Popular Trio Padraig Rynne, Tara Breen and Jim Murray
description:
Music Generation Clare present an exciting event featuring popular trio Padraig Rynne, Tara Breen and Jim Murray and showcase performances from young musicians that take part in the traditional programme.

The event promises to be a celebration of traditional Irish music with unique collaborations from the trio. Renowned concertina player and composer, Padraig Rynne is known for his innovative approach to traditional Irish music and has contributed to many acclaimed projects and collaborations. Tara Breen, a talented fiddle player is celebrated for her dynamic performances and mastery of fiddle repertoire. Jim Murray, known for his exceptional skill and ability to complement traditional music in his own style.

The event will also feature performances by emerging talent from Music Generation Clare’s traditional music programmes. These young musicians represent the future of Irish traditional music, showcasing their talents and the high standard of education and mentorship they receive through the programme.
Tickets to this event will be made available at midday on 9th September 2024.

title: Music Generation Wexford Presents
description:
Yellow Bellows, Music Generation Wexford youth singing group, will perform dynamic rock & pop songs with movement and body percussion as well as a piece as Gaeilge for Culture Night!

The group is led by musician educators Anita Mahon and Diarmuid Comerford who, with Yellow Bellows, recently led a performance of 2,000 children in Chadwicks Wexford Park, have a growing reputation for
their ‘supercool’ performances in Ireland and abroad.

Yellow Bellows have performed for the ETBI Principals conference at the Clayton Whites Hotel; the Spring Sessions, Wexford Arts Centre, supporting Frankenstein Bolts, Presentation Arts Centre; Enniscorthy, guest performers with Music Generation Waterford at the GOMA Gallery Waterford City, performed in the bandstand Wexford Culture Night 2023; and supported the Enniscorthy Gospel Choir charity performance, Riverside Hotel Enniscorthy in 2024.

They have performed both locally and internationally with Enniscorthy Street Rhythms Festival, The Music Generation National Conference in Dublin Castle, Creative Connexions, Sitges, Spain 2023 and most recently at the Fleadh Cheoil na hÉireann Wexford 2024.

title: Music History Walking Tour
description:
Join Aroundireland.ie Tours for a captivating Music History adventure! Beginning at the iconic Luke Kelly, this walking tour invites you to explore Dublin's rich history and legacy through its renowned landmarks and lesser-known treasures. As you traverse the city's streets, you'll have the opportunity to sing along to beloved tunes, uncover fascinating legends, and delve into the very heart of Dublin's musical heritage.

From its vibrant past to its thriving present, discover the musical soul that makes Dublin a truly unique and enchanting city. Whether you're a history buff, a music lover, or simply curious about Dublin's cultural tapestry, this tour promises an unforgettable journey through sound and story.
fullAddress: Luke Kelly Statue, King Street South, Dublin, Ireland

title: Music in Calary
description:
Catriona McElhinney Grimes Piano and Violin

“McElhinney Grimes played all the works with a loving attention to detail; and a range of approach that encompassed both the extreme of ferocity and the finest of filigree”.
"The piece that wooed the ear more than it tried to impress was Takemitsu’s Rain Tree Sketch, in which individual notes sometimes took on the quality of precious stones. “ The Irish Times, National Concert Hall, Solo piano recital review.

Catriona grew up in the North West of Ireland as part of a musical family, and gave her first concert performance at the age of six. She was introduced to the piano by her mother and was awarded an entrance scholarship to the Royal Irish Academy of Music at the age of ten and subsequently went on to win many major awards at Dublin Feis Ceoil, and Fleadh Cheoil as a traditional musician. Her teachers and mentors have included Brian Beckett, Antony Peebles, Alexander Ardakov, Ruth David and Korshed Gruenberg.

Catriona’s versatility as an artist is reflected in the diverse repertoire she performs. She feels equally at home playing Bach, Beethoven, passionate and expressive romantic music,contemporary pop and Irish Trad on piano, fiddle and tin whistle.
Catriona recently successfully completed her Master’s degree in Performance with Distinction at TU Dublin Conservatory of Music and Drama.
fullAddress: Calary Upper, County Wicklow, A98 H766, Ireland

title: Music Under the Mountains: Joe McHugh ‘Amongst Friends’
description:
Music Under the Mountains is delighted to open its 2024 festival with its Culture Night offering, in the beautiful surroundings of St. Kevin’s Church of Ireland, Hollywood.

After a lifetime as a musician, Joe McHugh, uilleann piper, and tin whistle player, has now released his project Joe McHugh ‘Amongst Friends’ after numerous collaborations.

Joe is indeed 'among friends' with David Aebli on bouzouki and guitar, Vanessa Loerkens on fiddle and his son Fintan on guitar, cittern, harmonica, and vocals. The album - recorded by Hollywood, County Down musician Rod McVey, known for his longtime association with the late bagpiper Liam O'Flynn - attests to the maturity and mastery of Joe's piping.

Admission is free with no prebooking required. Due to limited capacity admission is on a first come first served basis.

Please note there is no on-site parking - parking is available in the village.
There are no toilet facilities on-site, toilets in Tutty's & The Hollywood Inn are available.

title: MYO Cafe – Cormac Lally reads from ‘Soundings’
description:
Cormac Lally reads from 'Soundings'

Soundings was first published in 1969 and was the definitive introduction to poetry for all Leaving Cert students.

Within its pages are contained an eclectic mix of classical and contemporary Irish and international poetry - from Keats to Shakespeare, from Dickinson to Heaney, Chaucer, Milton and more.

Talking to Irish men and women through poetry events over the last thirty years, Soundings has always come up in conversation as an inspiration to poets and non-poets alike. So much so that when school books were being burned at the end of the school year, Soundings was always spared the flames. It touched the lives of every student that opened it.

So on Culture Night 2024, we invite you to join poet, Cormac Lally at Myo Cafe to share with us a bit about your experiences with this marvelous anthology and read your favourite poem.
fullAddress: Myo Cafe, Popes Quay, Shandon, Cork, Ireland

title: NASC’24
description: Nasc'24 is an extraordinary musical event taking place at the Garage Theatre in Monaghan. This project brings together young musicians from the northeast border region under the expert guidance of the incredibly talented singer/songwriter and multi-instrumentalist Lisa Canny. Collaborating with musician educators from Music Generations Cavan/Monaghan, Louth, and Meath, and in partnership with the Oriel Centre, Dundalk Gaol, the Comhaltas Ceoltóirí Éireann resource centre for the region, Nasc'24 promises a unique musical experience.
fullAddress: The Garage Theatre, Campus, Armagh Road, Knockaconny, Monaghan, Ireland

title: National Film School Award-Winning Short Film Screening at Mason Hayes & Curran
description:
Mason Hayes & Curran have a shared value approach to the world - the success of their business is closely connected to the success of the community in which we operate. They support emerging artists and create opportunities for cultural experiences for our people and clients. This enriches communities and fosters communication and innovation.

This Culture Night, Mason Hayes & Curran are delighted to team up with IADT to show a screening of award-winning short films by the talented students and graduates of the National Film School at the Institute of Art, Design + Technology Dún Laoghaire. This unique and specially curated programme of films will include the very best of animation, drama and documentary. Suitable for a general audience. Tea and coffee will be provided.

As Ireland's campus for the Creative Industries, The National Film School of Ireland at IADT is delighted to partner with Mason Hayes & Curran on this event for Culture Night.

locations.title: Dublin City - Trinity And The Docklands

fullAddress: Mason Hayes & Curran, Barrow Street, Dublin 4, Ireland

genres.title: Visual Arts (Painting, Photography, Sculpture, Digital Art, Print, Etc)

title: National Herbarium Library Tour
description:
Join librarian Rachel Hynes for this special Culture Night tour of the library at the National Herbarium. It is the largest plant based library in the country and houses many unique collections, including botanical art and rare books. Come along to National Botanic Gardens to discover some of the exciting highlights among the Herbarium library's collections.

Places are limited and booking is essential. Email botanicgardens@opw.ie or call 01 857 0909 to reserve your spot.
fullAddress: National Botanic Gardens, Glasnevin, Dublin 9, D09 VY63, Ireland

title: National Library of Ireland Late Opening
description:
The National Library of Ireland’s Director, Dr Audrey Whitty, opens Culture Night 2024 at the NLI with the Director’s Tour. She will welcome visitors to the National Library for an access all areas tour, which will feature the famous Reading Room as well as access to the newly opened Art Room. (This tour is now completely booked out.)

Meet the Keepers – 19:00-20:00
No booking required.
Brian O’Donnell, the NLI’s Deputy Director, will be on hand in the Front Hall, and bring people into the Richard Hayes Room, to talk about the former Director and code breaker (access is limited, so this will only form part of the tour).

The Joly Theatre is where Head of Published Collections Eoin McCarney will talk about books in the National Library.

Liz Coffey, Head of Communication and Development, welcomes visitors to the famous Reading Room, where Aryton O’Brien will read passages from James Joyce’s Ulysses. These passages from Ulysses set in the Reading Room will be read at 19:00 and again at 19:30.

Gerry Long will be in the Manuscripts Reading Room, 2/3 Kildare Street to showcase some items from Special Collections. Head of Exhibitions, Learning and Programming Dr Sinéad McCoole, will talk about how to research women from the collections, showing examples of finds over the years, how often that calling up items reveals a new source, or an idea for a book, article, talk or even a play.

Conservation Studio Visit:
Booking required.
Head of Conservation Andrew Megaw and conservator Maria Montcalm will demonstrate some aspects of the preservation of the collection, with the Head of Special Collections Colette O’Flaherty.

Free Exhibitions:
No booking required.
Explore the life of W.B. Yeats and see the original items from the collection of the National Library of Ireland, his poetry, books, material from his study of the occult, his medal when he won the Nobel Prize for Literature and the top hat which he wore on the day.

National Photographic Archive: 18:00 - 20:00
Visit the National Photographic Archive in Temple Bar where staff will be on hand to answer your questions.
People and Places showcases images of Ireland and the Irish over centuries. The recent acquisition of the work of Irish Professional Photographers during the COVID-19 pandemic is also available on a large digital screen in the exhibition.
Some handouts for children will be available.

From 20:00 in the Front Hall of the Main National Library Building on Kildare St. St Mary’s College Choir led by Director Maria Stanley will be there to entrance visitors with a selection of popular music in the beautiful entrance hall. Not to be missed.
fullAddress: 7-8, Kildare Street, Dublin 2, Dublin, D02 P638, Ireland

title: National Maritime Museum
description: Free admission to the National Maritime Museum. The Museum is housed in Dun Laoghaire’s 180-year-old Mariner's Church. The museum’s greatest artefact is probably the building itself.

title: National Sculpture Factory – Open Studios & Guided Tours
description:
The National Sculpture Factory will be open to the general public to experience working professional artists' studios alongside the historically significant building.

We will have staff available on the night to walk you through the building and answer any questions you may have about the artists and their respective practices.

We also have on show our final neon commission 'The Great Forgetfulness' by internationally renowned artist Haegue Yang.
fullAddress: National Sculpture Factory, Albert Road, Ballintemple, Cork, Ireland

title: National Symphony Orchestra: Concert for Culture Night
description:
This National Symphony Orchestra concert for Culture Night invites and encourages audiences to try something new, something astonishing - two very different living American musical giants.

Programme:
Philip Glass Violin Concerto No. 1
John Luther Adams: ‘Become Ocean’
Conducted by Ryan McAdams with violin from Elaine Clark.

The First Violin Concerto by Philip Glass is a loving remembrance of his father, as moving as it is modern, while John Luther Adams describes ‘Become Ocean’ as “a meditation on the vast, deep and mysterious tides of existence”. The New Yorker said it “may be the loveliest apocalypse in musical history”.
fullAddress: National Concert Hall, Earlsfort Terrace, Saint Kevin's, Dublin, Ireland

title: Natural Woman
description: Singer songwriter Fiona Kennedy presents an hour of songs and stories inspired by ordinary women doing extraordinary things. This uplifting short concert is based on the artists recent successful stage show 'Natural Woman'.

title: Needle felting with Constance Seymour
description:
On Culture Night come along to Castledermot Community Centre for this workshop with artist Constance Seymour as she guides you in the needle-felting process wool, using a single needle to create a picture.

Needle-felting is an old art form dating from the early 19th century. It is sustainable, eco-friendly... and a word of warning, it is extremely addictive!
fullAddress: Castledermot Community Centre, Abbeyview, County Kildare, Ireland

title: Neil Ó Lochlainn Group: Immram
description:
Immram is a setting by Neil Ó Lochlainn for chamber ensemble, reciter, and singer of the Immram suite of poems written by Nuala Ní Dhomhnaill and published in her collection Feis (1991). The music was commissioned by Paddy Bushe and the Amergin Solstice Poetry Gathering in 2019. The term 'Immram' meaning Voyage, is a type of tale found in mythological Irish writing that depicts a protagonist's sea journey to the otherworld and the adventures that ensue.

This musical suite seamlessly merges the sean nós tradition, jazz/improvised music, and contemporary chamber music, creating an innovative style of contemporary Irish music that is deeply rooted in Ireland's rich singing and dance traditions.

The performance features a stellar ensemble of highly regarded musicians: Eithne Ní Chatháin on voice, Lucia Mac Partlin on fiddle, Eilís Lavelle on harp, and Neil Ó Lochlainn on double bass and flute.

“Neil Ó Lochlainn has an instinct and a feel for different strands of music that allows him to create uncompromised musical worlds that speak with real depth and authenticity” Martin Hayes
fullAddress: Hylands Burren Hotel, Main Street, Knocknagroagh, Ballyvaughan, Clare, H91 EY00, Ireland

title: NETTLE HORSE by LITTLE JOHN NEE
description:
‘Nettle Horse’ is about a man selling edible beetles at a horse fair, a woman who’s just got planning permission to build a pyramid and a horse eating nettles.
A magical new show about characters you wish you’d met years ago.

Written and performed by award winning writer, performer and musician, Little John Nee, ‘Nettle Horse’ is a transformative theatrical odyssey weaving storytelling, song, and satire, inviting the audience to untether their imagination and gallop into a parallel universe.
Simultaneously hilarious and heartbreaking.
fullAddress: Cavan Town Hall, Town Hall Street, Keadew, Cavan, Ireland

title: New Ross Drama Group a Library Performance
description:
Join New Ross Library for an evening performance by The New Ross Drama as they close out our Culture Night activities with a bang. The group will be performing one of their favourite pieces for New Ross Library and it is sure to a be great show.

The New Ross Drama Workshop was formed over 40 years ago and has been at the forefront of drama in New Ross and the surrounding area ever since. The group has staged an eclectic range of works over the many years including such classics as All My Sons by Arthur Miller, Big Maggie by John B Keane, The Cripple of Inishmaan by Martin Mc Donagh, The Importance of Being Earnest by Oscar Wilde, Dancing at Lughnasa by Brian Friel and more recently Sive by John B Keane and Same Old Moon by Geraldine Aron.

Booking essential contact the library at newrosslibrary@wexfordcoco.ie or call 051 421877.
fullAddress: New Ross Library, Barrack Lane, Pondfields, New Ross, County Wexford, Ireland

title: Newcastle West Creative Event
description:
Music Generation Limerick County and Newcastle West Foroige have been partners for 3 years working with young people in the area across all abilities. Throughout the day young people from foroige will be part of the running and shaping of the day. This will give the young people who will be performing later in the evening a sense of ownership

This will be a full day long event, Part one will combine two workshops with the two national schools in the morning and also the secondary school Transition year students in the afternoon.

The young people will take part in an interactive Music and VR workshop to make collaborative music pieces together facilitated by Music Generation Limerick County's musician educators and Foroiges youth workers.

Part two will be in the evening where participants of Foroige will perform live music in the square in Newcastle West in an open and inclusive setting for the people of the area and beyond. This live section will be 2 hours in length.

title: Nicola Spendlove: A pub, a play: Christine
description:
With A Pub, a Play eavesdropping on a private conversation is encouraged. Christine recently found out that her husband has been having a two year affair with a younger work colleague. How bloody cliché. It’s not as simple as just leaving, though. As a stay at home mother to their four young children, she has to plan her next move with consideration. Before revealing to her husband that she knows, she decides to meet the other woman in a pub and gather information.
Come sit right next to the performances in the cosy surroundings of the Rag pub at 9pm
fullAddress: The Rag, Conduit Lane, New Ross, County Wexford, Ireland

description: Join Clare Leader Forum for powerful readings from two compelling books that explore the challenges and triumphs of Disabled People: "We Are Human Too", Clare Leader Forum Co-production, edited by Ann Marie Flanagan and "Never Know Your Place" by Martin Naughton with Jo Marsden. title: Nocturnal Beats: Culture Night Late Venue Trail
description: Culture Night Late Venue Trail offers a series of free events showcasing Dublin's vibrant nightlife. From Index to Tengu, Hen's Teeth to Fidelity, the trail covers diverse neighbourhoods and cultural hubs. This year, Culture Night introduces seven new venues, welcoming a broader audience and celebrating long into the night. Spanning the City Centre and from Dublin 8 to Dublin 7, the late-night trail explores the city's heartbeat with traditional nightclubs, late-night bars, and cultural spaces. Featuring DJ culture, electronic music, and top-notch sound systems, Nocturnal Beats highlights the dynamism and relevance of electronic music culture today. Venues: Index; Tengu; Pygmalion; Hen's Teeth; Fidelity; Love Tempo; and WigWam.
fullAddress: Dublin

title: Nocturnal Beats: Late Night Venue Trail at Wigwam
description:
Culture Night at Wigwam presents a variety of musical and theatrical performances, kicking off at 19:00 with a high class drag performance with resident drag queens, Aria Nasty, Francesca Filler and Eire Comme. Think Celine Dion meets Chappell Roan meets Titanic. There will also be some fun interactive games in between the performances for everyone to get involved if that’s your thing!

Following on from the drag performances, the night will continue with DJ sets on the main floor and basement from Puzzy Wrangler, High Fidelity, Geist, Nichole Weldon, Vlad MLR and more.

title: North Circular
description:
North Circular is a documentary musical that travels the length of Dublin’s North Circular Road, from the Phoenix Park to Dublin Port, exploring the history, music and streetscapes of a street that links some of the country’s most beloved and infamous places.

The film includes musical performances from artists local to the North Circular, including Lisa O'Neill, John Francis Flynn, Séan Ó Túama, Eoghan O’Ceannabháin, Ian Lynch & Gemma Dunleavy.
fullAddress: Pavilion Theatre, Marine Road, Dún Laoghaire, Co. Dublin A96 Y959

title: North Inner City Sculptures & Monuments Walking Tour – We Act
description:
On this walking tour, Fire Station Artists’ Studios and The Five Lamps Arts Festival will bring attendees around North Inner City on an exploration through the statues and monuments, from historical pieces about national heroes such as the 'James Connolly Memorial' on North Wall, to iconic sculptures like the 'Chariot of Life' by Oisín Kelly at the Irish Life Centre, including contemporary works, such as 'Hexagon' by Steven Doody at Marino College, and 'Scathan' by Robert McColgan on Store Street Plaza.

Join tour guide Margaret O’Sullivan and artist Steven Doody to discover both the history behind the sculptures and monuments of the north east inner city, and to find out more about the making of those artworks.

Meeting point: Marino College, Memorial Garden at the 'Hexagon' sculpture.
Duration: 1 hour and 30 minutes - 2 hours.
host: Fire Station Artists' Studios & Five Lamps Arts Festival
fullAddress: Dublin, D03 X589, Ireland

title: North Munster Freemasons Open Night
description: The Masonic Hall will be open to the general public. The Masonic museum and the lodge rooms will be open with members available to talk about what the Order does and what membership means. The ancient symbolism, still used in Freemasonry today, will be explained and historical Masonic artefacts will be on show. Short talks on the history of the Limerick Masonic Lodges, dating back to the early eighteenth century, will be presented and the underlying philosophy of freemasonry described in its historical context.

title: North Tipperary Artists Collective Exhibition
description:
North Tipperary Artists Collective (NTAC) is a diverse group of over 80 local creatives. NTAC was formed in June 2023. The members of the group are from all walks of life, with artists of all ages and stages, professionals and rising stars alike. The group came together to support each other with the ambition to enrich the art and cultural life of North Tipperary by securing an appropriate permanent exhibition space to showcase the work of local, national and international visual artists as well as the work of the community.
