title: North Wexford & Bannow Historical Society Community Archive Event
description:
The North Wexford Historical Society are looking for your help to identify people, locations and events from the 1960's in the Carnew/North Gorey area.

On Culture Night join them at the Askamore Community Hall for coffee/teas and a chance to look through old 8mm film by Fr. Lennon, Parish Priest capturing local weddings, point to point racing and the new local Carnew School (1960's). This informal, community focused, event will be a great chance to connect with your local community and to be part of a local archiving project which aims to preserve this cultural heritage for the community and future generations.
fullAddress: Askamore Community Council, Aska More, County Wexford, Ireland

title: NoVendors
description:
NoVendors are a dynamic four-piece original rock band from Cavan who are currently working on new material for releasing. The band features Dara Cunningham on lead vocals and guitar, Callum Kelly on lead guitar and vocals, Adam Kelly on bass and vocals, and Gearoid Doherty on drums.

The band has showcased their talents at a variety of notable events, including the Edinburgh Fringe Festival, Sing for Me Fest, Cavan Arts Festival, Culture Night, HMV, The Soundhouse, and Cavan Music Industry Week. They have also collaborated with the Cavan Sinfonia Orchestra on several projects, adding a unique orchestral dimension to their rock sound.

In 2024, NoVendors won the Toales (Dundalk) Battle of the Bands and previously advanced to the final of the Mike the Pies Battle of the Bands in 2023. Their upcoming performances include appearances at this year’s Edinburgh Fringe Festival, the Galway Fringe Festival, and Three Stages Killarney
fullAddress: Main Street, Cavan, Ireland

title: Old Cork Waterworks Experience – Family Science Workshops and SpookScreen film showings
description:
As a special Culture Night event, family groups are invited to participate, investigate, and discover "Whats in a Drop", our hands-on science workshop exploring the weird and wonderful properties of water and lifeforms found within.

This event is suitable for children aged 8-12 years, workshop times are 4.30pm, 5.30pm and 6.30pm.
A maximum of 6 per family group to include supervising adults.

Pre-booking online is essential

ALSO

Old Cork Waterworks hosts the SpookScreen Festival of scary movies (not for kids!)
4-8:30pm
Local-genre films in the afternoon, followed by a special screening of Cork made feature 'Beyond the Woods', with a director Q and A to follow.
Queries on this event to: spookscreen@gmail.com
fullAddress: Old Cork Waterworks Experience, Lee Road, Sunday's Well, Cork, Ireland

title: Old Liffey Ferry Boat Trips
description:
Embark on a scenic journey along the River Liffey on Culture Night!

The Old Liffey Ferry has been a Dublin institution for over 50 years, providing a unique perspective on the city's iconic landmarks and hidden gems. For Culture Night Dublin 2024, they are inviting visitors to climb aboard and experience the magic of the Liffey like never before. As the sun sets, the experienced crew will guide you along the riverbank, pointing out notable landmarks and sharing stories about Dublin's rich history and culture. Enjoy the stunning views of the city's skyline, the bustling Dublin Port, and the iconic Poolbeg chimneys as the city comes alive at night.

locations.title: Dublin City - Trinity And The Docklands

fullAddress: Quay 16, North Wall, Dublin 1, D01 XE03, Ireland

title: On a House Like a Fire by Michelle Read
description:
Sometimes in a gesture, or in a turn of phrase, sometimes in the scent of hairspray, or glimpsed in an old photograph, a person reappears.

In this evocative and moving show, writer-performer Michelle Read collaborates with composer Brian Keegan to recreate the experience of remembering her mother through the things left behind.

Michelle uses glimpses of photographs and fragments of memories to gradually reveal her mother’s story and share the universal experience of remembering a loved one.

A mother-daughter story, transfused with musical echoes, and a meditation on the nature of memory itself.
fullAddress: Pavilion Theatre, Marine Road, Dún Laoghaire, Co. Dublin A96 Y959

title: One Million Stars Ireland, Star Weave Workshop and Exhibition | We Act
description:
Amber Women's Refuge GLG are delighted to present One Million Stars Ireland at the Irish Emigration Museum to celebrate Culture Night 2024. Visitors are invited to attend this special star weaving workshop in the Liffey Corner Room at the EPIC CHQ Building.

Learn to weave an eight point star that represents light, hope and solidarity against gender based violence and all violence, and tie your woven star to the LOVE star installation which forms part of the exhibition for the International Day of Peace. This exhibition follows on from previous year’s successful collaboration with many community groups who have woven thousands of eight pointed stars in solidarity. The exhibition uses art as activism to promote social change and will contain new emotive, reflective artworks from this year’s participants, who perceive war and conflict as a form of gender based violence.

locations.title: Dublin City - Trinity And The Docklands

fullAddress: North Wall, Dublin 1, D01 R9Y0, Ireland

genres.title: Visual Arts (Painting, Photography, Sculpture, Digital Art, Print, Etc)

title: One Night for the Youth: Big Badass Heroes
description: This Culture Night, the Maple Youth Centre, Ballinrobe presents; One Night for the Youth: Big Badass Heroes. Since February 2024, a group of young people have been collaborating with artist and gamemaster Adrien Sourdot as part of their Roleplaying Game Club at the Maple Youth Centre. The group have been adventuring through imaginary landscapes, guiding their characters through a story that has evolved into an epic and entertaining drama. On Culture Night, the group will present an audiovisual exhibition based on their experiences, offering the audience a chance to explore the world they have created. Attendees will be able to enjoy an exhibition of large-scale paintings depicting these big, badass heroes while listening to a recording that narrates their thrilling adventures.
fullAddress: Bowgate Court, Bowgate St, Cornaroya, Ballinrobe, Co. Mayo, Ireland

title: Open Air Traditional Irish Music Session
description:
Kilcock CCÉ will host an outdoor traditional Irish music session in Kilcock Square on Culture Night 2024. Bring along your instruments and dancing shoes and join in, play a tune, sing a song, dance!

Several of the musicians have been playing together since the inception of the Kilcock branch of Comhaltas Ceoiltoiri Éireann ovr 30 years ago, as well as teaching and passing on their knowledge and skills to the next generation, including recent County, Leinster and All Ireland Fleadh winners. Bigí linn on Culture Night 2024 for some lively entrtainment!
fullAddress: The Square, Kilcock, County Kildare, Ireland

title: Open Evening at Kinsale Masonic Lodge
description: Meet members who will answer any questions visitors may have.

title: Open Evening at The Kinsale Museum
description: Discover the eclectic collection of artefacts detailing local and regional history at Kinsale Museum. Learn about the Kinsale Giant, once the tallest man in the world, as well as the Battle of Kinsale and the Sinking of the Lusitania among a host of other interesting historical artefacts and curiosities. Volunteers will be on hand to guided you around the museum.
fullAddress: The Kinsale Museum, Market Square, Town-Plots, Kinsale, County Cork, Ireland

title: Open Evening At The Maria Edgeworth Centre
description:
The Maria Edgeworth Centre have made a number of recent acquisitions for its museum in Edgeworthstown which are culturally very important to Longford and indeed nationally and internationally.
The Centre has also mounted an exhibition by Bernard Canavan on the subject of emigration from Longford in the 1950's.

It also has in its collection an Edgeworth Family album, images from which will be on display.

For Culture Night, the museum will be open from 7.00pm to 10.00 when the curator will be on hand to talk about these important artefacts.
fullAddress: Edgeworthstown, County Longford, N39 E3C8, Ireland

title: Open Evening at the Steam Museum
description:
On Culture Night, come see this amazing collection of model locomotives and working steam engines.

Visit the 18th century walled garden built in 1777. The garden was revived in 1948 and again in 1980 and today consists of several flower areas and long walks.
host: The Steam Museum and Lodge Park Walled Garden
fullAddress: Steam Museum Café, Lodge Park, Lodgepark, Straffan, County Kildare, Ireland

title: Open House at NUI
description:
The National University of Ireland is a federal university based in 49 Merrion Square, which is an historic Georgian building. University staff will welcome visitors to their offices, which are a fascinating juxtaposition of a contemporary workplace with Georgian architecture, centuries-old wall murals, a portrait gallery, and historic artefacts such as Éamon de Valera’s Chancellor robe and his Senate chair.

There will also be some archival documents of interest and some past NCAD graduate purchase prize winners on display.
fullAddress: The National University of Ireland, Merrion Square East, Dublin 2, Ireland

title: Open House at The Irish Writers Centre
description:
From its base at 19 Parnell Square, the Irish Writers Centre has been the leading support and development organisation for writers since 1991, carrying out its work, online and in-person, on an all island basis, working with writers of all types and talents, actively encouraging writers from all communities to engage in creative writing.

The Irish Writers Centre supports writers by providing development opportunities, residencies, mentoring, resources, creative writing courses and events. Pop in on Culture Night for a cup of tea or coffee, meet the team and find out about all we have to offer.

locations.title: Dublin City - Monto And North Georgian Quarter

fullAddress: Irish Writers Centre, Parnell Square North, Rotunda, Dublin 1, Ireland

title: Open House Townley
description:
Open House at Townley Hall, 4.00-7.00pm.

Come and enjoy a House Tour, walk through many grand rooms and marvel at the elegant staircase in the Rotunda, hear many interesting facts about the building of Townley Hall and its connections to the surrounding area. See more about Francis Johnston, the architect in a wonderful exhibition about his works which include the GPO on O’Connell Street. Attend a talk on Practical Philosophy in Action!

Tea, Coffee and Biscuits served in the restored Dining Hall.
fullAddress: Slane Road, Drogheda, County Louth, Ireland

description: Brú Bhríde will host an Open Mic session on Culture Night. Members of the Travelling and Settled community are invited to share their talents and to celebrate traditional, modern music and song. The event will give all communities the opportunity to meet, discuss, make friendships in a fun and enjoyable space where the performers' talents will be appreciated.
fullAddress: Brú Bhríde, Churchview, Tuam, Co. Galway, H54EY24

title: Open Mic Night with Nenagh Players
description:
We look forward to welcoming you to the Store Hanly’s Place on Friday 20th September to celebrate this special evening with you. Our start time is 8pm. We want to share the talent that is in our group and in our local community with members and public taking part. We have an evening of song, poetry, story telling planned and maybe a few more surprises!!

As you enjoy some refreshments at the end of the evening, you will get an opportunity to chat with our members and all the performers and see some of our group’s history which is chronicled by images around the walls of the Olive Harris rehearsal room.

title: Open Mic: Music & Songs at Alliance Française
description:
In the Member’s Room at Alliance Française, the stage will be open for this ‘Music and Songs’ event which will allow you to discover hidden and emerging talents. Several budding artists will sing and perform cover songs and their own creations. Evoking France and French music, these performances will be an opportunity to travel through music and keep the summer alive together.

This event is part of the European Culture Trail – a EUNIC Ireland (European Union National Institutes for Culture) initiative for Culture Night in cooperation with the European Commission Representation in Ireland.

Immerse yourself in the diversity of European languages and cultures. For those visiting European Culture Trail events in person, you are invited to download the “European Culture Trail Treasure Hunt” passport. Collect stamps/signatures at each stop and try to win some wonderful prizes!

The French Library at Alliance Française will open up a space for people to bring their favourite poems, short stories and excerpts from novels and plays, to read in French or English for a live audience!

This event is part of the European Culture Trail – a EUNIC Ireland (European Union National Institutes for Culture) initiative for Culture Night in cooperation with the European Commission Representation in Ireland.

title: Open Night at Erasmus Smith Archive
description: Visit this unique archive located on the grounds of The High School to uncover the rich history of this 350 year old education charity. Usually only open by appointment for researchers, the archive invites visitors who want to know more about this charity that has grant-aided over 250 schools and contains a particular and interesting snapshot of Irish history. A new display celebrates the amalgamation anniversary with the Diocesan Secondary School for Girls.

title: Open Night at The Chocolate Factory
description:
Until 22:00 on Culture Night, the artists, designers, film makers, photographers, architects, upcyclers, furniture restorers and creators of the Chocolate Factory collective will host an evening in Blas to show what goes on behind closed doors in this landmark building and repurposed chocolate factory.

Food and wine will be provided by Blas throughout and our on site craft shop Raw Materials will also be open for the evening.

title: Open Night at TOG Hackerspace
description:
Tour the Hackerspace to learn about innovative projects and technologies at TOG. Enjoy demonstrations of their fabrication equipment including 3D printers, laser cutters, and CNCs. Guests can also try their hand at an electronics project or learn lock-picking. TOG encompasses many elements from the maker movement, so this is a fantastic event for creators and tinkerers of all ages!

TOG is a hackerspace run and funded by its ongoing members. It offers a modern studio-like space, with access to a large range of equipment and a community of welcoming STEAM enthusiasts.

title: Open Night Cultural Experience
description: Dynamic cultural festival that brings together a rich tapestry of arts and traditions from the community. The festival aims to establish a favourable environment that encourages creative expression and collaboration for artists and attendees, while promoting cultural exchange, encouraging artistic exploration, and facilitates meaningful engagement with the arts. Attendees can look forward to an enthralling African artist dance performance, lively Samba drumming and dance performance, mesmerizing poem recitations, enchanting accordion music, intricate Ukrainian toy crafting, and diverse cultural exhibitions showcasing various ethnic minority groups and cultures. In addition, there will be an open mic session, providing a platform for participants to share their unique perspectives and cultural heritage.

title: Open Night Displays at Revenue Museum
description:
The Revenue Museum provides a unique window on the varied activities of Revenue, from tax collection to customs controls, over several centuries. Among the displays, you’ll find a poitín stil and even some counterfeit goods seized over the years at Irish ports and airports! All of these are housed in the atmospheric crypt of the Chapel Royal at Dublin Castle.

On Culture Night 2024, you’re welcome to look around the Museum at your own pace. Short tours around the Museum’s exhibits will be offered at regular intervals during the evening.

title: Open Pottery Studio at Touch Design Ceramics Balbriggan
description:
Touch Design Ceramics invites you and your family, to tour our pottery workshop and gallery and to learn about the process of how our pottery is handmade in Balbriggan.

At Touch Design Ceramics, we create durable stoneware and porcelain on a potter’s wheel. We create these original pieces for everyday use, in a large spectrum of colours and shapes. Some are lighthouses, some fairy houses, some salad bowls and others tea sets. You have probably seen our pots in numerous places all over Ireland and in the UK. We also hold pottery classes.

title: Open Streets – On-Street Activities – N/Main St., Cornmarket St., Patrick’s St.
description:
Part of the Open Streets series of events, Culture Night sees North main Street, Cornmarket Street and Patrick's Street full of animation for the evening.
Expect music, dancing, games and more.

North Main Street
Play Street 5 -7pm

Cornmarket Street
Play in the dark 6-9pm

St Patrick's Street
Members of Cork Street Performers Association play on Pana 4-10pm

Grand Parade (not closed to traffic): 3x3 Basketball

Let's Play Cork & the Open Streets collective are offering you some new opportunities to play in our city after dark!
> As part of the Open Streets initiative, North Main Street will be opened to PLAY with a series of street games and play equipment available for all ages to use.
> Cornmarket Street will see the piloting of a novel experience - where darkness is transformed into a playful glow zone. UV lights and specially designed play equipment designed to inspire new ways we can play together in public places during the long winter evenings ahead.
> And for PLAY of a sporting kind, Cork City Council, in conjunction with the Basketball Ireland, brings 3x3 basketball to Cork city centre on Friday 20th and Saturday 21st September. We all know people in Cork like a good ball hop - so come and try your hand at the courts that will be installed temporarily on Grand Parade.

Please Note:
While North Main Street, Cornmarket Street and Patrick’s street will be will be closed to traffic from 4pm to 10pm, buses & taxis will still be operating as normal on Patrick's Street - so cross with caution.
All car parks will remain open and blue badge holder can access Patrick's street as usual. Access will also be facilitated for residents of these areas

Keep your carbon footprint low - use Blackash Park & Ride to access the city on Culture Night - open till 8.30pm
fullAddress: North Main Street, Cork, Ireland

Monaghan based Artist Aisling Slattery-Fanning is passionate about bringing the creative arts to all. Join her for an Open Studio Session and create a piece of ‘junk art’ using mixed media and recycled materials.

title: Open Studio at Úna Guy Artist’s Studio
description:
Úna Guy is a highly acclaimed artist specialising in oil painting, watercolour and pen and ink. These days, Úna is concentrating on wild landscapes depicting mystical Irish scenes. She has a great love for colour which can be seen in her wilder pieces.

Úna’s paintings have been exhibited in Germany, Australia, UK and America and she has been commissioned to produce paintings for public spaces including St John of God’s Hospital, County Dublin and The Treasury Building, Dublin 2. She is currently on exhibition in The Blue House Gallery, Schull and at Chalk and Easel, Ballinspittle, County Cork.

The Úna Guy Studio is located on the second floor of an old Georgian building, at 11 Eustace Street, Temple Bar, Dublin 2. Visiting the studio is possible year round by appointment. Drop by on Culture Night for an exclusive peek behind the scenes at the studio of a prize-winning visual artist.

title: Open Studios
description:
A visual art exhibition, video installation, poetry reading and musical performance at Studio C, a day centre for adults with ID, located in Ballybane Village. The event is part of a proposed Culture Trail through City East, in collaboration with the nearby Ballybane Library. We are showcasing artwork and a documentary film, commissioned by Studio C, exploring the connection between the day centre and the local community including the Ballybane Library, Ballybane Community Garden, and Merlin Woods. In addition, we are staging a poetry reading, and a short concert with our in-house band, as well as the opportunity for visitors to try their hand at stone painting, inspired by a stone painting project undertaken by the individuals we support over the last year. Little refreshments will be served.

Contributing an event to Culture Night gives us the opportunity to increase community awareness of the services we provide here at Studio C, as well as helping us to establish community connections for the individuals we support which is one of the overarching objectives of our day programme. Studio C is managed by Beo Services, part of the Brothers of Charity Services in Galway.

description:
For Culture Night, Avista are opening up their doors to host an immersive audio tour of their building. Come along and listen to the voices and sounds of supported individuals, staff and community members as they guide you through the history of St Vincent's Centre. Let the voices of the people of Avista transport you into the past, and catapult you into the present at this memorable audio tour.

If you have headphones/earphones, please bring them along.

Avista is a person-centred, rights-based organisation that is dedicated to improving the lives of children and adults with disabilities. Previously known as the Daughters of Charity, they have been on the Navan Road for 99 years.

title: Opera After Dark
description:
It's late into Culture Night 2024. You take a seat in the hallowed grounds of Sligo’s grand Cathedral. For this evening, you’ve discovered a hidden treasure, you’ve entered the warmth of an Artists sanctuary. You take a moment to pause. From the silence a bow becomes restless and beauty fills the air for it was once said by St Augustine: “To sing, is to pray twice”.

Come then, witness the prayer.

Starring Sharon Carty and the Sligo Baroque Ensemble featuring Sligo Baroque Music Festival Director Nicola Cleary

Culture Night Late Sligo is proudly supported by The Arts Council; Dept of Tourism, Arts, Culture, Gaeltacht, Spot and Media; Sligo BID; Sligo County Council; Purple Flags.

Booking Recommended.
host: A Hawk’s Well Theatre and Sligo Baroque Festival co-production
fullAddress: The Cathedral of the Immaculate Conception, Sligo, Temple Street, Magheraboy, Sligo, Ireland

title: Opera in Wickham Way
description:
We are delighted to be part of Culture Night , to celebrate art, culture and creativity throughout the country, as a myriad of venues across Ireland open their doors to the public and offer wonderful free events and activities.

Our Wickham Way event aims to showcase the fantastic quality of Irish culture by advocating for the importance of operatic performance in Limerick. We have a great operatic tradition in Limerick.

Culture Night has become a significant cultural tourism event because it manages to attract loads of visitors from around the world. It provides people with an immersive experience of Irish culture and allows tourists to engage with the local community and arts scene.
fullAddress: Wickham Way, Wickham Street, Prior's-Land, Limerick, Ireland

title: Organ Marathon at St. Finian’s Lutheran Church
description:
St. Finian’s generously opens its doors to the public for an evening of non-stop classical music for Culture Night Dublin 2024. Centred around its organ, church musicians and the church friends will perform an evening of mainly baroque music in the relaxing and calming surrounds of this wonderful neo-gothic building.

Music by JS Bach, the preeminent Lutheran composer will feature centrally in the program. This year also sees the 500 year anniversary of the Lutheran hymnal with a bilingual exhibition in the adjacent Lutherhaus.
fullAddress: St. Finian's Lutheran Church, Adelaide Road, Saint Kevin's, Dublin 2, Ireland

title: Organ Recital
description: To mark the 10th anniversary of Limerick Pipe Organ Festival and the 160th anniversary of the beautiful Hill organ in St John's Cathedral, Irina Dernova will perform a selection of pieces from Bach, Howells, Saint-Saens and Alain. This programme, spanning centuries from the 17th to the 20th century, will demonstrate the full range of this King of Instruments from a whisper to the most grandiose crescendo. Prepare to be transported through the medium of sound in a most beautiful setting - truly a feast for the senses.
fullAddress: St John's Cathedral, Cathedral Place, Irishtown, Limerick, Ireland

title: Oriel Echoes: A Night of Traditional Music
description: This event will celebrate the rich musical heritage of the Oriel region, showcasing the talents of renowned musicians Gerry O'Connor (fiddle), Brendan McCreanor (uilleann pipes, whistles) and Feilimí O’Connor (guitar, vocals). Through their performances, attendees will experience the unique sounds and cultural significance of Oriel's traditional music. The performance will begin with a group of students from Scoraíocht Lanne Léire.
fullAddress: Dunleer, County Louth, Ireland

title: Origami-Folding for Fun
description:
The ancient Japanese art of folding paper to create almost anything you want. No glue, no sticky tape, just Folding for Fun. From birds to planes to foxes to boxes, from wonderfully simple to wonderfully geometric. A workshop for all the family and great for sharing with your friends. Be careful, this artform is very addictive and it's only paper- just any old paper or just any beautiful paper.
2 session between 6 and 8pm
fullAddress: Galway Atlantaquaria, Seapoint Promenade, Galway, Ireland

title: Orla Whelan: ‘Coloured into Shape’ Exhibition
description:
Visit Hillsboro Fine Art on Culture Night and enjoy an exhibition of a new series of paintings from one of Ireland's most acclaimed contemporary artists.

Orla Whelan is a visual artist based in Dublin whose practice is rooted in painting. Her approach is to consider the visual language and materials of the medium as tools to reimagine contemporary possibilities for transcendence. She is motivated by an existential anxiety and a belief that abstraction is a viable means to address metaphysical uncertainties.

Whelan's work is held in the collections of The Arts Council of Ireland, The OPW State Art Collection, Trinity College Dublin, The Merrion Hotel and private collections worldwide. She is founder and director of art publishing project Whale Dust, and AtHomeStudios, a collective of visual artists working from studios based in their own homes.

locations.title: Dublin City - Monto And North Georgian Quarter

fullAddress: Hillsboro Fine Art, 49 Parnell Square West, Rotunda, Dublin, Dublin, D01 A971, Ireland

title: OTHERWORLD
description:
Join us for a one-night music and arts event celebrating the duality of Galway’s cultural identity.

Following the huge success of Culture Night 2023, Outset Gallery in collaboration with producer Emmet Kerrigan proudly present ""OTHERWORLD"" for Culture Night 2024 . This ambitious multidisciplinary arts event promises to guide audiences through an expansive landscape, spanning multiple areas, stages and showcasing stellar music acts from Galway and beyond.

Through the incorporation of an immersive audiovisual experience, ""OTHERWORLD"" seeks to encapsulate a moment in time reflecting Galway's contemporary cultural essence and identity by referencing dual timelines to create a music and arts event explores contentment and ambition, mirroring the city's balance between historic charm and future possibilities.

The night will feature a diverse line up of musicians, DJ’s and visual artists & a complete line up, stage times and more information will be shared across our social media channels @outset_gallery / @outset_events_galway

8.00-23.30 Cornstore / 23.00-01.30 Deburgos

A collection of amateur work from the ArtD's students and the students of St Cronans and Borrisokane National School. This is a collective of Autumns amazing colourings and her bragging of its unmistakable beauty. The 3 per person artworks give both that glitter of individual and of a collective form.

We also will have an Acting workshop at 7pm and a talk at 8pm from one of our students artists.
Please call over anytime on the day or evening.

Refreshments, teas and coffees will be available.

title: Our Lungs Were
description:
Our Lungs Were is a short film that I began writing sometime in 2021- still in the throes of a kind of amorphous and blinding grief. It is a lyrical piece of writing, part prose poem, part ballad, part epic. It's a film about being lost and heartbroken and swimming in the freezing cold waters that surround the island of Ireland.

From the beginning it had a kind of softness, a tenderness and working on it became a solace in some way.

“Let's face it. We're undone by each other. And if we're not, we're missing something.” is the opening line of the film. It is from Undoing Gender by Judith Butler. It's a line that I loved for ages and it perfectly holds everything I wanted this film to hold.
This film is 15 minutes long (approx)

title: Out of Sight: Displacement and Survival in Gambella, Ethiopia
description:
The Gambella region in western Ethiopia has been hosting refugees from South Sudan for more than a decade, but remains one of the most neglected humanitarian crises in the world. People have fled to Gambella due to conflict, droughts and flooding.

This photography exhibition raises awareness and tells the stories of people in this region. It highlights how affected communities cope with the impact of conflict and climate change, and showcases their resilience despite the challenges of life in the camps. Visit Oxfam Ireland at The Complex this Culture Night Dublin for a special exhibition documenting this important subject.

Oxfam Ireland fights inequality to end poverty and injustice.

title: Painting Mirror
description:
Take part in a fun, interactive digital art display presented by the French Embassy in association with the National Gallery of Ireland.

From 4pm there will be an INDOOR painting mirror in the Millennium Wing Studio and the OUTDOOR Digital display on the facade of the building will take place from 8pm until 11pm.

Experience a real-time AI digital exhibition that puts you in the frame of your own masterpiece on a grand scale as we project your portrait or landscape onto the historical Merrion Square façade. Join in and have your picture taken and mirrored on the walls in the style of some of the greatest women Impressionist artists like Berthe Morisot and Mary Cassatt, along with other masters like Monet, Cézanne and Mainie Jellett. Be a muse and take part in this immersive experience, and accompanied by DJ sets! Whether you're in Ireland, France, or beyond, view the live projection on Facebook Live.

The Gallery, in collaboration with the French Embassy in Ireland, is issuing a national callout for photographs that capture the theme of "Living in the Moment." Submissions are welcome from Ireland, France, and beyond. To participate, send a photograph of a landscape, cityscape or portrait, along with your name, email address, the name of the place and the county to culturenight@ngi.ie between August 22 and September 12th. A selection of shortlisted photographs will be stylised onto the Gallery’s Merrion Square façade.

This event is part of the European Culture Trail – a EUNIC Ireland (European Union National Institutes for Culture) initiative in cooperation with the European Commission Representation in Ireland.

‘Painting Mirror’ is part of the Digital Arts – Créativité & Innovation Tour presented by the French Embassy in Ireland in association with Irish cultural partners. This initiative aims to strengthen France-Ireland collaborations in innovation, new technologies, and creative digital arts. The tour features public immersive experiences with live interactive mapping displays, along with skills development workshops in Dublin, Galway, Tuam, and Ballina.

title: Panel Discussion -The Role Social Media Plays on Young Person’s Perspective of Sex & 40th Celebration
description:
The Role Social Media Plays on Young People's Perspective of Sex aims to explore how social media has influenced the way young people perceive sex. With the increasing use of social media platforms by young people, it is important to examine how these platforms shape their attitudes towards sex, relationships, and sexual health. The panel discussion will delve into the different ways social media impacts the sexual behaviour of young people and how it can either positively or negatively affect their perception of sex.

The objective of the panel discussion is to provide insights into the role that social media plays in shaping young people's attitudes towards sex and to discuss ways to promote healthy sexual behaviours among young people in the digital age.

Followed by music and refreshments to celebrate 40 years of GRCC

title: Photo Exhibition of the Georgian National Costumes and Georgian Medieval Epic Poem ‘The Knight in the Panther’s Skin’
description:
This Culture Night, the Embassy of Georgia invites guests to participate in a celebration of Georgian culture with the photo exhibition of the Georgian National Costumes and Georgian medieval Epic Poem ‘The Knight in the Panther's Skin’.

This exhibition presents photographs of Georgian national clothing from the collection of the Art Palace of Georgia - Museum of Cultural History. The costumes range in style from the early medieval ages to the end of the 20th century. These typically sumptuous garments worn by Georgia’s noble and royal families vividly reflect the history of Georgia, the values and cultural diversity of its people.

‘Vepkhistkaosani’ or ‘The Knight in the Panther's Skin’ is the most iconic Georgian medieval epic poem, written in the 12th century by Georgia's national poet Shota Rustaveli.

title: Plečnik’s Ljubljana – Exhibition Celebrating Slovenian Architect Jože Plečnik
description:
As part of Culture Night, the Slovenian Embassy in Dublin will open its doors to showcase an exhibition celebrating the legacy of renowned Slovenian architect Jože Plečnik. Discover the multilingual touring exhibition, Plečnik's Ljubljana, created in 2017 for the 145th anniversary of Plečnik's birth.

This exhibition has captivated audiences worldwide, showcasing Plečnik's extraordinary architectural contributions. Jože Plečnik (1872-1957), Slovenia's most celebrated architect, left his greatest mark in Ljubljana, transforming it into Slovenia's true capital. His innovative approach significantly impacted Slovenia's urban landscape and global architectural heritage. The UNESCO inscription of Plečnik's works has renewed interest in his timeless legacy.

This event is part of the European Culture Trail – a EUNIC Ireland (European Union National Institutes for Culture) initiative in cooperation with the European Commission Representation in Ireland. Immerse yourself in the diversity of European languages and cultures on the European Culture Trail, where delights from different European countries await you.For those visiting European Culture Trail events in person, you are invited to download the “European Culture Trail Treasure Hunt” passport here - https://rb.gy/4cbske - and collect stamps or signatures at each stop. The passports with the most stamps at the end of the night will be entered into a raffle for the chance to win some wonderful prizes.
host: Embassy of the Republic of Slovenia

title: Poetry from the Edge
description:
Irish PEN/PEN na hÉireann and Wicklow Arts Office present an international poetry reading from poets Sean Borodale, Jane Clarke and Viviana Fiorentino.

Poetry from the Edge reflects on climate change, nature and how poetry and words can inspire change. Three poets celebrate internationality, all the more needed at this time when we see hostility and division growing all over the world.

Viviana Fiorentino grew up in Italy and has made her home in Co. Wicklow. Jane Clarke also lives in Co. Wicklow and Sean Borodale has recently moved to Co. Sligo from England. They will read from their work, inspired by the natural world and exploring environmental loss and restoration.

BIO
Sean Borodale works as an artist, poet, writer. He was the visiting Oscar Wilde Fellow at Trinity College Dublin in 2016. He was selected as a Granta New Poet in 2012 and a Poetry Book Society Next Generation Poet in 2014. He has four collections of poetry published with Jonathan Cape. His first, Bee Journal (2012), was shortlisted for the TS Eliot Prize and Costa Book Award. Other collections are Human Work, Asylum and Inmates. Mighty Beast, a documentary poem for BBC Radio 3 about cattle markets and modern farming practices, won a Radio Academy Gold Award for Best Feature or Documentary. His topographical poem Notes for an Atlas (Isinglass 2007), written whilst walking around London, was adapted and directed as a perform
Jane Clarke is the author of three poetry collections, The River (2015), When the Tree Falls (2019) and A Change in the Air (2023) published by Bloodaxe Books. Jane’s poems explore what it means to connect with each other and our surroundings through times of cultural and environmental upheaval. She edited the illustrated anthology Windfall: Irish Nature Poems to Inspire and Connect (Hachette Books Ireland, 2023). Her most recent collection, A Change in the Air, was shortlisted for the T.S. Eliot Prize 2023, the Forward Prize for Best Collection 2023 and the Farmgate Café National Poetry Award 2024 and was also longlisted for the Laurel Prize for eco-poetry.
Viviana Fiorentino is originally from Italy. She graduated at the Seamus Heaney Centre (Queen’s University) with a MA in Poetry. She translated Irish poet Freda Laughton into Italian (Arcipelago Itaca, 2022), Doireann Ní Ghríofa (VersoDove, 2024), Paula Meehan (Il Pietrisco, 2023) and Layli Long Soldier (Verodove, 2023). One of her essays on Anne Carson appeared in the volume Trasparenze 8/22 of San Marco dei Giustiniani (2022). Her poems in English appeared in anthologies (Dedalus Press, Salmon Poetry, Arlen House) magazines (i.e. The Stinging Fly, Banshee Press), on public transports in Dublin (Poetry Ireland), on air for RTÉ 1 and in the The Irish Poetry Reading Archive. In Italy she published a novel and two poetry collections. She is 2022 Irish Chair Of Poetry Student Prize winner and finalist in the Gregory O’Donoghue Poetry Competition 2024. Viviana is supported by The Arts Council.

title: Presenting The School of Hibernia (after Raphael) 2024
description:
The School of Hibernia (after Raphael), 2024 is a high-profile art project which received national and international recognition. The photograph depicts a full-scale re-enactment of Raphael’s School of Athens 1511 fresco with an all-women cast devised by the art collective Na Cailleacha and staged in collaboration with Trinity’s History of Art and Architecture Department in the Museum Building.

The image features women from a variety of age profiles and backgrounds, all leaders in their fields, who have contributed to human knowledge. This event on Culture Night will comprise of a large-scale projection of the work and a cross-disciplinary, inter-generational seminar. It will highlight the importance of integrating and critiquing art history, architecture, education, science and other disciplines from sport to social activism.

Participants are Dr. Rachel Moss, Associate Professor, History of Art & Architecture at Trinity College Dublin; Saoirse Exton, Irish representative on the United Nations Young People’s Climate Change Group; artists Patricia Hurl, Therry Rudin, and Art historian and Curator Catherine Marshall all of Na Cailleacha. Each speaker will give a short presentation on different aspects of the project, followed by a Q&A session.
This is a great opportunity to meet some of the creators of the School of Hibernia and to find out more about this unique and intriguing project. There will be much to discuss!

**Booking essential**

title: Prints & Tales: Linocut Printmaking and Storytelling Workshop
description:
Join us for an evening of creativity and storytelling at Portumna Town Hall. This unique workshop combines the art of linocut printmaking with the magic of collaborative storytelling. Participants will learn the basics of linocut carving and printing, creating their own prints. As each participant completes their print, we will incorporate these individual images into a collective narrative. During the workshop, you will:
1. Receive a brief introduction to the techniques and tools used in linocut printmaking.
2. Design and carve your own linoleum block.
3. Print your design onto high-quality paper.
4. Collaborate with fellow participants to craft a unique story inspired by the prints.
5. Record your voice narrating a part of the collective story.
At the end of the session, we will compile the prints, story, and voice recordings into a video. Each participant will receive a digital copy of this video, featuring photographs of their prints. This workshop is suitable for beginners. Adults 18+

title: Protect the Protest
description:
As part of Galway Culture Night, the Amnesty Galway Group are planning an event with two parts: the first part is a talk by our Executive Director, Stephen Bowen, the second part is a postcard campaign for political prisoners in Russia.

Stephen will talk about Amnesty’s work in general and more particularly about human rights violations in Europe and Russia. Following the war in Ukraine, the Russian parliament has introduced war censorship laws to impede any criticism against the invasion by making it a grave offence. Several people are serving lengthy prison sentences for peaceful anti-war dissent. Unfortunately, other European parliaments are passing laws to restrict the right of peaceful assembly and protesting. Amnesty International has a campaign, called “Protect the Protest”, to raise awarness in the wide community about this worrisome trend. As part of this campaign, Amnesty advocates on behalf of Russians who have been imprisoned by the Russian authorities for their various protests against the War in Ukraine.

The local Galway Amnesty Volunteer Group will provide postcards of Galway with messages written in Russian to stick to the postcards. We will invite people to choose a message, stick the message to the postcard, add a drawing if they like and sign the postcards. We will also have markers for those who want to draw a visual message. These postcards will be posted to the Russian prisoners of conscience that are serving several-year sentences in prison just for exercising their right to protest the war in Ukraine.
fullAddress: Irish Centre for Human Rights, University Road, Galway, Ireland

title: Pruːf, A Group Exhibition Curated by Sarah Pierce at the Library Project in Temple Bar
description:
Pruːf draws on guest curator and artist Sarah Pierce’s ongoing interest in alternative ways of knowing, thinking, acting and making. Queer(ed) identities, false histories, and radical mysticisms overlap as drives in the exhibition. Pierce has selected twelve works from across geographies and historical periods focusing on artworks that question what is seen, cast as truth, and where the image lies (or lies). Several works in the show are unfinished, damaged, or refer to research in progress or artworks that were never made; others were never intended to be seen as art and have been gathered for this presentation only.

Artists include Buddhist Third Class Junkmail Oracle, Ian Burn, Gerard Byrne, Janine Davidson, Jacob Epstein, Emma Finucane, Breda Lynch, Fiona Mc Donald, Emily Mc Gardle, [O+F+C], Kathy Prendergast, and Elizabeth Price.

Commissioned by Black Church Print Studio.

It requires you to bring nothing except an imagination - everything else, including pencils and paper, will be provided.

title: QuareClare Poetry Night. Clare Pride 2024
description:
QuareClare proudly presents another night of Queer Poetry for Culture Night at glór. This year’s event features renowned poet and editor Paul Maddern and performance poet and playwright Dr. Lauren McNamara. We are also thrilled to introduce newcomer Katie McCann, a talented performance poet. The event will be hosted by Clare-based, internationally renowned poet and community worker Sarah Clancy, promising an extravaganza of queer literary talent.
Paul Maddern, born in Bermuda to Irish and Cornish parents, resides in Co. Down, where he operates the River Mill Writers Retreat. Paul has published with Templar Poetry and edited the Queering the Green: Post-2000 Queer Irish Poetry.

Lauren McNamara, from Co. Limerick, is a widely published author of plays Quarter Life Crisis and Hello My Name is Single, which have been performed in multiple cities worldwide.

Katie McCann is a queer singer, poet, and comedian who began performing at open mics regularly two years ago. Her work explores queer identities, human eccentricities, and self-analysis.

Sarah Clancy is the winner of the Cuirt International Festival of Literature Grand Slam Championships. Author of Stacey and the Mechanical Bull, Thanks for Nothing, Hippies, and The Truth and Other Stories, Sarah holds an MA in Public Advocacy and Activism. She is also a respected political activist and commentator.

All members of the LGBTQIA+ community and allies are welcome to this free event. Booking is essential at www.quareclare.ie.

title: Race and Place in the City
description:
"Mind blowing."
"Brilliant."
"I will never look at these streets the same again."

Using stories of local buildings and places, Richard Carson invites participants to reimagine our relationships with the place and with one another. Using history, theology and much more, we will encounter how the colonial imagination was established in the place of the north east inner city and is still yet to be exorcised.

This 90-minute walking tour of Lower Gardiner Street and its laneways has featured on RTÉ Lyric FM, Culture Night 2023 and with numerous schools, colleges and community groups. New features for 2024 include a local wedding that united two settings of 19th century colonialism from opposite sides of the world and how what happened at the site of Store St. Garda Station over 250 years ago reminds us that so-called “new communities” are not so new after all.

Meeting point: Custom House, South Facade, beside the river, D01 W6X0

description:
View a new short animated film by Stephen Fagan, highlighting the story of Private James Daly, a Connaught Ranger, who was executed by the British Army for playing his part in rebellion.

In 1920, protesting how his fellow citizens were treated by the British occupation, Private James Daly, a soldier in the British Army and an Irishman from Boyle, along with some other members of the Connaught Rangers battalion, staged a mutiny at the Wellington Barracks in India; as a result, James Daly was executed by firing squad.

title: Red Moon Creative Arts Theatre Presents – ‘Hideous Creatures’
description:
Join Red Moon Creative Arts Theatre at the Bullring for an interactive family friendly performance. Expect laughs, surprises and colourful costume as we join Bobbie and Terry on their adventure.

It’s 3am in the morning. Bobbie has just snuck her best friend, Terry (an enormous tarantula), into the family’s back garden for his nightly ‘tarantuladventure’, when a mysterious flying object crash-lands in her mother’s favourite flower bed!! A ‘hideous creature' emerges, much to Bobbie’s terror!

Trepidatious as she is, Bobbie knows she must override her fear (and awkwardness!) in order to save her beloved arachnid, but comes to realise, in the process, that the cosmic being is far more scared of her than she is of it!

Through comical trial and error, misunderstanding and mishap, the two begin to learn how to communicate a little better, understand each other’s stories and needs, explore their differences, celebrate their commonalities, and even have some fun!

But how will Bobbie’s beastly big brother react when he discovers the alarming alien? He's never been very tolerant...

A story about taking a leap of faith, being open to new people and experiences, and navigating the concept of acceptance.
fullAddress: The Bullring Market, The, Bull Ring, Ferrybank South, Wexford, Ireland

Through comical trial and error, misunderstanding and mishap, the two begin to learn how to communicate a little better, understand each other’s stories and needs, explore their differences, celebrate their commonalities, and even have some fun!

title: Reels on the Bus
description:
"Reels on the Bus is an interactive traditional music workshop and live trad music session open to secondary school students in Longford.

Reels on the Bus aims to introduce young people to Irish traditional music with a one-hour workshop in Bodhrán. This workshop allows for 100% participation, where everyone will get a Bodhrán, provided by Music Generation Longford for the event, and will be guided by professional musicians on the basics of this instrument. This immersive workshop is open to complete beginners and experienced musicians who will learn how to accompany live traditional music in a fun, collaborative environment.

Participants will put their new skills to immediate use as the workshop will be followed by a live 'session' concert. The budding Bodhrán players will play alongside experienced, professional trad musicians playing a variety of instruments including concertina, banjo and fiddle.

Reels on the Bus will be a vibrant, cultural experience for young people to enjoy this traditional instrument.

'Reflections' will bring to life the Wexford Arts Centre building highlighting the history and vibrant arts and culture offer within the town as part of Wexford Arts Centre celebrating its 50th anniversary as the oldest regional arts centre in Ireland. Featuring designs by Cormac Murray and Eddie O'Flaherty from Algorithm and artworks by Jonny Murphy and Mirona Mara.

More information coming soon.

description:
Rodrigo Almonte is a Peruvian/Irish guitarist and composer based in Kildare. With influences gathered from around the world through his musical journey, Almonte creates an eclectic and engaging approach to improvised music. Fuelled by the musicality of Irish musicians Aidan Gray on double bass and Michael McCarthy on drums, Almonte’s music explores emotion and story-telling through inspiring melodies and intricate rhythms.

- “Almonte's shimmering guitar resembles the music of Pat Metheny, and sometimes even Tal Farlow.” - All About Jazz
- “Rodrigo Almonte’s approach to music is a sublime distillation of musical genres and inspirations with various influences from around the world weaved within its rich basket of harmonies and melodies.” - Jazz Views

Curated by Jazz in County Kildare, this unique project presents original compositions that combine contemporary jazz and traditional Peruvian music

title: Roots and Routes: A Celebration of Old and New Traditions
description:
Roots and Routes: A Celebration of Old and New Traditions is more than just an event; it is a celebration of the shared human experience and the beauty of diversity. Come and be a part of this vibrant celebration, where every culture is honored, and everyone is welcome. Together, we will celebrate the cultural richness that makes our communities thrive.

An unforgettable evening at Cultural Night in Castlerea, a national celebration of culture, creativity, and the arts that brings communities together to share and experience the rich tapestry of our diverse society. This event is a national moment, designed to actively promote the belief that our vibrant and varied culture is alive, treasured, and nurtured in people’s lives today and every day.

Intercultural Celebration:
This year's Cultural Night in Trinity Art Centre Castlerea will feature a remarkable intercultural aspect, showcasing the traditions and contributions of various nationalities that now call Ireland home. Participants will include Irish, Ukrainians, Afghans, Nigerians, Syrians, Polish, and representatives from the Balkan countries. Each group will offer a unique glimpse into their culture through:- Food, Dance, Photography and Traditional Arts and Crafts.
Join us for an evening of cultural exchange, creativity, and community spirit. Let's celebrate the rich cultural tapestry that is Ireland today!

title: Saint Michael’s Church: Pugin’s Romanesque Gem in the heart of Gorey
description:
Explore the rich history of North Wexford through a series exhibitions and tours of Saint Michael’s Church, Pugin’s Romanesque gem in the heart of Gorey. These events are open to everyone. They will explore how the history of Saint Michael’s is intricately interwoven with the broader history of Gorey and the wider North Wexford area. No booking is required, just turn up on the evening.

Come explore our past, and see the work we are doing in the present to preserve our shared history for future generations.

5pm – 8pm: Exhibition in the Pastoral Centre featuring the treasures of Saint Michael’s Church, along with photographs and documents from the Parish Archive.

5pm and 7pm: Guided tours of Saint Michael’s Church, beginning at the Parochial House , will explain the development of the parish and church, while highlighting some of the fascinating stories and characters from Saint Michael’s long history.

5pm – 8pm: Icon exhibition in Saint Michael’s Church will explore the liturgical and spiritual beauty of the ancient artform of iconography.

The grounds and church are fully wheelchair accessible

Satakieli:
Satakieli (meaning 'Nightingale' in Finnish) is an ensemble of women's voices dedicated to performing the beautiful folk-based and contemporary a cappella music of Finland. They came together in 2022 and rehearse on a monthly base, in Kilkishen Cultural Centre. They have so far performed joint concerts with Ancór in Limerick and Cois Cladaigh in Galway, as well as Culture Night in the Clare Museum, Ennis, in 2023. The choir is directed by Richard Pomfret.

Harmony Bro:
Harmony Bro is a recently-established a cappella group of men based in Ennis, who sing a wide variety of music from Doo-wop to Barbershop to Sea Shanties and enjoy performing anything with a bit of harmony. They won 1st prize in the National Competition for Lower Voice Choirs at the 2024 Cork International Choral Festival. The choir is directed by Michael Hennessy.

title: SCATTER
description:
An virtual exhibition by Nua Collective.

Launching on Culture Night, Friday 20th September at 7pm on www.nuacollective.ie/scatter.

Across diverse contexts—whether in the shifting patterns of the sky, the migration of people, the application of paint, or the passage of time — there exists a universal experience of scattering. As humans, we find ourselves dispersed by forces both external and internal, whether through geographic relocation, emotional distance, or the natural progression of life.

Yet, within this scattering lies a profound potential for reconnection. Our roots, relationships, and shared histories form intricate networks that, despite physical or emotional distances, continue to bind us together. This process of scattering and reuniting, of shedding the old to embrace the new, reflects the dynamic and resilient nature of the human experience. Whether scattered by choice or circumstance, we carry within us the threads that link us back to our origins, to each other, and to the ever-present possibility of reconnection.

Original artworks created specifically for this concept collection by Nua Collective artists Anne Martin Walsh, Caoimhe Heaney, John Murray, Josh Stein, Katrīna Tračuma, Maria Markham, Robert Jackson, Saoirse O'Sullivan, Eamonn B. Shanahan, Lucy Lambe and Christina Geoghegan.

Join us for our free launch event. There are limited spaces available for our private zoom showcase - please sign up through the following link: www.nuacollective.ie/scatter/

Established in 2020, Nua Collective is a visual arts collective providing a space that supports artists, shares their work and starts conversation

description:
The Seamus Heaney: Listen Now Again exhibition invites visitors on a fascinating journey exploring the highlights of Heaney's archive, from his rural origins through to his remarkable career as a poet.

Heaney's own writing desk is the focal point of an experience that explores Heaney’s creative process through original manuscripts, as well as letters, unpublished works, diary entries, photographs, personal artefacts and multimedia recordings, revealing the internal and external forces that shaped his work.

Curated by Professor Geraldine Higgins, Director of Irish Studies at Emory University, this exhibition was created in partnership between the NLI, the Department of Tourism, Culture, Arts, Gaeltacht, Sport and Media, and Bank of Ireland.

title: Secret Sonic Cinémathèque: Live Scores to Silent Film
description:
Secret Sonic Cinematheque is a unique presentation of short silent movies or excerpts of movies with a live score performed by the SSC ensemble. The movies span a broad range from documentaries to fantastic imaginings to experimental processes.

The audience will experience a wide and varied series of sights and sounds as the group works through their prescribed works along with a number of ‘surprise’ films, chosen with the participation of the audience. In our efforts to make the events as site-specific as possible we like to source a movie from a local filmmaker, where possible as well as using local guest composers in our ensemble.

Each composer picks a movie to score in whatever manner they see fit, from total improvisation to guided improvisation to fully realised composed works, to be realised by some or all of the musicians, as required by the composer.

Our core composers (Andy Mooney and Diarmuid MacDiarmada) facilitate the guest composers in any way they can in the realisation of their ideas. Andrew Edgar is our very entertaining compere who brings in an element of audience participation with regard to the choice of films that the group will respond to, sight-unseen.

The audience invariably understands that the Secret Sonic Cinematheque is an artistic tight-rope walk and tends to be very engaged in the nail-biting drama unfolding before them.

title: Séideáin – Canadh, Amhráin, Síocháin
description:
Ócáid aon uaire faoi leith, Séideáin - Amhráin, ‘Síocháin’
Beidh an cór, muintir an Spidéal, Cois Fharraige agus máguaird ag teacht le chéile le seánra éagsúla amhráin a chasadh le chéile thar 30 go 40 nóiméad cois le sráid bhaile an Spidéal. Beidh béim ar amhráin na síochána cé nach amhráin síocháin uile a bheidh á gcanadh ar an tráthnóna. Tá fearadh na fáilte roimh óg agus aosta!
Spreagadh na hócáide Séideáin Amhráin, Síocháin. Tagann an spreagadh don imeacht seo ó leithéid “Blowing in The Wind” le Bob Dylan, amhráin frith chogaidh agus le spreagadh ón réabhlóid amhránaíochta san Eastóin agus sna tíortha Balcánach, ag tagairt go sonrach don “réabhlóid amhránaíochta” ó 1987 go 1991 áit ar tharla mór agóidí de 300,000 duine agus iad ag canadh i Tallinn, in imeachtaí a deirtear gur chuir siad le neamhspleáchas na hEastóine sa deireadh ón Rúis. Glacfaidh muid páirt bheag le hardú glóire a thabhairt don tsíocháin agus an t-athrú gaoithe atá ag teastáil sa domhan tríd a bheith ag canadh lena chéile.

title: Seisiún Ceoil agus Damhsa do Ghasúir Réamhscoile agus Luathbhlianta
description: Tabharfar deis do ghasúir réamhscoile agus luathbhlianta taitneamh agus tairbhe a bhaint as ceol agus damhsa traidisiúnta an cheantair. Casfaidh na ceoltóirí cuid de na foinn is mó aithne i repertoire an cheoil thraidisiúnta do na gasúir agus labhróidh siad leo faoi na huirlisí a chasann siad. Déanfaidh na damhsóirí dreas damhsa do na gasúir agus beidh seans ag na gasúir dul ag damhsa freisin. Ceolfaidh na hamhránaithe amhráin thraidisiúnta leis na gasúir atá feiliúnach dóibh agus le gur féidir leo páirt a ghlacadh san amhránaíocht freisin. Tabharfaidh an seisiún blaiseadh deas de chultúr an cheantair do na gasúir, chomh maith le sin tabharfaidh sé deis dóibh páirt a ghlacadh ann agus a spéis i ngnéithe éagsúla den chultúr a spreagadh agus a chothú. Anuas ar an rannpháirteachas thuasluaite, bainfear leas as ábhar amharc-ealaín ar nós póstaeir mhóra ar a mbeidh léaráidí agus cuid den bpríomh fhoclóir a bhaineann le hábhar le labhairt faoin gcultúr áitiúil agus na huirlisí srl. Fágfar na póstaeir sin in airde san Ionad i ndiaidh na himeachta, cuirfidh na póstaeir seo le foghlaim agus feasacht na ngasúr ar a gcultúr.

title: Self-Guided Tours at Christ Church Cathedral
description:
Christ Church’s audio guide uses storytelling to bring the cathedral’s nearly 1,000-year history to life in a new and exciting way.

It is offered in 7 languages; English, French, German, Spanish, Polish, Portuguese and Italian. Irish Sign Language and Audio Descriptive tours are also available with transcriptions (in English only). Please download the audio guide onto your own device and bring your earphones/headphones. Visitors are able to choose from three different themes as they explore: ‘Power and Politics’, ‘Christ Church & the City’ and ‘Music & Spirituality’.

There is a limit of 200 spaces available for each self-guided tour and they must be pre-booked in advance. The audio guide must be downloaded onto your own device as physical devices will not be available on the night.

Slots for these self-guided tours are at 16:00, 17:00, 18:00 and 19:00. The tour lasts approximately 45 minutes. Please note that latecomers will not be admitted. There are no bathroom facilities on site.

title: Seoladh Fáistineach le Eoghan Ó Ceannabháin, Ultan O’Brien & Saileog Ní Cheannbháin
description:
Launch of Fáistineach with Eoghan Ó Ceannabháin, Ultan O'Brien & Saileog Ní Ceannabháin.

Concert with Eoghan Ó Ceannabháin, Ultan O'Brien and Saliog Ní Ceannabháin, produced by the collective Gliogar group in the area of An Mám.
The concert will open the Fáistineach an installation by Peter-Tom Mercier as part of the Dinnseanchas project with Hometree.

Fáistineach is an audio-visual installation concerning the dual-trajectory of upland areas and communities, in this case An Mám, Dúiche Sheoigeach and North Conamara. The aim is to represent two future outcomes, possible progress and the worst-case scenario.

The “worst-case scenario” is a future in which the domestic wool industry has plummeted, increased rainfall has led to the collapse of cattle farming, biodiversity is beyond extinction level, invasive species and reduction of native woodlands cause water quality disasters, depopulation accelerates, closure of schools and local services and the area is abandoned.

The “possible progress” is a future in which tradition meets innovation where traditional sustainable farming methods are hybridised biodiversity caretaking enterprises. This new custodianship not only leads to an increase of biodiversity and carbon capturing, but also to the locality flourishing with a co-operative economy. As the local economy grows, offering new forms of meitheal and income from progressive agricultural methods for future generations of farmers. This a future based on pre-industrial Ireland in which the community, local economy and natural ecosystem are synchronised for the betterment of all.

This installation hopes to spark conversation in upland communities around their future and the power they have to make it a positive one through their collective decisions.

An té nach gcuireann san earrach ní bhaineann sé san fhómhar.

description:
Sexual pleasure is for everyone - whether you're young, old, outgoing, shy, gay, straight, deaf or blind - for most it's a natural aspect of being human.
So how can you practice pleasure in your daily life, and why should you bother? What could make you feel more confident in your sexual experiences?

Fun and educational insights on embracing pleasure throughout the many ages and stages of our lives, as well as some blue-sky thinking on a sexier Cork! This event is open to all demographics (over 18) - you do not need to be sexually active or partnered to glean some useful information, as well as a few laughs, at this workshop.

Sex educator Sx Sláinte is joined by the delightful ISL interpeter Keira O' Connell for this inclusive workshop. (18+)

title: Sexual Violence Centre Cork / Indie Cork Film Fest – Film screening with live score
description:
Visions of the Future by Flowers At Night

The Sexual Violence Centre Cork is delighted to partner with IndieCork Festival in presenting this special film screening and live performance on Culture Night, curated and performed by electronic artist, Juno Cheetal (Flowers at Night). The screening will be accompanied by a live-score, played over segments of pre-recorded compositions for each film, using vintage synthesizers, field recordings, theremin, pipe chimes, and autoharp.

These short films/animations and TV ads of the period explore the themes of the 50's and 60's space-race through the lens of culture.

The cold war between the US and the USSR displayed competing visions of the future which shaped the horizons of everyday experience, influencing popular culture through film, leisure, architecture, design and fashion, as well as peoples’ overall perceptions of the future which were often fantasies of a highly technological society with fantastical gadgetry, virtual worlds, robots, space colonies and interstellar travel.

Films like 2001 A Space Odyssey (1968) opened up a new market for science-fiction blockbusters like Star Wars, Alien, Close Encounters and Bladerunner. Disney transformed its theme parks to include a variety of space-themed amusements such as 'Astro Orbiter' and 'Space Mountain'.

description:

A renowned uilleann pipe player and maker in his time, he is relatively unknown today. Through this event, we aim to preserve and celebrate his legacy.
The programme will also highlight the best local talent and culture, featuring theatre, song, music, and poetry with a special connection to Shercock. Each section of the event is planned to be approximately 20 minutes long. The lineup is outlined below.

title: Short Reading ‘Going Home to Roscommon’ Fictional Story
description:
Title: Going Home to Roscommon
Author : Catriona M. Byrne

The story is a fictional and set in the West of Ireland.

Olivia reaches a crossroads in her life and escapes to the West of Ireland for some respite. Leaving a very comfortable lifestyle to move to her ancestors very dilapidated cottage outside Boyle. With little savings and no job to sustain her, she is forced to live very frugally, recycling everything in her path.

However, despite the enforced distance between herself and her past, she has no option but to confront her tormentors.

Surrounded by all the beauty and tranquility of Lough Key on her doorstep , she unearths other hidden gems and heritage in County Roscommon, the people and places she encounters making her reassess her previous lifestyle.

Having forged strong friendships with her neighbours she discovers they also have their own demons in life, but through the power of true friendship and community spirit, Olivia and her newfound friends emerge as stronger and better people.

Adding to the evening's atmosphere, we are delighted to welcome the renowned soprano Regina Nathan as our guest performer. Her exquisite voice will bring a new dimension to the evening, complementing the visual art with a selection of pieces that resonate with the exhibition's themes.

Music will also be provided by the talented duo Áine and Matt Heslin, whose melodies will weave through the event, creating a harmonious blend of auditory and visual experiences.

title: SNAP, PIC, CHAT: An Exploration of Life Challenges
description:
A sensory creative experience for teens with disabilities where you will explore how we can rise and shine from life’s challenges by using our imaginations and inner superpowers within our own natural environment, ending with going outside into the beautiful Autumnal trees in the Fair Green, having support, time, space and fun to exhibit your work which the public from 8 to 8 15pm as you arrange your very own SNAPCHAT.

Using various drawing, paint and textile materials, you will respond to pop music that portrays our theme of feeling challenged and failing at something, but later managing to problem-solve and get out of the rut!...painting or drawing large scale on the wall or ground. Sorohan will provide you with a variety of unused paint and surfaces, wallpaper and canvas. The emphasis is on the expression of feelings through colour, lines, shapes, patterns and form as the teen works intuitively responding to my prompts and music.

The workshop is limited to eight teenagers who have Autism or another learning difficulty. Personal assistants may accompany the teenager. Teenagers can bring small snacks for our picnic that will take place halfway through the session in the park.

Booking essential with the teen's name, age and needs by Whats app message to Eve: 087 9890219

Bookings open 6th to 13th of Sept

The event will take place at Ennis community rooms, Fair Green , Ennis. Please park on Steeles Terrace: V95H67A and enter Fair Green from the archway opposite.

The exhibition showcases the wide photographic perspectives and styles within the club including wildlife, landscape, seascape, abstract, still life and other genres.

This event is online to facilitate a wide audience in our virtual exhibition gallery where you can freely roam around or take part in a guided tour to view the artworks.

title: Songlines
description:
Actress and Singer Susie Lamb in collaboration with musician and composer Kate Powell bring you Songlines; A one hour acoustic performance in the beautiful Rothe House in the heart of Kilkenny City. These songs tell stories of love and loss, the domestic and the political. They chart the relationship between Ireland and England over the centuries through coded romance, rejection, seduction and exile.

They mirror the landscape itself, and have travelled the byways of the British Isles laying down songlines as they are passed from voice to voice. Presenting Irish and English folk songs with Gaelic Sean Nos singing, Songlines explores thematic links within and between songs of these musical traditions which themselves are intertwined and share common heritage.

The performance will feature songs collected by Susie in Connemara as well as music made popular by the likes of Seosaimh O’Heanaigh, Margaret Barry, Annie Briggs, June Tabor and others.

Come and help us experiment with and explore how music and abstract visual improvisation interact and influence each other in this kaleidoscopic multi-sensory and participatory experience.

title: Sound the Bells in Taney
description:
"The Taney Bell Ringers are a group in Dundrum, Dublin that practice the traditional art of full-circle change ringing. This is a method of ringing where bells are rung by hand in a series of varying sequences under the direction of a conductor.

In this form of ringing, bells in the Church steeple are mounted on a headstock attached to a large wheel attached to a rope. When the ringer pulls the rope at the bottom of the tower, this turns the wheel, causing the bell to swing and then rotate in a full circle. The bell rotates from top to bottom and back again - sounding a chime at each end of the rotation.

Full circle change ringing can be traced to the early 17th century. Since then, mechanical systems have replaced most teams of ringers - Taney is one of just five steeples in Dublin that are still rung by hand.

The bell tower at Taney houses a set of bells from St George's Church on Hardwicke Street. These bells were first commissioned by architect Francis Johnston for his own use in a full-size steeple he built at the end of his garden. His neighbours persuaded him to donate the bells to a church, so they were moved to St. George's in 1828. After St George's was deconsecrated in 1990, these bells were rescued and stored until their installation at Taney in 2000.

For Culture Night, we will host three open ringing sessions where visitors can listen to a team ring, then try sounding a bell themselves."
fullAddress: Christ Church, Taney Parish, Taney Rd, Dundrum, Dublin, Ireland

title: Sounds from the Burren
description:
An authentic evening with rich and pure sounds from the Burren. Artists, musicians and singer-songwriters based in the Burren area of Clare come together to share the vibrant and vivid heritage and creativity of this ancient and unique region in the intimate surroundings of the Whale Theatre.

To open the evening we will be joined by environmental poet Grace Wells with musical accompaniment and visuals. Grace has published three books of poetry, and is currently Writer-in-Residence for Hometree Charity’s Dinnseanchas eco-arts project.

Next joining us will be Branwen Kavanagh, a musician and performance artist from the West of Ireland. Their work is imagination centric and is inspired by mythology and folklore from home and around the world. They are a songwriter, a sculptor, puppeteer, a visual artist, writer of surreal visual plays, and a lively adventurer.

Rounding out the evening will be an energetic performance from MegaTrad, an innovative and exciting trio that bring high energy, improvisation and a new tribal face to Irish traditional music.

Pre-booking is essential, and tickets will be allocated on a first-come, first-served basis, via the Whale Theatre website.

www.whaletheatre.ie

Róisín Dubh:
One of Carlow’s most popular bands, comprising of John Kelly, Sean Byrne, Mick Miley, Micheál Bolton and Willie Delaney. Róisín Dubh have played in every corner of Ireland as well as the UK, USA, France, Germany and Europe and toured on separate occasions with Irish legends, The Wolfe Tones and The Dubliners.

Benny Culleton:
Benny has played extensively throughout Ireland with many different bands but this time, Benny is going solo to perform some well-known Irish Folk and Ballad songs.

Mad For Trad:
Mad for Trad is a traditional band made up of local musicians. The group features some of the county’s most talented players, including Cillian Townsend and Brian Ó Déan. They are known for their vibrant and energetic performances, as anyone lucky enough to witness their recent display at Carlow Arts Festival can attest to.

title: Soundwalk
description:
A guided sound and listening walk around the town of Midleton. Participants will be encouraged to mindfully listen to sounds past and present and will be provided with a guidance map from the artist Danny McCarthy.

Led by the artist Danny McCarthy. McCarthy is vastly experience in the field of Sound Walks having led his first walk over twenty years ago and led walks all over Ireland and abroad.. The walk will take a circular route around the town where participants will be able to mindfully listen to the various sounds of the town old and new, big and small and develop a listening practice of their own. The walk will encompass sites that once had very different distinctive sounds associated with them to the sounds that are now there. The walk takes place at 7pm and gives plenty of time to attend other Culture Night events before and after.

title: St George and St Thomas Church Community
description:
The Church of Ireland Parish of St George and St Thomas is the oldest continuous organisational structure still in existence in Dublin's North-East Inner City. Founded in 1758, the original Venetian styled church was destroyed on June 4th 1922 in the Battle of Dublin. Through a government compensation scheme, a brand new church was built and opened on the site in 1931. This church was paid for by the exchequer, making it the only Protestant church in Ireland funded by Irish Free State taxpayers. The Parish has seen many changes in North Dublin's residential, economic and cultural life. Indeed it has recently restructured and reopened its church, following a period of reorganisation.

Come and see this fascinating oasis located just off Dublin's main thoroughfare, O'Connell Street, this Culture Night.

title: St. Fin Barre’s Cathedral – Open House
description:
Embark on a journey of architectural splendour, living history and spiritual enlightenment at Saint Fin Barre's Cathedral in Cork. Celebrating 1400 years of continuous worship since its inception as an ecclesiastical site and founding location of the city of Cork in 606 AD, St. Fin Barre’s provides the ideal starting point to explore Ireland’s second capital.

The Cathedral has played a pivotal role in the topography of Cork city, providing a language for the cityscape which can be seen by the names of our local buildings and streets. Marvel at the exquisite craftsmanship of this iconic landmark, where every stone was laid by hand - learn of its architectural significance, a French gothic cathedral designed by Burgess and one that celebrates the skills and craftsmanship of this monumental project started in 1865. From its intricate stained-glass windows to its majestic spires, every corner of Saint Fin Barre's Cathedral tells a story of resilience and devotion.

On Culture Night we open our doors to all visitors from 6pm to 9:30pm with guided tours at 7, 8 and 9pm providing an expert overview of Cork's finest Victorian building.
fullAddress: Saint Fin Barre's Cathedral, Bishop Street, The Lough, Cork, Ireland

title: St. Joseph’s Church, Mayfield – History, Art and Architecture
description:
Built in 1881, St Joseph's Church has been an integral part of the community in the North East of Cork City ever since. Culture Night provides an opportunity to view the architecture and church art in the building and hear talks on its origins, heritage and records.

Join us between 6 and 8 pm on Culture Night. Hear a talk by our historian starting at 6.30 pm (finishing 7 to 7.15 pm). See the sacred vessels, the antique altar cloths, the many artworks, and hear tales of the founders, the benefactors, the priests and the people who passed over this holy ground.

And take a rare look into the church records of births, marriages and deaths from upwards of 100 years ago. These books are only ever available to the public on Culture Night.

See an up close view of our beautiful stained glass windows in footage taken by an aerial drone camera.

There will be refreshment available, free of charge.
fullAddress: Iveragh, 294E Old Youghal Rd, Mayfield, Cork, Co. Cork, T23 E3P2, Ireland

This is a celebration of the people who have worshipped, sung, mourned and celebrated happy times in this magnificent church.

Adults and children alike will be entertained as they journey through time in the company of the Roe family as they share stories about the history of the Church and cherished family memories. The Church tour will take place from 5pm to 7pm. Booking essential on www.livingyoughal.ie
