title: To the Letter: Liam Lynch Talk and Exhibition
description:
This presentation by artist Dolores Lyne will include a talk and a fine art exhibition, inspired by the letters of her granduncles, Liam and Tom Lynch, from 1917 to the final stages of the Civil War in 1923. While Liam became IRA chief of staff, Tom was a priest. Lyne decodes the letters, identifying their rural locations and contexts.

The presentation brings to life the human aspect of the Civil War, highlighting one family's struggle in the context of the national struggle. Lynch’s grandniece provides unique insights into her subjects’ thinking , and should prove fascinating to those interested in revolutionary period. She also presents a unique personal perspective on Lynch.

Lyne’s large canvasses evoke the folded letters of the brothers and follow the journey of the dispatches back to the safe houses where they were written. The source material for the exhibition is a trove of family letters, now in the National Library of Ireland’s collection. The bicycle in one of the paintings may have been the actual one used to deliver the message as the owner acted as an intelligence officer during the War of Independence.
fullAddress: The Mick Lally Theatre, Druid Lane, Galway, Ireland

title: Toil and Moil
description:
Toil and Moil is a solo exhibition by artist Emma Swan, alongside a showcase of the Celebrate People’s History poster series, a project initiated by Josh MacPhee.

Toil and Moil is an exhibition featuring painting, sculpture and sound, exploring the significance of time and labour in the work environment. Swan investigates how the introduction of the Henry Ford assembly line revolutionised manufacturing, industry, and society by accelerating productivity. By looking at the repetitive and monotonous nature of industrialised labour, Swan references these practices to protest against the regimented structure of the working day, highlighting the limitations imposed and its prevailing influence.

This exhibition prompts a conversation about labour and workers’ conditions, while facilitating an opportunity to platform strike action and global protest. The Celebrate People’s History poster series demonstrates a DIY tradition that centralises principles of democracy, inclusion and collective action. The project has been organised and curated by Josh MacPhee since 1998, he is a founding member of the Justseeds Artists’ Cooperative and Interference Archive, a public collection of cultural materials produced by social movements based in Brooklyn, NY. Justseeds Artists’ Cooperative is a decentralised network of 41 artists from the U.S., Canada, and Mexico, committed to social, environmental and political engagement. The collection is kindly borrowed from artist and organiser Kate O’Shea.

This exhibition is curated by Rachel Botha.
Design by Emmet Brown.

–

Emma Swan is an installation artist based in Dublin, Ireland. She holds a BA in Fine Art from Technological University Dublin. Her multimedia practice is focused on labour and social hierarchies. Recent exhibitions include GRADX, TU Dublin (2024), PLUID PROJECT, the Cowshed Gallery, Farmleigh Estate (2021). She was selected for RDS Awards’ longlist (2024).

–

Public Programme
Join us for an artist lunch on Saturday 21 September at 1.00pm. A casual gathering for local artists to catch up in the newly opened building. It’s potluck style, so bring a dish or something to share. We will be joined by Elinor O’Donovan from Praxis: The Artists’ Union of Ireland. Book via Eventbrite.

–

Top 8 aim to nurture Ireland’s ever growing and vibrant Street Dance and Hip Hop culture.
This event will take place across two venues in Limerick City on Culture Night, Friday, 20th September 2024.

The first event, held in The Church, hopes to showcase the rich and underground culture of neo-Irish-Afrolism which is a healthy blend of Irish, UK, West-African and American culture with dance cyphers and performances from the Static LED Show. Dance performances will be infused throughout the event in the form of a Performance Platform where the audience will see the social dance moves of Hip Hop and Break Dance, to the rhythmic body movements of Afro fusion and freestyle movements of All Styles. The Performance Platform will be going beyond Street Dance to include all the dance art forms with the following dance exchanges, K.R.U.M.P X Irish dance, Afro dance X Contemporary, Hip Hop X Ballet. This event is open to all.

Top 8’s event will then move to and continue in the Commercial Bar, The Record Room. Where, local and invited DJs will provide the very best in music to bring the night to a close. DJs will include Limerick based Ceese, with a collaboration from Gxrl Codes Mona Lxsa. This event os over 18's
fullAddress: Dance Limerick, John's Square, Irishtown, Limerick, Ireland

description:
The Hunt Museum is excited to host a special Culture Night event catered around jewellery, in collaboration with the Council of Irish Fashion Designers (CIFD). The highlight of the evening will be "Conversations with Jewellery Designers," offering an insight into their creative processes and inspirations.

title: Tour of Marsh’s Library
description:
Guided tours introducing visitors to the historic building housing Marsh's Library, one of Dublin's hidden gems. Very little has changed since the Library first opened to the public in 1707, one of the few Georgian structures still used for its original purpose.

Tour guides will regale attendees with some of the quirkier stories associated with visitors through the years. Follow in the footsteps of Jonathan Swift, James Joyce and Bram Stoker past the famous reading cages.

Tours will take place every 15 minutes on a first-come, first-served basis. Final tour at 20:45. Suitable for all ages.

Join us on Culture Night, Booking Essential. Booking opens on Eventbrite September 5th, small group tours, we ask you to please not waste your ticket. Friday Sept 20th 5.30pm. Age 10 and over, see website for accessibility info.

title: Tours King House
description:
King House is a restored Georgian Mansion in Boyle, County Roscommon.

You will find out about our unique visitor centre that not only tells the story of this important house as a home to the King family and later a barracks to the Connaught Rangers, but also displays important cultural collections and Irish history exhibitions.

Our expert Tour Guides on the day will provide an informative and animated introduction telling you all about the history and cultural exhibitions we have on display before you set off on a self-guided tour exploring King House.

The tour of King House will take approximately 60 minutes.

title: Tours of the Edward Worth Library
description:
The Edward Worth Library was bequeathed to Dr Steevens' Hospital by Dr Edward Worth (1676-1733), an early eighteenth-century Dublin physician. The Library contains wonderfully preserved books dating from the late fifteenth century onwards, which are housed in beautiful early eighteenth-century book cases. Library staff will be giving tours exploring Worth and his Library on Culture Night.

All are welcome to this drop-in event. Please note that due to space limitations each tour can hold no more than 23 persons.

title: Traditional Irish Music and Poetry Night Featuring Comhaltas Ceoltóirí Éireann, Rónán Hession and Chiamaka Enyi-Amadi
description:
This Culture Night, drop in to the Department Tourism, Culture, Arts, Gaeltacht, Sport and Media on Kildare Street for a special evening of trad music from Comhaltas Ceoltóirí Éireann and readings from Rónán Hession and Chiamaka Enyi-Amadi.

Rónán Hession is an Irish writer and musician based in Dublin. He has published three novels: Leonard and Hungry Paul, Panenka and Ghost Mountain. His writing has been listed for a range of major prizes in Ireland and abroad, and his novels have been widely translated. Rónán reviews fiction in translation for the Irish Times and he has been a judge for the Irish Book Awards, the Society of Authors and the British Book Awards.

Chiamaka Enyi-Amadi was commissioned for the Poetry as Commemoration project. Her work is published in The Art of the Glimpse anthology, and she co-edited the Writing Home: The 'New Irish' Poets anthology. Chiamaka is on the editorial board of Unapologetic Magazine, the advisory board of CIACLA, and serves as a Creative Writing Mentor at Fighting Words.
host: Department Tourism, Culture, Arts, Gaeltacht, Sport and Media

title: Traditions of the Traveller Camp and Traveller Singing at Pavee Point
description:
Visitors on Culture Night are invited for a peek behind the scenes at Pavee Point Traveller & Roma Centre, where attendees can talk to the staff and see this important cultural centre.

From 17:00 to 18:00, Travellers will demonstrate some of the traditional skills needed for camp life at the outdoor event ‘Life on a Camp’, featuring recipes from ‘Pavee Peck’ a cookbook by Traveller women.

Then, from 18:30 to 19:30, visitors can enjoy a special film and performance of Traveller Songs. There is a rich tradition of collecting songs and singing within the Traveller community. This year a young Traveller man went in search of the history of the song ‘Campfire in the Dark’. PJ Mongan, supported by Music Generation Galway City, met Paddy Houlihan, the writer of the song. A short film was made with young people from Foróige Ballinfoile youth club which will be screened in Pavee Point and PJ and other Travellers will sing their favourite songs.

title: Truck Art in Irish Apparel by Qandeel Kafeel
description:
'Truck Art in Irish Apparel' is influenced by Pakistani cultural Truck Art which is a vibrant and colourful form of art that is popular in Pakistan. It is typically seen on trucks and other vehicles, and often features intricate designs, geometric and floral patterns, bird and animals motifs as well as landscape. Its vibrant and eye catching aesthetics has captured the attention of fashion world.

In this project, clothing and accessories are hand-painted by Qandeel in these designs. There will be three distinct mannequins - black, white, and brown - representing the universality of this art form and its message of inclusion. At the same time Qandeel will be wearing her cultural dress in truck art and will be there to talk with visitors to the exhibition on Culture Night.

Outside of Culture Night, the exhibition will be open from Thursday, 10am-8pm and Friday, Saturday 10am-5pm.
fullAddress: Naas Library & Cultural Centre, North Main Street, Naas West, Naas, County Kildare, Ireland

title: Try a New Language for Culture Night!
description:
For Culture Night 2024, the European Commission and Languages Connect invite visitors to try a new language at their premises in Europe House.

Take the opportunity to try free 20-minute taster classes in-person at Europe House in Dublin in Chinese, Czech, German, Japanese, Korean, Latvian. Lithuanian, Maltese, Polish and Spanish. Guests are of course encouraged to try more than one language and refreshments will be provided on the night for anybody wanting to take a break between sessions.

If you want to keep up the momentum, European Commission and Languages Connect are offering online taster classes in another 11 languages on European Day of Language, 26 September, from 6 to 9pm. Check them out at the booking link below.

Booking is recommended, though walk-ins may be accommodated if the event isn't at capacity.

title: TullaSkies
description:
The exhibition will feature approximately 30 stunning astrophotography images captured in the village of Tulla and surrounding hills and lakes of East Clare over the past 8 years. The collection will showcase a diverse range of celestial events, including: Lunar Eclipse, Partial Solar Eclipse, Milky Way, Perseid Meteor Shower, Comet NEOWISE, Northern Lights, ISS Transits.

Each photograph highlights the beauty of our local night skies and aims to inspire a sense of wonder and curiosity about the skies above us. Weather permitting with clear skies we will end the event by gathering at the nearby church ruins to participate in a group long exposure shot with the stars.

title: Turas Úr Artists Collective Illuminated Sculpture Trail.
description:
Turas Úr, a collective of Donegal Gaeltacht visual artists, present ‘Art at The Museum with Turas Úr’, featuring a fusion of sculptures, installations, soundscapes, and spoken word. Turas Úr consists of Leanne McLaughlin, Ed Devane, Cathal McGinley, Mickey McFadden and Laura Nic Dhuibhir. This year, the collective will be joined by internationally renowned artists Emily Waszak and Kim Sharkey. Highlights of the evening include a collaboration between Leanne McLaughlin and poet Polina Cosgrave, created for the Irish Museum of Modern Art, entitled ‘Decoding the Waggle’. This piece is inspired by the honeybee’s dance and explores themes of life cycles and matriarchal structures.

Additionally, a vibrant sunflower created with the Ukrainian community, supported by Create and Donegal County Council, will be on display as a symbol of unity and cultural exchange.

Turas Úr at the Workhouse Garden is funded by Creative Ireland.
fullAddress: Donegal County Museum, High Road, Letterkenny, County Donegal, Ireland

title: Turlough Hill 50th Birthday Bash
description:
Hosted in the foyer of ESB HQ at 27 Fitzwilliam Street, an exhibition celebrating the 50th anniversary of Turlough Hill will take visitors on a visual journey, which began in the late 1960s with an ambitious vision to carve a massive cavern deep within a mountain in County Wicklow.

At the time of completion, Turlough Hill – Ireland’s only pumped storage hydroelectric station – was the largest civil engineering project ever undertaken in the country. Carefully curated images will highlight how today, Turlough Hill captures and stores surplus energy generated by wind and solar power, thereby supporting ESBs ‘Net Zero by 2040’ strategy.

As well as this bespoke exhibition, visitors to Turlough Hill 50th Birthday Bash can enjoy poetry recitals by Chandrika Narayanan-Mohan, complimentary barista coffee & cupcakes served from the iconic ESB Volkswagen van or try their hand at generating their own kinetic energy!
fullAddress: ESB Head Office, Fitzwilliam Street Lower, Dublin, Ireland

description:
Embrace your spirit as you 𝘫𝘰𝘶𝘳𝘯𝘦𝘺 𝘪𝘯𝘸𝘢𝘳𝘥 and 𝘤𝘰𝘯𝘯𝘦𝘤𝘵 with the ancient energies of the autumn equinox.

This meditation session is a sacred space for 𝘳𝘦𝘧𝘭𝘦𝘤𝘵𝘪𝘰𝘯, 𝘳𝘦𝘯𝘦𝘸𝘢𝘭, 𝘢𝘯𝘥 𝘦𝘮𝘣𝘳𝘢𝘤𝘪𝘯𝘨 𝘵𝘩𝘦 𝘮𝘢𝘨𝘪𝘤 of this special season.

title: Two Paths Meet
description:
South Dublin County Council Arts Office presents Two Paths Meet, a celebration of traditional Irish and Ukrainian art and culture, produced by Sofft Productions, for Culture Night 2024.
Starting at 2 pm and running until late, Two Paths Meet offers a fantastic opportunity for people of all ages to enjoy the folk traditions of both countries through art, music, poetry, and dance at Rathcoole’s The Old Courthouse as part of this year’s South Dublin Live programme.
Audiences will be treated to an incredible programme, including a special musical collaboration between two internationally celebrated artists – Ukraine’s first ever female conductor Victoria Zhadko, and renowned Irish musician Caoimhín Ó Raghallaigh (The Gloaming, This is How We Fly) at 9 pm. “Ukrainian and Irish cultures have so much in common, both beautiful and sad, that they can and must together, side by side, win their rightful place on the world cultural map. And my honor, right and honorable mission is to do everything in my power for this.” Victoria Zhadko, performer

Enjoy live music from 2pm before exploring an exhibition by Ukrainian artist Alla Shmyhovska, showcasing her beautiful folk dolls that are an iconic representation of Ukraine’s cultural heritage (2.30pm).

Get moving with a Sean Nós Dancing workshop led by the talented Rónán Regan (5pm), and enjoy poetry and songs shared by Ukrainian poet Halyna Budilova (4pm) as well as enchanting sounds of Ukrainian folk musician Kseniya Rusnak (6pm).

Two Paths Meet also features live performances of traditional Irish music led by Tom Moran & Friends (8pm), a group of local musicians who are mainstays of traditional Irish music in South Dublin County.
host: County Hall Tallaght, Dublin 24, D24 A3XC
fullAddress: Main St, Tootenhill, Rathcoole, Co. Dublin, Ireland

title: Tyrone Guthrie Tours and Jamie Duffy Recital
description:
The Tyrone Guthrie Centre, an extraordinary gift to the State by Sir Tyrone Guthrie, has been a workplace for artists for over 40 years. Take a tour of the Big House, studios and lakeside gardens and meet the artists in residence on Culture Night 2024. Guests taking either the 6pm or 7pm tour are invited to stay for the 8.30pm recital with Musician and Songwriter Jamie Duffy. Jamie has become a notable force in the music scene in a few short years and needs little introduction in Monaghan. Seamlessly blending traditional, popular, and classical influences, Jamie's distinctive musical style is simply captivating.

Spaces are limited and booking is required. To book one of the tours, email culturenight@monaghancoco.ie and confirm whether you will stay for the Jamie Duffy Recital at 8.30pm.
fullAddress: The Tyrone Guthrie Centre at Annaghmakerrig, Mullaghmore, Newbliss, County Monaghan, Ireland

title: UCC – Arboretum Tour – Meeting point: Main Gates
description:
Meeting point: Main Gates

Join us for an evening stroll through the trees of UCC where we will discuss the history of this unique botanical resource and how it began as an early outreach and reseach tool.Today, the UCC arboretum stands as a testament to the university's commitment to sustainability and conservation. It is an integral part of the campus landscape, offering a serene environment for students, staff, and visitors. Community engagement and outreach programs as well both national and international collaborations have highlighted the importance of trees in combating climate change and biodiversity loss. These programmes aim to protect and celebrate trees, snsuring their scientific, cultural and historical significance is recognised.

Looking to the future, the arboretum's mission is expanding. UCC is committed to planting more rare and endangered species, enhancing its role in global conservation efforts. Future plans include advanced ecological research initiatives and increased community engagement, ensuring that the arboretum remains a thriving hub for environmental education and a green haven for generations to come. This Culture Night, we honor the past, celebrate the present, and look forward to a future where nature and culture continue to flourish together.
fullAddress: UCC Arboretum, College Road, University College, Cork, Ireland

title: UCC – Boole Library – Tours, VR Demos, Workshops & Activities
description:
Unlock Wonders: Discover, Create, and Preserve: Culture Night at UCC Library - 16:00 to 20:00.
4 varied hands-on and interactive activities. All events are drop-in and take place on the ground floor, Boole Library, UCC. For each event all are welcome but due to equipment child supervision is recommended. 16:00-17:00: Drop by the ‘Caring for library and archives’ materials table and chat with our conservator. See, touch and experience behind-the-scenes tools and materials and learn how we care for and conserve damaged rare items.

16:00-18:30: Create your own Cyanotype: Choose from an array of source materials or bring your own to create a cyanotype, a 19 century photographic process, more commonly known as a blueprint. At the end of your experience take your cyanotype home with you!

16:30-19:00: Immerse yourself in the Digital Scholarship studio showcase via a display of student digital creativity week outputs, light projection mapping, a VR demo with the Oculus Quest, a 3D printing display and Adobe character animator.

17:00-20:00: Explore Boole Library’s cultural spaces and discover how libraries develop in response to the evolving educational landscape. Tours begin on the hour and will last approximately 40 minutes. The final tour will begin at 19:00.

Paint your own fossil! - 16:00 to 18:00
Palaeontologists from Ireland’s Fossil Heritage will be running a family event at UCC Boole Library where you can paint your own 3D printed fossil while learning all about the fossils that are found in Ireland. Ireland’s Fossil Heritage is a public engagement project based at the School of Biological Earth and Environmental Sciences at UCC, funded by Science Foundation Ireland. Parents can browse our photo exhibit – Irish Fossils Hidden Treasures – which will be on display in the same area, while the kids paint their fossils. The event will run from 4 – 6 pm on a first come first served basis. All participants will be able to take their painted 3D fossil home with them.

Irish Fossils Hidden Treasures: Photo Exhibit - 16:00 to 22:00
A photographic exhibition featuring the winning entries from the 2023 National Fossil Photo Contest. The contest invited people across Ireland to photograph an Irish fossil in a natural or an urban environment. The rocks of Ireland contain fossils of many ancient creatures, including plants, shellfish, sharks, amphibians and even dinosaurs. The fossils depicted in the photographs in this exhibition are pictured in situ in their current locations. Collectively, these encompass both urban and natural environments in counties Cork, Galway, Roscommon, Wexford, Sligo and Kerry. The contest was organised by Ireland’s Fossil Heritage – a public engagement project based at University College Cork. The National Photo Contest 2024 is now open and will be accepting submissions until Friday 27th September.
host: UCC Library and Ireland's Fossil Heritage
fullAddress: UCC Boole Library, University College Cork, College Road, University College, Cork, Ireland

title: UCC – Sustainable Futures Lab – Storytelling for Sustainable Futures
description:
A night of stories on nature and climate action. Fiction and arts are essential to develop visions for mutual flourishing in reciprocity with all living beings. Arts and creativity are known to have a positive impact on wellbeing. We all need stories that enable us to see, believe in and act on the possibilities for a better world. On this Culture Night, we will gather at the Sustainable Futures Lab to imagine and shape the future we all long for.

Through participants’ stories, we will envision liveable futures, strengthen social ties that motivate us and empower each other to be creative and do what it takes to make the world we need. To change our relationship with the living world means changing how we think about everything – joy, power, time, space, nature, value, what constitutes a good life, what matters, and how change happens. In a convivial open exchange session, we will invite participants to unleash their imagination and creativity to build hope for a new world, one story at a time…Join us to listen to stories or share your own – all welcome!

Booking here: https://forms.office.com/e/K44cm2TSEw

title: UCC – Tyndall National Institute – Workshops, Demos & Tours
description:
Bring the future to life as Tyndall National Institute opens its doors for an evening celebrating science and technology. Meet our scientists who will present their cutting-edge research and learn about electronics and photonics (the science of light) through a series of demonstration stands and talks.

Children aged 8+ will also have the opportunity to learn about the science of light and electronics by creating their own illuminated greeting cards and spectroscopes.

From our impressive glass atrium, you can observe our state-of-the-art fabrication laboratories, where silicon wafers and microchips are produced. Dress up as a fabrication researcher and learn about cleanroom technology.

description: Our theme is Bharat Sanskritik Pradharshan meaning Indian cultural showcase for the Culture Night in Cork. Experience the vibrant tapestry of Indian culture through an enchanting showcase of dance, music, and fashion. Immerse yourself in the rhythmic beats and graceful movements of traditional and contemporary dances, accompanied by melodious tunes from classical and folk music traditions. Marvel at the rich diversity of Indian fashion, featuring exquisite sarees, lehengas, and intricate embroidery that reflect the country's heritage and craftsmanship. Join us for an unforgettable journey celebrating India's artistic legacy and cultural splendor.

description:
Visit the United Arts Club for a short documentary screening by film-maker Felix Alyn Morgan, followed by a Tour of the United Arts Club.

This event is part of an open house for Culture Night where United Arts Club are delighted to welcome members of the public to come and visit the United Arts Club for a variety of events throughout the night including drawing and art demonstrations, musical performances and tours of our historic building.

Situated in the heart of Georgian Dublin the United Arts Club has, since its founding in 1907, been a meeting place for people with an interest in all aspects of the arts. The Club has a rich and fascinating cultural history with founding members including W.B. Yeats, Countess Markievicz, and AE Russell.

title: Vanessa Daws Exhibition at The Lab
description:
For Culture Night Dublin 2024, The LAB Gallery will welcome visitors to view the new exhibition ‘Swimming a Long Way Together’ by Vanessa Daws, curated by Rosie Hermon. There will also be an artist and curator walk through starting at 5pm, which is bookable at the link below.

‘Swimming a Long Way Together’ is a rolling art project, spanning the past 4 years, created by artist Vanessa Daws and curated by Rosie Hermon. Drawing its inspiration from pioneering swimmer Mercedes Gleitze, the work is a celebration of swimming and swimming communities across the island of Ireland, in South East England and beyond.

The LAB was established by Dublin City Council in 2005 as a municipal arts hub, housing gallery, rehearsal and incubation spaces for a range of art forms. The LAB Gallery supports emerging art practices and delivers a year round programme of free events for all ages. In addition to Dublin City Council, the LAB Gallery is supported by the Arts Council.

title: Virtual Guided Tour on Leonardo da Vinci’s ‘Lady with an Ermine’
description:
Come along to Italian Institute of Culture on Culture Night 2024 for this live virtual guided tour by Mario Bernardi (The Grand Tour) and discover a great work of art with the help of GigaPixel images.

The first masterpiece that will be explored is ‘Lady with an Ermine’ by Leonardo da Vinci.

This event is part of the mini series: ‘Leonardo, Michelangelo and Raffaello: The Image of Woman’ - a series of virtual guided tours led by Mario Bernardi.

Schedule:

• Leonardo's ‘Lady with an Ermine’ - The Courtesan (17:00-17:20)
• Michelangelo's ‘Doni Tondo’ – The Saint (18:35-18:55)
• Raffaello's ‘La Fornarina’ – The Lover (20:15-20:35)

Each 20-minute presentation will be dedicated to a single work by each artist and to his personal and particular way of representing women.

Room: Pavilion Hall

title: Visceral Art Studio presents “This -fruit-ART-EH”
description:
“This-fruit-ART- EH!” is an interactive art installation where you can watch, dance, and include yourself in the composition. A series of acrylic painting surrounded by different elements that embrace the audience will be displayed in a pop-up gallery in Cavan Town.
“Disfrutarte” is Spanish word that means “you enjoy your own self,” is pronounced as the title of this new artwork being presented to the audience. This collection is a fresh new work in which the artist wants to reflect the positive side of self-love and playful spirit, don’t take anything too serious! In this exhibition the spectator becomes part of the collection if they wish. They’re invited to explore the sensations motivated by the sound effects, the visuals and other surprising stimulus in the room, like senses or temperature changes. So they can perform and interact as they feel.
fullAddress: Cavan Town Hall, Town Hall Street, Keadew, Cavan, Ireland

title: Visit Rathfarnham Castle
description: Take this rare opportunity to visit Rathfarnham Castle after hours. Visitors may take a guided tour or self-guide through this fascinating castle. Discover original features dating back to the Elizabethan period at the end of the 16th century, and learn about the origins of the building as a ‘fortified house’. View fine 18th century interiors and learn how the building was transformed into a fashionable Georgian villa with rooms designed by Sir William Chambers and James ‘Athenian’ Stuart. Learn about the different people who once resided here, and the changes in lifestyle over the centuries. Last admission 8pm. Admission free.
fullAddress: Rathfarnham Castle, Rathfarnham, D14 K3T6

genres.title: Visual Arts (Painting, Photography, Sculpture, Digital Art, Print, Etc)

title: Visit the National Science and Ecclesiology Museum at St Patrick’s College Maynooth
description:
On Culture Night, why not visit the National Science and Ecclesiology Museum and see their large collection of scientific instruments and ecclesiastical artefacts.

Firstly, there is a large collection of scientific instruments, mostly associated with Nicholas Callan of which a full catalogue was published in the 1994 book: ‘The Scientific Apparatus of Nicholas Callan and Other Historic Instruments'. The museum now has the largest collection of scientific instruments on public display in Ireland, most of which were manufactured in Ireland between 1880 and 1920.

The second part of the Museum is a collection of ecclesiastical artifacts from the past three centuries including vestments donated by European royalty and a large collection of penal crosses and alter stones.
host: The National Science and Ecclesiology Museum
fullAddress: St. Patrick's College, Maynooth, Collegeland, Maynooth, Co. Kildare, Ireland

From coats of arms to simple labels, these miniature works of art connect us with the past, providing an intriguing window into the history of the former owners. Come and view a selection of the most unique and decorative bookplates in our collection.

title: Voice Workshop
description:
To celebrate Culture Night why not join us for a 1 hour workshop on the actor's voice?

Workshop Overview:

This 1 hour workshop will give you a taster on technique and exercises to maintain a healthy voice. The workshop will focus on how your voice works, the good habits to maintain vocal health and techniques to help you effectively engage your voice when speaking texts. You'll learn techniques to develop posture, breath, voice and articulation, and explore resonance, range and tone as well as vocal variety of pitch, pace and volume.

The workshop will be delivered by our Artistic Director, Kate Canning. Kate holds a higher diploma in Vocal Performance and Teaching and has spent the last 20 years working with actors and singers in understanding technique and connecting voice to body.
fullAddress: Dlr Mill Theatre, Dundrum Town Centre, Dundrum, Dublin, Dublin D16 C5X6

title: Voices from the Bog
description:
Friends of Kilconly Wetlands invites you to 'Voices from the Bog', an evening celebrating the richness of our peatland heritage. Come along and immerse yourself in the natural wonders and cultural heritage of our bogs.

This unique event explores the rich tapestry of our bog landscape: the myths and folklore it has inspired, the culture of peat-harvesting it supported, and the delicate ecosystem it nurtures.

Local people will share oral histories and traditions, while poetry readings will explore the influence of the bog on Irish culture. Gain insights into wetland ecology from Professor Mike Gormally of the University of Galway and discover local creativity in an exhibition curated by artist Sarah Deane, featuring bog-inspired artwork and photographs from the community.

The evening culminates in a traditional Irish music session with local musicians. Join us for an unforgettable celebration of nature, history, and community spirit inspired by our local wetlands.
fullAddress: Ballynagittagh, County Galway, H54 C526

The Mayfair library will be hosting a series of workshops on the evening of Culture Night, where some of the artists offer the opportunity to work with natural fibres for rope-making/ bunting, embroidering on a community-created artwork and screen-printing on canvas bags for Culture Night visitors. Each visitor can take home their own bag. This is a family-oriented activity, suitable for all.

title: Waterbone
description:
In "WATERBONE" by Aisling Roche and David Ian Bickley, the artists explore the harrowing impact of underground nuclear testing on our planet, particularly the delicate marine ecosystem.

Through the use of ceramics inspired by aquatic forms, Projected Augmented Reality, Motion Lighting, and Film, they create a series of immersive and thought-provoking ritual events.

This multi-dimensional experience, transports viewers into a world where the beauty of the ocean is marred by the destructive force of human actions. The artists invite us to reflect on the consequences of our actions through a multi-channel audio visual environment, featuring stunning visuals and a haunting sound design.
fullAddress: West Cork Arts Centre, Uillinn, Coronea, Skibbereen, County Cork, Ireland

title: WATERFORD – THE MUSICAL!
description: An evening of music celebrating Waterford's identifying traits. Expect fun, madness, nostalgia and good old rock and roll featuring Waterford Music Society, Tramore Music Society and Jack Cunningham productions.

fullAddress: Waterford Gallery of Art, O'Connell Street, Trinity Without, Waterford, Ireland

title: Waterside Walks With Historian James Doherty
description:
Join James Doherty for this free historical walk of Waterside as part of Culture Night . The walk will start at 5.30 at the junction of John Street and Waterside.
The walk will last for just under a hour and focus on the trades associated with the area . The history of the Gasworks and the old City walls.

title: Waterstones Bookstore – Readings – Conal Creedon and Molly Twomey
description:
Culture Night at Waterstones means one thing - an early evening reading with Conal Creedon and guest reader, Molly Twomey.

Conal is an author, playwright, film maker and radio writer who has been a fixture of Cork literary life for many years. His new book, Spaghetti Bowl, is published this year.

Molly Twomey is a poet from Lismore, Co. Waterford whose debut collection Raised Among Vultures was published by Gallery Press in 2022. She has won multiple awards and been published in Stinging Fly, Banshee and other journals. An awardee of the Arts Council Literature Bursary she was also the recipient of the 2023 Ireland Chair of Poetry Bursary.
fullAddress: Waterstones, 69 Saint Patrick's Street, Centre, Cork, T12 C921, Ireland

title: Way of the West x Connollys Of Leap
description:
Experience the magic of Culture Night with Way of the West (WOTW) – a spectacular Late Night Event of music and art on the 20th of September, 2024, at Connolly’s of Leap. This event, supported by the Arts Council in partnership with Cork County Council, promises to be a highlight of the cultural calendar, showcasing a dynamic and eclectic mix of performances.

The lineup features some of the most exciting names in the music scene, including Darren Emerson, JFDR, Curtisy, Billy Scurry, Arveene, Bon Voyage, Dj Iphone Charger and Little O. Each artist brings their unique style and energy to the stage, ensuring a night of diverse and engaging musical experiences.

From electronic soundscapes to live performances, there’s something for everyone to enjoy.

As part of the annual Culture Night celebrations, Way of the West is a fantastic opportunity to immerse yourself in the vibrant cultural life of Cork. Connolly’s of Leap, renowned for its atmosphere and exceptional acoustics, provides the perfect setting for this event.

Tickets for this event are free! However, to avoid disappointment, it’s essential to book your tickets in advance. This ensures you secure your spot and don’t miss out on what promises to be an unforgettable night.

Time: 9pm-2:30am
Tickets: Free, booking required
fullAddress: Connolly's of Leap, Main Street, Kilmacabea, Leap, Co. Cork, P81 AK20, Ireland

title: We Act – Spice Culture at CCRC
description: Spice up your Culture Night and visit Clonakilty Community Resource Centre for complimentary spicy, delicious nibbles from around the world, accompanied by an international flavour of music with a drumming workshop with Fergal. All welcome

title: We Act Through Sustainability: Celebrating Lifelong Learning at NCI
description:
Experience the vibrant, educational space of National College of Ireland’s Spencer Dock for Culture Night Dublin 2024.

The National College of Ireland are immensely proud to present a broad range of activities from our various faculties (Business, Computing, Psychology, and Education) that will be on offer for everyone to enjoy on Culture Night.

All are welcome to enjoy this educational, community space. Whether you are eight or eighty, there will be something for everyone. On the first floor, from the afternoon onwards, the Early Learning Initiative (ELI), the School of Computing, and the Centre for Education and Lifelong Learning welcome visitors to the world of computers. On the second floor, engage with the School of Business and Psychology. Discover the new library on the fourth and fifth floors that has been designed for 21st-century learning, all while admiring the artwork that is on display throughout the building.

Complete your night at our storytelling session on the 6th floor and enjoy the striking views of Dublin while listening to local stories about the diverse communities of past and present.

locations.title: Dublin City - Trinity And The Docklands

fullAddress: National College of Ireland, Spencer Dock, Spencer Dock, North Wall, Dublin, Ireland

genres.title: Visual Arts (Painting, Photography, Sculpture, Digital Art, Print, Etc)

title: Weaving History: Exploring the History and Legacy of the wool trade in Kilkenny
description: In the 16th century, John Rothe was a prominent wool merchant who imported wool to be treated and woven at his own mill on the banks of the river Nore. The skill of spinning, weaving and felting has undergone a revival in recent years. Rothe House will welcome Mary O’Rourke, an experienced textile artist and designer who lives and works on her family sheep farm in the Dublin Mountains. Mary is a member of the Irish Guild of Weavers, Spinners and Dyers, who will ‘weave’ stories of the wool trade of years past and demonstrate the craft of spinning. This will be an interactive, hands-on event, allowing audiences to learn more about the cultural importance of this industry and its long connection with Kilkenny.
fullAddress: Rothe House & Garden, Parliament Street, Gardens, Kilkenny, Ireland

title: Welcome to Motherland
description:
Motherland is proud to present a unique selection of work by an array of award-winning Irish filmmakers for Culture Night Dublin 2024. The evening will feature in-depth discussions and screenings, offering a unique glimpse into the creative processes behind some of their most acclaimed projects as well as creatives. Among the highlights, artist Asbestos and director Ross Killeen, will share insights into their feature film Don't Forget to Remember. Additionally, director Rory Hanrahan and producer Louise Byrne will discuss their journey in creating the award-winning short film Wife of the Future. These are just a couple of the exciting projects on the agenda, with more film focused discussions planned throughout the night. Motherland invites you to their home at 7 Hill Street for an evening of film, conversation, wine, and popcorn, celebrating Irish filmmakers!

Motherland is a Dublin-based film production company based in the North Inner City.

locations.title: Dublin City - Monto And North Georgian Quarter

fullAddress: Motherland, Hill Street, Rotunda, Dublin 1, Ireland

title: Westend Hidden Gems
description:
Westend’s Hidden Gems is a multidisciplinary arts event in Galway’s Westend, organised by Galway’s Westend, HystERia, and Púca Productions. The event aims to highlight artistic talent of people who can often be found in the Westend, whether the arts is their primary job or not. It encompasses a variety of performances and activities across venues such as Massimo Bar, The BlueNote, The Crane, Westend Art Collective, Bierhaus, Bell, Book & Candle, Aplomb and more.

Key highlights include a Ceilí at The Crane, a Queer Talent Night at Massimo, Pub Theatre and Open Stages at The BlueNote, a reading hub at Bell, Book & Candle, an art gallery and flash tattoos at Westend Art Collective, a fashion show and DJ set at Aplomb, a surprise gig at Bierhaus, and open air live music and DJ sets on the street. Westend’s Hidden Gems is the community coming together to celebrate culture in all its forms through a unified programme and approach.

For more information please see https://galwayswestend.ie/

description: The Westport FCRC Multicultural Evening, part of Culture Night 2024, will take place at Sacred Heart School in Westport. This family-friendly event celebrates the rich tapestry of cultures in our community with an engaging array of activities. Attendees can explore tables representing various countries, enjoy traditional foods, crafts, and cultural displays. Children will be delighted by face painting and lively entertainment. A world map will be set up for guests to mark their places of origin, and many participants will showcase their beautiful traditional attire. Building on last year’s success, this year’s event promises to be a vibrant and inclusive celebration, fostering community spirit and cultural exchange.

title: Whale Fall
description:
Whale Fall is an evening of artists’ film and painting at J.J. Hough’s Singing Pub in Banagher. The event will feature two films: Whale Fall by Offaly artist Patrick Hough, a short fiction film shot on location in Offaly about the mysterious appearance of a humpback whale in a desolate bog.

The second film is The Wexford Whale, a short animation by artist David Begley, based on the true story of a blue whale captured outside Wexford Harbour in March 1891. Additionally, a series of new paintings by artist Sheila Hough, responding to the films’ themes, will be on display.

Commission funded by Offaly County Council Arts Office

Booking not required

title: Wild Justice
description:
As the Nature Restoration Law is passed in Europe, the wildlife of Merlin Woods decide its time to bring those who participate in wildlife crimes to justice. A natural court of law commences with punishments and guilty verdicts decided by the audience and the wildlife of the woods. Will it be natural decay wrapped in an ivy jail or will it be freedom to rehabilitate in to the natural world. You decide.

An original performance from the Merlin Woods Collective told through the medium of art, drama and music with interactive elements for our audience.
An outdoor performance, seating in the green seat amphitheatre.

Friends of Merlin Woods in association with Merlin Woods Collective

description: Get back to nature with Dúlra Cill Dara’s workshop in the woods for adults in this enchanting evening of discovery and connection with nature. Learn to identify native plants and their uses, master the art of ﬁre-making, and create beautiful nature crafts. Gather around the ﬁre to share stories, songs, and folklore that have been passed down through generations. Enjoy the cúpla fócail over some foraged tea. This unique adult forest school session is a blend of education, creativity, and craic, oﬀering an evening of escape from the everyday. Embrace the wonders of the natural world, and let the forest awaken your sense of adventure!

title: Women Impressionists Exhibition
description:
Marking the 150th anniversary of the first Impressionist exhibition, held in Paris in 1874, Women Impressionists at the National Gallery showcases the works of four important artists. Berthe Morisot (1841-1895), Eva Gonzalès (1849-1883), Marie Bracquemond (1860-1914) and Mary Cassatt (1844-1926) all played vital roles in one of the most revolutionary movements in Western art.

The exhibition explores how each artist navigated complex personal and professional networks to create and exhibit her art, and is the first exhibition to bring these four important artists together in Ireland.

The gallery will have free ticketed time slots for this exhibition. Tickets will be available to reserve on the gallery's website.
fullAddress: National Gallery of Ireland, Merrion Square West, Dublin 2, Ireland

title: Wood Quay Amphitheatre: Learn the Dabkeh
description:
Come along to Wood Quay Amphitheatre and learn to dance Dabkeh, the traditional dance of Palestine. Recognised by Unesco as Intangible Cultural Heritage of Humanity, Dabkeh is danced by Palestinians at a variety of special occasions, spontaneously on the street, as well as in protest and resistance to oppression.

Palestinian and Irish dancers from Apartheid-Free Dance will lead you in learning and dancing a simple Dabkeh dance, which we invite you to take with you, to share and to dance wherever you can. Their goal is to spread the rich heritage and culture of Palestinian Dabkeh far and wide, encouraging its use as a form of resistance. This initiative is about more than just learning a dance; it’s a call to action.

Performed by Omar Qatamesh, Itzel Limon and Salma Atayeh

This event is part of an expansive programme at Wood Quay Amphitheatre for Culture Night Dublin. Filming and photography will be taking place at this location. By attending we assume permission unless a member of our team is explicitly notified.

title: Wood Quay Amphitheatre: Mariachi San Patricio
description:
Mariachi San Patricio has been proudly celebrating the great tradition of Mexican mariachi music in Ireland for over a decade.

Established in 2011, the band is christened San Patricio after the brave St. Patrick's Battalion, an Irish regiment who fought and died for Mexico in the Mexican-American War of 1846-48. The name is a nod toward a beautiful affinity of Mexican and Irish cultures, represented by the soulful gritos of Ireland's only full mariachi.

The ensemble has travelled all over the island of Ireland sharing and honouring the beauty of mariachi music. What started as a passion project bringing the spirit of Jalisco to the heart of Dublin City has since become a moveable fiesta of music, colour and joy.

This event is part of an expansive programme at Wood Quay Amphitheatre for Culture Night Dublin. Filming and photography will be taking place at this location. By attending we assume permission unless a member of our team is explicitly notified.

description:
We are proud to present this exciting, never-been-seen before Culture Night event as part of the 2024 programme. Experience a deeply resonant performance from Dublin’s very own 8-piece Mongolian Khuur Band. Playing a variety of instruments unique to Mongolian culture, including the Morin Khuur (horse head fiddle), the band also features Hoomei (traditional Mongolian throat singing), all accompanied by a mesmerising Mongolian National Dancer. This awe-inspiring performance is certainly not to be missed.

title: Wood Quay Amphitheatre: Seisúin Palaistíneach
description:
Experience an unforgettable evening of music and unity as Irish and Palestinian musicians come together for Seisiún Palaistíneach, a unique event that blends the soulful strains of traditional Irish music with the rich, evocative sounds of Palestinian melodies.

Taking the format of a traditional Irish session, this event will see virtuoso musicians from both cultures performing in the scenic setting of the Wood Quay Amphitheatre. The session will feature a vibrant exchange of tunes and songs, reflecting the deep histories and heartfelt narratives of Ireland and Palestine.

From the lilting jigs and reels of Irish folk music to the hauntingly beautiful mawwal and darbuka rhythms of Palestinian traditions, Seisiún Palaistíneach will offer a spirited exploration of joy, resilience, and shared human experience. This collaborative performance promises not only to entertain but also to foster understanding and connection between diverse traditions.

Don’t miss this rare opportunity to witness the harmony of Irish and Palestinian music in an intimate, engaging environment. Performed by Palestinian artists Abdullah Al Bayyari, Leen Maarouf and Latif Midoume, as well as Faró members Fergus Cahillane, Róisín Ward Morrow, Ben Strong and Richard Breen, join us for an evening where melodies transcend borders, and stories from different corners of the world come together in a celebration of our shared humanity.

Artwork by Cónal Hanamy.

This event is part of an expansive programme at Wood Quay Amphitheatre for Culture Night Dublin. Filming and photography will be taking place at this location. By attending we assume permission unless a member of our team is explicitly notified.

title: Wooden Notes – Soundscapes of the Irish Flora
description:
For centuries, the Irish people have been recognised for their musical talents. This special tour will highlight the musical inspiration that Irish flora has provided throughout history, including the creation of some of Ireland’s most iconic musical instruments, poetry, literature and song.

The tour will journey through the gardens stopping at trees and plants to discover their story and uncover their contribution to our traditional music, poetry and storytelling.

title: Working with Colour: Artist Demonstration with Sara Foust
description:
Sara Foust is known for dramatic use of colour and expressive mark-making in her contemporary landscape paintings. In this artist demonstration, Sara will explain her process of active underpainting and demonstrate colour mixing, wet-into-wet painting, colour glazing and palette structure.

The demonstration will be fascinating for art-lovers and artists of all levels. Sara will demonstrate many painting techniques and how they are used in the various stages of creating a painting.

The event will be hosted in Sara's studio gallery, and audience members will be able to observe Sara's techniques in the many works on display. The event will be friendly and intimate, limited to a small group, with a question and answer period incorporated into the presentation.
venueName: Foust Gallery, 3 Main St, Ennistymon, Co Clare V95TX92
fullAddress: Foust Gallery, Main Street, Ennistimon, County Clare, Ireland

title: Workshop and Performance in Devised Theatre
description:

This workshop is suitable for young people aged 12 to 15 years. The workshop will be followed by a short performance. Family members are invited to attend.

title: Workshop for young artists with Laura Ní Fhlaibhín
description:
Calling all children! Join us this Culture Night for a workshop led by artist Laura Ní Fhlaibhín on her exhibition Edge of Range at Wexford Arts Centre. Laura will introduce children to large-scale drawing on compostable materials. The exhibition will be the starting point for creative, process-led activities such as glow in the dark mark-making experiments, seed germination, and botanical drawing. 

Workshops suitable for children aged 6-10 years.
Admission free but booking is essential.

Edge of Range focuses on the cotton weed plant which is a distinctive species recognized by its dense covering of white, cottony hairs and yellow flower heads.  At present, the cotton weed plant is in a perilous state all across Europe.  The exhibition traces the story of this near extinction through a sculptural installation and wall-based works.
fullAddress: Wexford Arts Centre, Cornmarket, Townparks, Wexford, Ireland

title: Workshop: Green Garden Makers: Crafting Eco-friendly Clay Pots

Explore sustainability and creativity in the garden at The Ark, Ireland's national cultural centre for children!
Do you love nature and want to help the environment? Start your journey at The Ark this Culture Night, creating your very own clay plant pot!

Hosted by Debora Adachi, this engaging taster workshop will guide participants in crafting and designing their own clay plant pots to enhance their local garden for both plants and animals. Through fun, hands-on activities, children will explore natural elements to make designs inspired by nature. With small actions, we can make a big difference!

For our Portuguese-speaking friends, The Ark is hosting a special session conducted in Brazilian Portuguese!

Each workshop is 30 minutes:
16:00 - ages 5 to 7 years
17:00 - ages 8 to 12 years
18:00 - ages 8 to 12 years (delivered through Brazilian Portuguese)

Please note that for this workshop, booking will open at 10am on September 20. This page will be updated with a link to tickets at 10am on the 20th.

title: World Culture – Open Air Multicultural Performances
description: An evening of dance, music and singing from around the world will fill the Town Park with a festival atmosphere this Culture Night. Audiences will get the chance to hear from our African Male Voices and the Ukrainian Women’s Choir. The Letterkenny Indian Community and the African community will wow audiences with their energic mix of traditional and fusion dancing with the Natya Rocks Cinematic Dancers, Dancing Divas Indian dance groups and the Synchronise African dance crew. This celebration brings together the diverse talents of performers from Ireland, Ukraine, Nigeria, Somalia, India, Albania, and Zimbabwe—all now living and working in Donegal.
venueName: Amphitheatre Area / Skateboard Park – Letterkenny Town Park
fullAddress: Letterkenny Town Park, Ballyboe Glencar, Letterkenny, County Donegal, Ireland

title: Would You Like to be a Human Squirrel?
description:
Native Irish Oak - A look at some history, folklore, music, botany, biodiversity around our Irish oak and our role in bringing native Irish oak home again to coastal and rural Mayo.

Deirdre Kennedy is a qualified horticulturist, linguist, engineer and anthropologist. She has worked overseas in various roles in India, Australia and Norway. In recent years, she has caught a vision and passion to facilitate the growing and reintroduction of native Irish oak in to parts of Ireland where it disappeared hundreds of years ago, particularly the Gaeltacht.

Enjoy a cup of tea and chat with Deidre after the talk and hear more of her amazing story about the Irish oaks trees.

Kennedy Oaks
www.kennedyoaks.org
fullAddress: Mallaranny, County Mayo, F28 F8N8, Ireland

title: Writing the Wrongs
description:
Take A Part Carlow is delighted to present a special event, hosted by our Community Writer in Residence, Clifton Redmond.

From 6.30pm, join us at An Gairdin Beo as we launch our second poetry broadsheet, designed by artist, Kate O’Shea and developed as part of “Writing the Wrongs: A creative response to the concept of displacement”, a programme delivered by Clifton earlier this year.

There will be live music by Tullow Road singer songwriter Duane Ayers plus a selection of poems from our wonderful community members!
fullAddress: An Gairdin Beo, Dublin Road, Rathnapish, Carlow, Ireland

title: Writing Workshop with Children’s Author Marian Brennan
description:
This Writing Workshop is with children’s author Marian Brennan. The workshop is suitable for 10–14-year-olds who love writing stories. We will go through basic story structure and what makes a great story. We will discuss how to take readers into a different world, character development, and creating suspense. This will be an active workshop encouraging children to write in the session.

This is an in-person free event however booking is required via the Eventbrite link below.

You can read more about Marian Brennan here: https://www.marianbrennan.com/

This event will take place in the children's library in Baltinglass library.
fullAddress: Baltinglass Library, Weaver's Square, Baltinglass East, Baltinglass, County Wicklow, Ireland

title: Writing your Memoirs with Roscrea Heritage Society
description:
The Roscrea Heritage Society celebrates Tipperary Culture Night with a practical workshop dedicated to writing your own memoirs. All people carry with them unique memories: the Society encourages you to write yours down and save them for future generations to enjoy. With King John’s tower at Roscrea Castle complex as a unique setting, writer and journalist Rebecca Lenehan will offer practical tips and will guide you to turn your memories into powerful stories.

Due to the practical nature of the workshop, seats are limited and need to be booked in advance. More information can be found on the website: www.roscreaheritagesociety.org

title: Youghal Clockgate Tower Tours
description:
Experience life and time since 1777 as a merchant tradesman, gaoler, prisoner, clock winder and family home. Visitors can move through the inner stairs of the four-storey tower to learn about its diverse past as a local time-keeper, gaol and centre of trade.

Led by an expert costumed guide, this iconic building’s story of love, generosity and friendship as well as pain, tragedy and rebellion are literally brought to life through a sensory experience that includes smelling the spices in the Merchants Quarters, touching silks, testing the bed and bathroom facilities in the gaol cell, reading the accounts of the gaoler and winding the enormous clock. The Guided Tour of the Clockgate will take place at 5pm, 6pm and 7pm. No children under 7 years and maximum two tickets per person.
host: Living Youghal & Youghal Socio economic development group
fullAddress: Youghal Clock Gate Tower, North Main Street, Youghal-Lands, Youghal, County Cork, Ireland

description: Prepare to be spellbound by the ZoNa Dance team with innovative choreography, boundless energy, and a performance that resonates with the beating heart of Culture Night. title: 🎨 Hands of Peace: A Hands-On Workshop for Culture Night, Commemorating Imogen Stewart🕊️
description:
Join us on Culture Night for an engaging and inclusive workshop commemorating the renowned sculptor Imogen Stewart, creator of the iconic "Hand of Peace" in Cavan Town. With Imogen's recent passing in 2024, this is a timely opportunity to honor her legacy and educate the community about her contributions to art and peace.

Participants of all ages and abilities will create their own mini "Hand of Peace" using non-messy, air-drying clay. Learn about Imogen Stewart's inspiring life and work through literature and visuals.

Don't miss this unique chance to celebrate art, peace, and community together!

Please note kids to be accompanied by parents.
fullAddress: Magnet House, Farnham St, Keadew, Cavan, Ireland
